PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Sales Tax Legislation
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Humphreys and Mr Barry Jones.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The Government proposes to impose a Sales Tax of 17 1/2 per cent on manufactured pet foods which were previously exempt.
2. That this new tax will impose an unreasonable burden on pet owners, many of whom are pensioners and citizens in receipt of a small income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That a need exists within the community for the Community Youth Support Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government not remove any funds for the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned parishioners of St Luke's Church of England, Vermont, Victoria, requests the following pertaining to the Commonwealth Youth Support Scheme:-
(1) That the Government, in the intervening months from October 1981 to February 1982, should consult widely, especially on the local scene, to explore the affects of C.Y.S.S. in the community.
(2) That C.Y.S.S. should remain the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government.
(3) That the scope of the Scheme should be widened to include a job creation program on a larger scale than at present.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the members of the House retain and extend C.Y.S.S. as requested above, and that your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth; that the serious youth unemployment problem is a direct result of the community's failure to create sufficient jobs.

In these circumstances the decision to abolish Community Youth Support Schemes (CYSS) is a socially retrogressive step. The CYSS Projects provide valuable support services and work training for many young unemployed.

We the undersigned are concerned that the closure of CYSS Projects may lead young unemployed to become involved in anti-social behaviour such as crime, vandalism, prostitution, rebellious behaviour and mob action. There is the even more frightening prospect that many more young people will give up hope of obtaining a job, become idle and even contemplate suicide.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse its decision to abolish CYSS Projects and provide sufficient funds to enable the various CYSS Centres to continue their valuable work with the young unemployed in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5 per cent on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the Budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Librarians and library users throughout the nation call for the exemption of books, periodicals and newspapers from the imposition of sales taxes.

The tax exempt status of libraries and schools will not protect them from general cost increases which sales tax and its collection will cause. Indeed, exemption claims on millions of items per year will themselves add to the cost burden of both libraries and suppliers.
This tax is socially injurious and unworkable, and a burden on education, science and culture.
Your petitioners therefore pray: that your honourable House will exempt books, periodicals including newspapers from the proposed sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed changes to assistance to the passenger motor vehicle and components industries after 1984 shall lead to the collapse of the vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia. Your petitioners therefore pray that the Industries Assistance Commission report be not given effect.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell, Trans Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology and environment of the Island.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the Register of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act, 1975 take into consideration the protection of the island.

3. That the Queensland Government has given approval to the sandmining of Moreton Island despite the advice of conservationists and despite the opposition of the majority of electors in the Moreton Region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to refuse export permits covering mineral sands mined on Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Aid to Polish Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Rt. Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that recent events in Poland are of such seriousness as to justify Australia's direct involvement in attempts to relieve tension there.
Your petitioners note that food shortages are a major cause of civil unrest.
Your petitioners further note that Australia has the capacity to make direct donations of food at short notice.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;
That the Federal Government make the Polish Government an immediate and substantial offer of food aid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Hon. the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:
1. That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the poverty line.
2. That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That women's refuges have provided on a 24 hour a day basis emergency accommodation, child care, financial aid, moral support, legal advice and guidance in dealing with government departments for over 13,000 women and children in the past year at a cost to the national government substantially less than $4 million which is half the cost of holding the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Australia later this year.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will not proceed with its stated intention to withdraw from funding women's refuges and pass this responsibility to ill-equipped and sometimes unsympathetic State Governments and will increase federal funding levels for women's refuges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pancrease: Australian Drug Evaluation Committee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That tests performed at the Royal Children's Hospital, Brisbane, indicate that the drug, Pancrease, can provide significant relief and assistance to sufferers of cystic fibrosis.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the government will require the processing of the drug, Pancrease, by the Australian drug evaluation committee of the Department of Health, as a matter of high priority.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government and Telecom management have presided over the deliberate scaling down of Australia's telegram services, to the disadvantage of those poorer people in the community who cannot afford telex or telephone facilities and rely on the Telegram service in time of emergency; that the Government and Telecom management have undermined the telegram service by increasing the unit cost of telegrams by over 130 per cent in four years with the result that the use of telegrams as a form of communication has fallen by approximately 60 per cent in that time.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government and Telecom management retain the telegram service at a standard and cost that will not disadvantage the ordinary citizen.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That retired low and middle income superannuants are disadvantaged by (a) inflation (b) double taxation and (c) low means test for the aged pension.
(2) That the age pension means test has not been increased since September 1972.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will increase the means test for all pensions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Eagle Farm Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That noise levels created by aircraft using Eagle Farm airport already constitute an annoyance and inconvenience to those residents living near the airport and along flight paths.
That relaxation of the Eagle Farm airport curfew to allow any aircraft including TAA's airbus to fly into and out of Eagle Farm airport between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. would:
(a) substantially increase the inconvenience and annoyance caused by aircraft noise because the operation of aircraft at this time would seriously disturb people's sleep;

(b) contradict and negate a commendable undertaking made by the Commonwealth Minister for transport, the Hon. Ralph Hunt, in reply to a question on notice in the parliament, that the curfew will remain on the runways at the existing site at Eagle Farm airport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will not approve the application of TAA-or any other airline-to relax or withdraw the curfew at Eagle Farm airport.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.
(ii) The imposition of tuition fees for second degrees and post graduate degrees will deter many able persons from enrolling in such courses and further preserve higher education for the rich.

(iii) The introduction of a loans scheme, subsequent review of the level of TEAS and the tightening of the eligibility criteria for TEAS will cause great financial hardship and will deter students from enrolling in tertiary institutions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(1) post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
(2) the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
(3) the government reverse its decision to introduce a loans scheme and instead increase and extend TEAS scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant variety rights in other countries has had adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed onto the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic material from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant variety rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Telephones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the Federal Government has power to withdraw the commissions granted to the Posts and Telecommunications and reunite into one service run by the Government staff under control of Public Service Board as a service to the Australian people, and not a business making erratic high profits, only possible because they are a monopoly, and no responsibility for large mistakes. A uniting of the two services established in 1809 which ran successfully until 1975 that kept pace with any country in the world, this is where Telecom took over and from the men that had to learn and teach and are still with us, but the Management has had no experience in this type of business. The Managing Director has resigned? We humbly urge the supply of a free Telephone for pensioners very ill and living alone.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Gambling Casino in Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra would debase the National Capital and increase crime in Canberra.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should seek to preserve the dignity of the National Capital by disallowing any ordinance to authorise the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That the way in which we treat the animals entrusted to our protection is a reflection of our concern for people;
(2) That charitable organisations which work in the area of animal welfare must have the funds to help them to pursue and promote a policy of more enlightened and humane treatment towards animals;
(3) That tax concessions for donors to animal welfare charities-
(i) would achieve much toward alleviating unnecessary suffering and cruelty toward animals;
(ii) would bring animal welfare charities onto a more equal footing with other charities.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will legislate to amend present taxation laws to enable the extension of tax concessions to people and organisations who donate funds to accredited animal welfare charities.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Eagle Farm Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(a) That residents of densely populated suburbs in the vicinity of the airport and residents of other suburbs in the flight path of international and domestic jets are experiencing an unreasonable degree of aircraft noise.
(b) Further, that these same residents will be subjected to prolonged bouts of such aircraft noise if a decision is taken to extend the curfew at both the domestic and international airports.
(c) That this decision has been foreshadowed on two occasions as follows:

(i) In Submissions to the Public Hearing held by the Public Works Committee of this Parliament in regard to Stage One-Redevelopment of Brisbane's International Airport; these submissions proposed an extension of the existing curfew when the new runway is completed (approx. 1986). This proposal received the full support of the Queensland Government.
(ii) TAA's request for an extended curfew to coincide with the introduction of the Airbus.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will refuse to extend the existing curfew and will reconsider its siting plans for the proposed new runway so as to minimise noise pollution over high density suburbs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That Federal Government proposals to shift the cost of health insurance onto the individual has placed a disproportionate and unfair financial burden on lower income groups, but particularly on large families; single income families; the chronically ill; those with recurrent illnesses and those on fixed incomes

2. That an estimated 15-20 per cent of Australians will not be able to afford insurance and will be forced to undertake extensive travel to avail themselves of outpatient services, the quality of which will be drastically reduced because of staff cuts
3. That doctors, who at this moment are awaiting a fee increase, will inevitably become more and more expensive

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government (i) will re-examine the effects of health proposals and of the necessity for compulsory health insurance on lower income groups who do not presently meet the description of disadvantaged, and (ii) redefine the criteria determining the genuinely needy and disadvantaged to encompass the categories of persons mentioned in (1.) above.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic projects is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aspect House for Handicapped Children
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. All children in Tasmania are not treated equally
2. Persons with intellectual, physical and multiple handicaps in particular will be denied access to Aspect Homes, 6 Warragul Avenue, New Town in Tasmania if the house is closed
3. Aspect house is faced with imminent closure because of lack of Government policy and on-going funding

4. Aspect House is the only community-based facility in an ordinary house in an ordinary suburban setting which provides relief to parents and families engaged in the onerous and demanding task of rearing their handicapped children in the community
5. That the rights of all children to live with their families should be respected
6. That we seek Government to take immediate action to prevent the closure of this unique facility
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Planning Association of Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action as it deems appropriate to ensure the continuing effectiveness of the Family Planning Association of Victoria.
In particular that:
Federal Government continue to provide funding to the Family Planning Association of Victoria for clinical services to meet the growing demands of the community.
Increased funding be provided to the Family Planning Association of Victoria's Training, Education & Research Unit for educational services to the community.
All funding be provided on a triennial basis to enable cost-effective long term planning.
The Federal Government grant the Family Planning Association of Victoria exemption from sales tax and allow donations to be tax deductible.

That we, the undersigned, support the expansion of family planning services to ensure that adequate contraceptive information is fully available to all sections of the community, with special consideration given to disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully request that the Federal Government ensures that:
(a) it honours its 1975 election promise to maintain Medibank-a free, universal health insurance scheme, and instigate methods of improving hospital and health services for the Australian people.
(b) The Community Health programme remains a Federal Government responsibility, with increased funding and expansion of services.
(c) It abandons means testing and the re-introduction of charges at public hospitals which will severely disadvantage low and middle income groups.
(d) Every effort will be made to meet the health care needs and demands of the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled will give earnest consideration to this most vital matter.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: We, the people who have signed this petition ask all parties, Labor, Liberal, Democrats and others, to stop the latest increase in taxes and the forever increases in taxes which hit all people of the country of Australia in all goods and consumer goods and we call for a referendum on taxes and interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the underesigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled in Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult-as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure-and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) the imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners pray that:
(1.) post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students
(2.) the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately
(3.) the Minister of Education immediately clarify the government's attitude to the re-introduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Census Forms
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Commonwealth Government, on the advice of the Bureau of Statistics has rejected the view that all census forms should be retained, as they are in Britain and the United States. These forms contain much vital information of an historical, medical and sociological nature which should be available to future generations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this decision be reconsidered especially since the view of a majority of the members of the Australian Law Reform Commission was in favour of retaining individual census returns.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Subsidy Payments for Nursing Home Patients
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The majority of pensioners in nursing homes are currently not receiving any significant rebate after all fees and laundry expenses are paid. This situation does not allow for a basically acceptable quality of life and undermines the dignity of people who are unable to fend for themselves. We call upon the Federal Government to investigate the plight of these people and guarantee them at least the opportunity to financially support their own basic needs.

2. When residents of nursing homes go to stay with friends or relatives for short periods-e.g. weekends-they are compelled to pay the Commonwealth subsidy for the period of their absence. This expense is obviously not able to be met by the majority of nursing home residents or their friends and relatives. The result is that people who would benefit from short periods away from the nursing home are restricted to its confines because they are not in the position to pay for their release. This situation causes emotional trauma on festive occasions such as Christmas and birthdays.

We feel this is a hardship that should not be borne by nursing home residents and call on the Federal Government to relax its policy regarding subsidy payments for nursing home residents on short leave.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Government policy on subsidy payments for nursing home residents on short leave, be relaxed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decrease in Federal Government funding for health, transfer of Commonwealth responsibility to the States, application of the 'user' pay principle to health services and encouragement of private business and profits in the health sphere will inevitably lead to a downgrading of health services and increasing health risks among people who cannot afford health insurance or private payment of doctors and hospitals.

That the cuts in Federal Government spending resulting from the recommendations of the Cabinet Sub-Committee of Review of Government Functions-Razor Gang-will lead to an increase in unemployment and a general deterioration in community services and living standards.
Therefore your petitioners urge that:
(1) The Government continue Commonwealth funding of health services at an improved, and certainly not a lesser, level than that operating prior to September 1, 1981.
(2) That recommendations of the Cabinet Sub-Committee of Review of Government Functions-Razor Gang-be not proceeded with.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Maranoa respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Farrer respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate the downgrading or closure of The Rock 2655 post office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Hume respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate the downgrading or closure of Adelong 2729 post office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Calare respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Ryan respectfully showeth:

That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate the downgrading or closure of St Lucia South 4067 post office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Reid respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Melbourne Show Band
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that:

As regular viewers and listeners of the ABC Melbourne Show Band we were disappointed to learn of the dismissal of seventeen members of this outstanding orchestra. We have had a great deal of pleasure over the past eight years viewing and listening to this Band's fine music. It is the only full-time light orchestra in Australia and we are disgusted to think that such talented musicians should be dismissed in this manner.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full show band.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the employees of Repco Limited Trading as Hardy Spicer (Australia) Company 45-49 McNaughton Road Clayton 3168 respectfully showeth-

Our jobs as Australian automotive parts manufacturers will be lost and our families and children will also lose job opportunities now and in the future if more imported cars and component parts are allowed to be imported.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will preserve our jobs, by reducing the current level of imported cars and parts coming into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your petitioners resident in the Tasmanian North-West Coast and West Coast municipalities of Circular Head, Wynyard, Burnie, Penguin, Waratah, Zeehan, Strahan, Queenstown and Gormanston are desirous of retaining first class air service through the major airport serving the area, namely the Wynyard airport.

Since the Government has agreed to provide $5.5m for Devonport which serves a smaller population and area, we ask the Government as a matter of urgency to also provide sufficient funds to upgrade Wynyard airport to the standard required for it to accommodate medium size jet aircraft.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled will give urgent consideration to this request.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives. This humble petition of citizens of the Geelong region in the State of Victoria respectfully request the Federal Parliament not to accept the I.A.C. recommendations on the motor vehicle industry as they would, if accepted, have a disastrous economic effect on the region and would create massive unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Ballarat respectfully showeth
1. That the proposed imposition of 2 1/2 per cent sales tax to building materials will have a disastrous effect on the already seriously depressed industry.

2. That the latest interest rate rise of 1 per cent to home mortgages will now end the hopes of many intending first home buyers. We believe the Federal Government must initiate a scheme of assistance to first home buyers, as proposed by building industry representatives.
In conclusion we reject the Federal Government's lack of genuine interest in the home industry. We also clearly state that the effects of points 1 and 2 above are not acceptable to us.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government give immediate attention to an already seriously depressed industry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the Gallery this morning a delegation from the National Assembly of the Hungarian People's Republic led by Mr Janos Peter, the Deputy Speaker of the Assembly. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to the members of the delegation.

—Has the Minister for Communications seen the report in today's Canberra Times of statements made by Senator Walsh in the Senate alleging that the Minister put pressure on Mr Webster of the Australian Dairy Corporation to issue an export certificate in breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangement? Did the Minister instruct Mr Webster to issue a certificate to a manufacturer at some time between 13 October and 15 November 1976, or at any time between September and 15 November 1976? The Minister, in two statements to this House, has said that as soon as he was advised of the breach of GATT he instructed Mr Webster to end it. Can the Minister inform the House of the exact date on which he was advised of the breach, or are we to assume that he was advised in September 1976, as Mr Wallace's evidence to the Senate Committee states?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The source of the allegation in the Senate sufficiently demonstrates its calibre and quality. It was made by a person for whom I have little regard and absolutely no respect. In terms of the representations made to me by manufacturers, it is true that over an extended period as Minister for Primary Industry, quite a number of people came to me asking whether it would be possible to export particular agricultural commodities, including skim milk powder. The price control mechanisms, of course, were operated through the Australian Dairy Corporation and any requests sent to me were passed on to the Australian Dairy Corporation. I know that on some occasions new markets were sought to be developed and propositions were made about concessional terms in order to become established in those markets. At no stage did I approach the Australian Dairy Corporation to breach international arrangements in order that those sales could be concluded. However, I certainly passed on many requests to the Australian Dairy Corporation under the chairmanship of Mr Webster for consideration of whether they were exports which should be approved. In the very vague way in which the suggestion has been made in the Senate, I find it impossible to know whether the particular discussion took place as alleged, but at no stage did any discussion take place between me and Mr Webster or any other officer of the Australian Dairy Corporation suggesting that there should be a breach of the international GATT arrangement or in any other way in order that Australian sales could be augmented or should take place.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the other part of the honourable gentleman's question concerning the time lapse before advice was received from the ADC about the breach of the pricing arrangements within GATT. Discussions were held between my officers and me after the officers advised me about the sale having been made at a price less than provided for by international arrangements. There was correspondence-I think in telex form-between the departmental officers and the ADC instructing the ADC to terminate the breach and, as a result, at the first possible occasion I saw Mr Webster to confirm those instructions. As I remarked in the House before, there was no time lag between the advice to me and the instructions from the Department to Mr Webster to terminate that breach.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Has the Government given consideration to undertaking the preparation of family impact statements on a continuing basis to monitor the effect on families in recent years of all relevant government revenue raising policies, expenditure programs and movements in major economic indicators? Does the Treasurer recognise the need for such statements involving all three levels of government and involving family samples in each State? Would not such statements involving official, objective data be a necessary prerequisite for the Government in deciding the extent and direction of any future tax relief for the family unit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question raised by the honourable member for Perth is a very thoughtful one. I must say that the idea of a family impact statement as such has been put to the Government on a number of occasions. I certainly have sympathy with the objective. Whether that is quite the most productive methodology to be adopted to provide governments with all the information that ought to be at their disposal when taking revenue and expenditure decisions is perhaps another matter. But the honourable gentleman, whose concern to see that Government policies are sensitive to family interest is well known to the House, properly reminds us that we ought to have objective information available when we take decisions that affect the family.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, the current debate on the impact of sales taxes on average family incomes is testimony to the need for more objective information, because some of the exaggerated claims that have been made about the impact of these taxation measures on family incomes indicate that the people making those accusations are completely without any objective data so far as the impact of these measures is concerned. Of course, ultimately the quality of individual government decisions is reflected in the results. If one looks back over the last five years at areas of enormous significance to Australian families, one sees very great improvement. For example, the level of home ownership has risen some 4 per cent or 5 per cent in the last five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not; it has fallen.

—Since 1976 it has risen significantly, according to the latest survey. There cannot be anything more important to the quality of life of average Australian families than the overall level of home ownership. If one looks at the level of inflation, which affects all of us, and at other measures of the standards of living, one sees a pattern of constant strengthening in growth over the past few years. I will address myself to the question of whether a family impact statement would be appropriate even though it may not be possible, as a result of that examination, to justify the enormous commitment in terms of man hours that would be involved in preparing it. I can nonetheless assure the honourable gentleman that in future revenue and expenditure decisions of this Government continuing and special regard will be paid to the interests of Australian families.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Prime Minister about South Africa and diamond policy. In view of the fact that the Ashton diamond mine will provide an increment equivalent to half the present total world production of diamonds, does the Government see this development as a remarkable opportunity for the establishment of a totally new and massive industry for Australia not only in mining but also in processing? Is the Government continuing to ignore this huge potential benefit, as the Deputy Prime Minister indicated to the House a few weeks ago, by its failure to set in place a diamond marketing policy, or is the Prime Minister now in a position to apprise the House of the Government's policy towards this new and exciting prospect?

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Prime Minister aware that with Zaire and the Soviet Union having left the De Beer's Central Selling Organisation, the CSO is now particularly vulnerable to a large low cost potential producer such as Ashton? Finally, in the light of the Prime Minister's firm view on South African policy, what does the Government intend to do to guarantee that Australia's huge diamond output will not be swallowed up by the South African diamond syndicate, serving only to make the De Beer's monopoly stronger and more resilient at a time when its old high cost diamond mines are rendering it less and less competitive?

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman has asked a detailed question. I will have the matter examined and see what information can be provided to him. I would like to comment in particular on the last part of the honourable gentleman's question. I can see no advantage to Australia or to Australian industry in having arrangements in which Australian diamond discoveries only serve to strengthen a South African monopoly in these areas. I believe that that would be contrary not only to the interests of Australia but to the interests of Australian corporations. Any examination that we would undertake would be against that background. The honourable gentleman has asked a complex question. I will see what information can be provided to him.

—I ask the Minister for Transport what criteria he would require to be satisfied before approving specialist or no-frills air services to and from Western Australia? Secondly, are there any current approvals or licences for such services to or from Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no approved specialist passenger services from Western Australia at present. I expect the 1981 airlines agreement to be proclaimed within the very near future. Therefore, any applications will be considered against the background of the new airlines agreement. If an operator proposes a specialist-type service which differs from the type of service that is offered by the major operators and which serves a need that the major operators are not offering, it is possible for the Minister to ask the two major airlines whether they are prepared to offer that service. If they are not prepared to offer that service then the Minister could-I repeat 'could'-approve such an application.

ANSWER.PARA: I have approved a specialist service between Sydney and Canberra under the 1972 airlines agreement. I regarded the application by East-West Airlines Ltd for a no-frills service, where passengers can purchase tickets aboard the aircraft, where no services are provided on the aircraft free of charge and where baggage is carried on to the aircraft, as being a quite different type of service from that being offered by the major operators on that route or on any other portion of the trunk route.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. In view of the answer given to the Leader of the Opposition yesterday conceding the social importance of Telecom Australia in providing services in areas where the density of traffic is such that profitability in narrow economic terms is unlikely in the foreseeable future and in view of the Minister's statement that it is only in the major population areas of Sydney and Melbourne that the profit potential is high, why does the Minister persist in inhibiting the expansion of Telecom into new, highly profitable areas of communication? Would this extension of Telecom's activity not better enable Telecom to improve its facilities and range of services throughout the rest of Australia, particularly in country areas, which, I take it, he is very interested in? Why did the Government ignore the report of McKinsey and Co. Inc., which in June 1980 recommended increased capital investment by Telecom for these very purposes? Why is it necessary to set up yet another inquiry into Telecom which must inevitably come to the general conclusion that the Minister came to yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what the honourable gentleman's question is directed at. In terms of the extension of Telecom's activity into the provision of new technological services, there is little doubt that it has done so. It is for that reason that it is maintaining the level and standard of services that it now provides. Only this week it announced a new package designed to facilitate data transfer around Australia. It is a very significant development and is one which will offer to data and computer users a significantly more economic basis of data transfer than was previously available. If that is the basis of his question, I suggest that he is on the wrong ground altogether.

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of the inquiry is to try to ensure that, in the very rapidly developing communications period we are about to enter, there is a capacity for the Australian community to have the greatest possible diversity of facilities available. There is no reason that the honourable gentleman has advanced in his question, nor any that has been advanced by McKinsey in that report, nor any that has been advanced in this House and on other occasions for suggesting that Telecom alone should have a monopoly to operate in this entire area. Indeed, the very opportunities for diversity are paramount with technological change. Our concern is that the public dollar should be spread as far as possible and, where possible, the private dollar used to extend the facilities available. The purpose of the Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia-the Davidson inquiry-is to ensure that Telecom can move into the next decade and into the year 2000 able to provide those services which Australia provides at the most economic level and without undue demand on the capital facilities of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the wounding of a member of the Australian Embassy in Cairo, Mr John Woods, during the assassination of President Sadat on the sixth of this month. Can the Minister inform the House of the present condition of Mr Woods?

—I am pleased to be able to inform the House that the condition of Mr John Woods, who was seriously wounded at the time of the assassination of President Sadat in Cairo, has very much improved. He has been under treatment in an Egyptian military hospital and Dr Cumming, the chief medical officer of the Australian High Commission in London, has been in Cairo to advise and assist in his treatment. Assistance has also been given to Mr Woods by United States Army doctors. It is planned to evacuate Mr Woods today, Cairo time, to the United States Air Force hospital at Wiesbaden in the Federal Republic of Germany aboard a specially equipped United States medivac aircraft. He will be accompanied by his wife and daughter and by Dr Cumming. I take this opportunity to record the Government's thanks to the Egyptian authorities for the medical treatment they have provided and to the United States authorities for their assistance with the evacuation and treatment at Wiesbaden. I inform the House also that arrangements have been made for Mr Woods's parents to travel to Wiesbaden to be with their son and his family. I am sure that all members of the House will join me in expressing our concern at John Woods's injuries and our best wishes for his recovery.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether he recalls issuing a Press release on 10 September in which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government has decided to defer issuing the application to de-register the Builders' Labourers' Federation at the present time because of the legal implications associated with the Royal Commission proceedings.

Did he further state that the Government had made this decision on legal advice from counsel having regard to the possibility of the embarrassment to the Federal Court of Australia, to the royal commission or to the parties who may be involved in the proceedings and to ensure that the royal commission, with its wide terms of reference, was not inhibited in its operation? I ask therefore: On what grounds did the Government reject this legal advice and decide to go ahead with proceedings on 25 September?

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman is well aware of the conduct of the Builders Labourers Federation, subsequent to that statement of mine, which I have explained to the House and which led to the institution of the deregistration proceedings. Before those proceedings were instituted the Government took legal advice. I understand that there is a hearing before the Federal Court of Australia today when an application by the BLF to defer the royal commission will be dealt with. Of course, the Government has taken legal advice. The Victorian Government has taken legal advice and the royal commissioner himself will be represented before the court.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education, refers to his announcement on 30 April that the Government intends in 1982 to introduce a tertiary students' loans scheme to supplement the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and to be administered by the tertiary institutions and the banks. Will the Minister advise the House of what progress has been made towards the introduction of this scheme?
—I call the Minister for Education.
—There is a question on notice which I have asked myself.
—The honourable gentleman will need to direct my attention to the number of the question.
—It has been on the Notice Paper for some time. We have only this week's Notice Paper. It would take me some time to find the question but I can assure you that it is in almost the same terms.
—I regret that I cannot prevent the Minister from answering until I can see the question on the Notice Paper. I call the Minister for Education.
—In answer to the question raised by the honourable member, it is a fact that the Government--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Dr Klugman

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is question No. 3278 which is directed to the same Minister and which reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: When will he announce details of the loans scheme for tertiary students to supplement Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I uphold the point of order raised by the honourable member for Prospect.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I was not asking for details of the scheme but for information on the progress made towards the introduction of the scheme-the negotiations with the banks and matters of that kind.
—I have given my ruling, and I adhere to it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and is supplementary to the question asked yesterday by the member for Calare concerning the Minister going soft on a second runway for Sydney airport. I ask the Minister: When will the Government go hard on the Prime Minister's statement that a second airport for Sydney is now considered necessary?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for the question because it gives me an opportunity to try to explain to this House and to those who do not want to understand that the development of a close spaced parallel runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is quite a separate issue to that of a second Sydney airport.
—Absolute rubbish.
—Give them a go.

—The members of the Australian Labor Party try to hide behind the possibility of developing a second Sydney airport. A couple of Labor Party members in this House do not want a second Sydney airport because it could be in the vicinity of their electorates. But the truth of the matter is that Sydney airport is now nearing maximum capacity. It will take at least 12 to 15 years to remove 600 people from one site and thousands of people from another site--
—Which site?

—And resettle them. There you are, the honourable gentleman wants the Government to name the site. The whole approach to Sydney's airport problem is a political ploy of the Opposition, and it is prepared to play politics at the expense of the people of New South Wales and of Australia. That is how shallow their attitude is towards the aviation needs of the State governed by a Labor Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly there are two separate issues. There are the immediate needs of Kingsford-Smith Airport to meet the growing traffic and, as the Major Airport Needs of Sydney study indicated, there may be a need for a second airport in the next century. But even the officials who wrote that report were not prepared to predict that a second Sydney airport would be in fact necessary. So, as much as members of the Opposition might try to laugh themselves out of their own problem, there is an immediate problem in Sydney and unless the Labor Government of New South Wales is prepared to act with responsibility it will be responsible for the downgrading of Australia's number one airport.

—The Minister for Primary Industry is aware of the importance of the live sheep export trade in underpinning the viability of the sheep industry. In view of the opposition to this trade by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the animal liberation movements, can the Minister assure the House of the Government's full support to ensure that this trade continues without disruption?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has given support to the live sheep export trade for good and valid reasons. There is a demand in a number of Middle East countries for live sheep. They firstly have a preference for freshly killed meat and, secondly, in some cases they do not have facilities available for the handling of frozen meat or chilled mutton. We as a government also have given encouragement to the development of facilities in a number of Middle East countries to increase their capacity to handle chilled meat but this will not move their consumer preference away from live sheep. Therefore, if Australia does not meet that market requirement they will move their purchasing to some other product in some other country. It has been established that they are able to purchase alternative products from other countries to satisfy their demand. So the Australian sheep industry is really built up to meet this new trade. I met representatives of the ACTU here several weeks ago and we had a good discussion on the problems of the live sheep export trade. They sought answers to several other questions that were put to us and we agreed to provide those. I provided that information, but unfortunately before we were able to meet again as agreed, the ACTU congress carried a resolution seeking to place a limit on the live sheep export trade.
—Shame.

—It is a shame. That is exactly what it is. It is a shame because the fact is that the Australian sheep industry has developed to meet this trade. There has not been a transfer within the Australian community from live sheep to cold killed sheep. There has in fact been an increase in the slaughterings of sheep for the Middle East trade as well. I was able to demonstrate that to the ACTU. The abattoir side of the industry has not lost its numbers; the live sheep part of the trade has built up its numbers.

ANSWER.PARA: I have written to the President of the ACTU seeking to know whether he wants to meet again following the carrying of the resolution by the ACTU. I can only assume that the earlier arrangement we made will be met and that we will meet and discuss the matter further. I hope that is the case because I believe we have undeniable proof that the live sheep trade is a very valuable and important part of the trade and does not affect the abattoir industry. The Government does support the live sheep export trade.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and refer him to his statement of 24 September last regarding the Community Youth Support Scheme, when he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the current CYSS projects will receive their current level of funds until 28 February 1982.

What provision has been made for funds to be made available to cover increased costs, such as increases in project officers' salaries? If no such provision has been made, how does the Minister expect the projects to meet such expenses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be understood at the outset-I do not think it has been fully understood over the years-that the Commonwealth Government is not the employer of CYSS project officers. Those project officers are in fact employed by local committees which have the responsibility for the day-to-day running of the CYSS projects. However, when the funds are calculated reference is of course made to, amongst other things, prevailing salaries in the community in similar fields. As the honourable member said, the Government made a decision that the current projects would receive their current level of funds until 28 February next year, to enable the Government to conduct a wide ranging process of consultation with community interests as to the new guidelines under which the Scheme should be conducted after that time. We are making funds available to projects at the current levels until that time.

ANSWER.PARA: Within the overall sum that the local committees have they may have-I am prepared to consent to this-responsibility to redistribute their funds so that if in their own discretion, judged on local circumstances, they believe that it is appropriate to pay additional money to project officers, they may do so, but within the ambit of the lump sum which is paid to them. It is not possible to pay additional money to the projects simply because there has been an increase in salaries for people in similar fields of employment. It is a matter of the local committees exercising their responsibility and judgment. I think most people would agree that there is a responsibility in making decisions with respect to spending money, especially when it is not one's own. It is a responsibility which the local committees will have to exercise themselves. They may decide, with reference to local circumstances, that it is more appropriate to pay additional money to the project officers until that time and to devote less money to other activities of their project. That is a matter for them to decide. If they wish to do that I am prepared to consent to it.

I might add also that, to assist local committees that wish to take part in the consultation process, they may also use a small part of their funds-I will be giving details of this later-to enable project officers or other committee representatives to take part in some of the conferences that are being held to enable submissions to be put to the Government as a part of the consultation process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Can the Minister advise the House whether the recently arrived boat load of Vietnamese people in Darwin Harbour have been given the status of refugees or are they illegal immigrants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bradfield and several other members from both sides of the House have raised that matter with me in recent days. Investigations are continuing and we have not yet determined the status of those on board. We became aware of the vessel when it reached Malaysian waters and the close co-operation which we have with the Malaysian Government enabled us to ascertain that the vessel had not come from Vietnam. When it was heading south, the Governor-General proclaimed the Immigration (Unauthorized Arrivals) Amendment Bill which this House passed last year. I expect, as a result of the interrogations, that we will take action either under that Act or under the Migration Act and perhaps under other legislation to prosecute at least some of the people on board. There are, of course, 60 children on board and that creates considerable difficulties because they are the innocent victims of other people's decisions. We are anxious to make sure that no final statement is made until every individual has been interviewed and we are satisfied that we are in a position to make a judgment on the status of every individual on board.

ANSWER.PARA: We have a team of people, including immigration officers, the Federal Police, and also the Hong Kong Police who are fluent in all of the Chinese dialects that are likely to be spoken on board. Their investigations are necessarily painstaking. We hope to be in a position early next week to make a further statement, in which case I will make a statement to the House and will make myself available to the media. I add that one of the sensitivities has been that we are most anxious not to impugn the status of those persons who are unquestionably genuine refugees, many of whom are now Australian citizens. I know that they share everyone else's concern that this racket, if indeed it is, is fully exposed, and that action is taken.

I take this opportunity of congratulating, I am sure on behalf of the House, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on the award of the Nobel Peace Prize. That throws into very great relief the work done on behalf of genuine refugees as opposed to what looks in this case to be an extremely serious racket.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the Prime Minister the fact that under the Parliamentary Witnesses Oaths Act 1871, which is in force in Australia by virtue of section 49 of the Constitution, witnesses before parliamentary committees who give false evidence are liable to the penalties of perjury. In view of the clear conflict between the statement of the Minister for Communications to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations on 16 March 1981 and the sworn evidence given to the Committee by Mr Webster, set out on pages 146 to 149 of the Senate Committee report, will the Government consider bringing criminal proceedings for perjury in relation to that sworn evidence and thereby vindicate the unsworn statement of the Minister?

—My colleague the Minister for Primary Industry will be making a detailed statement about a number of matters concerning that report and Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd at the appropriate time in the future. He has already advised the House of that. The only other comment that I would like to make is to suggest to the honourable gentleman that he read the debate in this Parliament.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers to the communique of the recent Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting regarding the Middle East and the status of the Palestinian Liberation Organisation. Can the Minister assure the House that this Government will continue not to recognise the PLO as a responsible negotiating body on Middle East disputes until such time as the PLO publicly and officially acknowledges the right of Israel to exist in peace within secure and recognised boundaries?
—Yes.

—I ask the Minister for the Capital Territory whether he is aware that his recent decision to hand over some emergency housing functions to voluntary organisations is causing concern, confusion and unnecessary delays in dealing with housing problems. Is he considering handing over other government welfare functions such as adoptions, the parole of prisoners and counselling services to voluntary organisations whose resources are already over extended? Will he consider increasing the resources of the welfare branch of his Department rather than unloading his responsibilities onto voluntary organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say to the honourable member that I reject completely the suggestion that the Department of the Capital Territory is handing over its responsibilities-indeed, to use his words, 'shelving its responsibilities'-in respect of welfare matters. The honourable member made a public statement a few weeks ago in which he alleged that the housing section of the Department of the Capital Territory, which deals, inter alia, with welfare housing, was shirking its responsibilities. Not only was that an unjust reflection on the Commissioner for Housing, Mr Brian Rope, and the members of his staff, but also it was a very great reflection on the House of Assembly Housing Committee, which is chaired by a member of the Australian Labor Party, Miss Robyn Walmsley, and which vets all decisions taken.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member claims that we are shirking our responsibilities. I dispute that. The Society of St Vincent De Paul and other welfare groups are prepared to work in co-operation with the Department. As I have explained to one of the honourable member's colleagues-the honourable member for Canberra-we believe the new system will be much fairer and better. Instead of raising this matter publicly and continually criticising the Department, I invite the honourable member to come to my office, as the honourable member for Canberra has, and discuss the matter in the presence of Mr Rope and officers of my Department. I make the point that the honourable member for Canberra comes to my office frequently. The honourable member for Fraser does not come very often at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's the end of me. I thought it was a safe seat.
—Perhaps the honourable member for Canberra wishes to make a personal explanation.

—Is the Minister for Communications aware of comments made yesterday by the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission concerning the future of national broadcasting in Australia? Does the Minister agree with the statement that corporate sponsorship can be operated satisfactorily provided adequate safeguards are written into the terms and conditions of such sponsorship? Do the Minister and the Government support corporate sponsorship of the ABC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, quite properly, has aired his views in respect of one of the aspects canvassed within the report of the Dix Committee of inquiry. There is a necessary field for examining each of the recommendations that came out of that report. The Chairman of the ABC in his role quite properly canvassed one of those issues and I commend him for having done so. With respect to corporate sponsorship, I have intimated in this place and elsewhere that there is a difficulty in trying to fund the expectations of the ABC. There is no doubt that, given the significantly increasing revenue of the commercial television stations, the ABC is faced with some difficulty in trying to mirror the program range that they provide and yet provide its distinctively different responsibilities, in terms of the quality of both the programs that it offers and the range of services which extends throughout Australia and which covers not just the national television stations but also national broadcasting. It is for that reason that the Dix Committee looked quite closely at the question of advertising and corporate sponsorship.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that it is necessary that these questions be properly aired.
