TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware of the problems that small businesses will have in administering the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax? As I pointed out to him yesterday, a button manufacturing firm, such as the Maxart Group Pty Ltd, which sells in small lots to many customers, delivering two and three times a week, has many returns from manufacturers of sample dresses. It will have to invoice out its buttons with the sales tax and then credit the sales tax on goods returned in hundreds of weekly transactions. Small businesses like Maxart are vital to Australian employment. This tax could send some of them to the wall with its increased cost of administration. Can the Treasurer offer any relief to them in both their administration problems and costs?

—It would be idle to pretend that the introduction of a wholesale tax for the first time for certain manufacturers will not cause an additional administrative burden and some additional cost. But whenever one decides to make a change in the taxation system, or even if one decides not to change it but rather to rely on existing methods in raising their respective proportions of tax, there are costs and consequences involved. If, as the Government believes, there is value in broadening the taxation base, I do not think there can be any doubt that of all the methods of raising indirect taxation, given the existing mechanism for collecting wholesale tax in this country, the method we have chosen is infinitely less costly and infinitely less burdensome on the Australian business community than, for example, the introduction of a value added tax or the introduction of a general consumption tax at the retail level, whatever other advantages that might have. I can assure the honourable member that every effort will be made by the Australian Taxation Office to minimise the administrative costs involved. The existence of a well trained and very experienced administration so far as sales tax collection is concerned will ensure that that occurs. I am very confident that in cost benefit terms this broadening of the tax base can be achieved with minimal interruption to and disturbance of the Australian business community.

—I refer the Minister for Transport to the decision of the Department of Transport to drop action against Singapore Airlines, Trans Australia Airlines and others in Tasmania for illegal international fare discounting. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to accept its national responsibility and be involved in Australia's soil conservation programs and in the prevention of further land degradation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, we are all familiar with the many varied problems which dominate policy making relating to primary industry. I refer specifically to such problems as trade for different commodities, the effects on the ongoing cost-price squeeze, rising interest rates, escalating land values and adjustment problems. These are all areas of concern which justifiably receive a good deal of attention from government. Often they are the result of our primary industries being so export orientated and consequently sensitive to international trends and fluctuations in world prices. Despite the significance of these issues their effects in terms of threatening the long term viability of agriculture pale in comparison to a problem which arises within our own shores and is basic to everyday agricultural activities. I refer here, of course, to the degradation of agricultural land throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is this serious problem which I wish to draw to the attention of Parliament today. It is also my aim to set out how the Fraser Government has steadily retreated from its national responsibility in this area and has shown complete disregard for the future viability of Australia's land resource base. The relationship between agriculture and the land is as basic as one will find. Without a healthy land resource base a strong ongoing agriculture cannot exist. Therefore this problem is not just a conservation issue concerning the binding of economic activities and protecting environmental quality for a number of intangible reasons. The objectives of efficient productive use of resources and resource conservation are synonomous. A degrading land base can neither sustain the increasing output of food and fibre essential to feed and clothe an increasing world population nor maintain this important sector of our economy.

Despite the apparentness and basic logic of these statements, cropping and grazing activities in Australia at present are threatened by a number of largely unattended processes which lower the stability of the landscape and render large areas of land useless for future use. There is ample evidence that degradation of our soil and water resources is accelerating. This scene is brought about by a number of interrelated processes such as: Erosion by wind and water in many of our major cropping and grazing areas; desertification of the arid inland as a result of overgrazing by domestic and feral animals; the spread of noxious weeds; the lowering of soil fertility by overcropping; the spread of soil borne pests and diseases; dry land salting as a result of indiscriminate clearing, and salinisation and waterlogging problems in irrigation areas. This list is by no means exhaustive but it is indicative of the environmental problems assailing agriculture in Australia today. It is important to realise from the outset that we are not merely talking about a bit of erosion here and there.

Much of how this present situation has come about can be explained by land users' and governments' traditional attitudes towards land resources in Australia. For most of our history we have seen the Australian landscape as being somewhat hostile; something to be subdued and exploited. This attitude has been fostered by government land development and settlement policies which encouraged ad hoc utilisation of the land for purposes of short term gain. The land degradation problems confronting us today are the legacy of such attitudes. Denuded and eroding slopes and areas of land covered with salt are the long term costs not accounted for by early developers. Similarly these same costs will face future generations because once land is severely degraded the effect is permanent. Indeed it is still possible to come across examples where governments are still supporting land development schemes with scant regard for the long term damage which may accompany such projects.

Australians tend to think of their country as being one generously endowed with land suitable for agriculture. This view is reinforced by constant referrals by enthusiastic, though uninformed, National Country Party politicians to the 'wastage' of natural resources in the remote areas of Australia. The Australian countryside is littered with degraded relics of grandiose development schemes. Once again it is the old story of quantity not equalling quality. The plain facts are that, while Australia is indeed well endowed with substantial areas of land, much of it is of poor quality and fragile, unsuitable for intensive development. In addition recent survey work by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation reveals that we have already occupied most of the land suitable for agriculture. We cannot continue to look to development of new lands on a broad scale as a means of improving productivity; instead we must turn to managing properly those areas already utilised. Indeed, the need for this is well overdue, for it is on these lands that the future viability of agriculture in this country depends.

In the past farmers and governments had an excuse for early mistakes in land utilisation. Little was known of how the Australian environment functioned, of how unsuitable techniques developed in Europe were here. Today no such excuse exists. Research over the last couple of decades has shed considerable light on the processes at work in the landscape and on how the use of land for cropping and grazing can best be managed so that stability and thus long term productivity can be achieved. What is lacking is the political will of governments to confront the problem and to implement what has been learnt. Nor is the matter of loss of productivity as a result of resource degradation new to the political sphere. Soil erosion first became a prominent political issue in the 1930s and 1940s in Australia. Fresh in the minds of those advocating government action was the 'dustbowl' catastrophy of the Great Plains in the United States of America, where many thousands of hectares of farming land were rendered useless by unsuitable management. Out of this concern began a movement leading to the establishment of soil conservation authorities in each of the States.

Before turning to the matter of Federal Government involvement in coping with the problem of land degradation, I wish to give honourable members some idea of the magnitude and seriousness of the problem confronting Australian farmers today. I do this lest the Government attempt to play down the problem or to accuse me of overreacting, particularly since it obviously sees the matter as being of little consequence. The most recent and thorough assessment of the extent and severity of land degradation in rural Australia was undertaken by officers of relevant State and Federal government authorities. The study entitled 'The Commonwealth and State Government Collaborative Soil Conservation Study 1975-77' was released in April 1978. That study was initiated by the then Minister for the Environment, the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Dr Cass), and all State governments, with the exception of the then New South Wales Liberal Government, agreed to co-operate. That study's findings were, to say the least, disturbing and confirmed the worst fears of many experts that the problem was spreading and rapidly getting out of control.

The study found that over half of the area of land in Australia being used for cropping and grazing required treatment for land degradation if its productivity was to be maintained. At June 1975 prices the costs of capital works required to control and treat the degraded area were assessed to be $675m. This figure does not include annual maintenance costs, estimated at around $50m a year, nor does it include costs of land use changes or the costs of extension advice, survey design and administration. Given the damaging effects of a four-year drought and a 10 per cent or higher inflation rate since these figures were released, it is certain that the total bill for land degradation is well over a billion dollars. The total value of fixed investments in the area threatened by degradation of one form or another was assessed to be of the order of $12 billion.

No wonder a recent Four Corners program gave soil erosion the correct title of being the most serious environmental problem in Australia today. At an international seminar on arid land management held in Brisbane in May, the country where desertification was deemed to be most likely to spread was not Ethiopia, Sudan or any of the other poorly developed countries which border on the world's major deserts; it was Australia. Some 40 per cent of Australia is at high risk of becoming desert. There is more. Work carried out by the Queensland Department of Primary Industries has shown that in wheat lands soil is being lost at an annual rate of 50 tonnes a hectare. If these losses continue the productivity of these soils will be seriously reduced before the end of the century. In many areas the consequences will be disastrous well before then since they simply do not have that amount of topsoil to lose. The costs do not end with just declining productivity; there are also those costs associated with silted creeks and dams-costs that affect the community.

I could go on detailing the results of other studies because the evidence is there, but time precludes this. What is obvious is that land degradation is not just some conservationist's whim, as the coalition prefers to see it; rather it is a major problem with potentially disastrous economic, social and environmental consequences for rural communities and indeed, through the importance of primary industries, for the nation. What is obvious also is the inability of the market forces to deal with the costs of land degradation and the need for government intervention.

This is not to say that some responsibility does not lie with the individual land user. However, the farmer is seriously constrained in his capacity to practice and fund soil conservation. Direct government involvement is justified by the need to maintain a productive and versatile land resource for future generations as well as to minimise off-site effects, such as siltation of dams and harbours, which directly affect the community.

Under the Constitution, the State governments have the responsiblity for land. However, the Federal Government has a basic responsibility to ensure an efficient agricultural sector for the social welfare of people in rural areas. The magnitude of land degradation in Australia is such that it threatens both. Therefore, I feel active participation by the Federal Government with the States is warranted and essential if the problem is to be dealt with.

Given this responsibility of the Federal Government for the maintenance of Australia's land resource, I turn now to examining how the Fraser Government has gone about bearing this responsibility. During the years of the Whitlam Government Federal involvement in soil conservation was steadily intensified. In 1971-72, grants to the States for soil conservation totalled $637,000. By the Budget of 1975-76 this had grown to nearly $3m. This followed the findings of an interdepartmental committee established in August 1973 to examine the matter of financial assistance for soil conservation. When the Fraser Government took office, things took a backward step and, by 1978, Federal funding had fallen to less than $1.5m. This then was how the Fraser Government accepted its responsibilities for dealing with Australia's land degradation problem. It was an ominous sign of things to come.

One of the principal findings of the interdepartmental committee's report was that there was an urgent need for a national soil conservation program and that a collaborative study involving State and Federal governments be undertaken so as to provide a sound basis for such a program. I have already referred earlier in my speech to some of the findings. It was a most comprehensive and competently prepared document. It provided a basis for a national soil conservation program and advocated a more active role be taken by the Commonwealth Government through the complementary mechanisms of research, policy co-ordination and financial assistance to the State soil conservation authorities.

Following the release of the main report of the study, the Government dillied and dallied and generally avoided taking any substantial steps, although it agreed in principle to assist the States on a national soil conservation program. There is nothing in the 1979 Budget, or the 1980 Budget, despite repeated assurances. Following angry responses by the States to the omission in the 1980 Budget of any specific funds for soil conservation, the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) announced, quite incredibly, that the Government would be reviewing the soil conservation program funding later in the financial year. All that the Federal Government was doing was biding its time.

Finally, the Government pledged itself to support financially a national soil conservation program. Predictably enough, this occurred in the coalition's election speeches in October 1980 when the Government pledged $3m for soil conservation. The Leader of the National Country Party (Mr Anthony)in his Party's 1980 election speech-ironically enough entitled 'Keeping Australia Strong'-said:
. . . as a first step towards a national soil conservation program we will provide $3m in 1981-82.

Unfortunately it proved also to be the last step. In April 1981, the Fraser Government, in its Review of Commonwealth Functions decided that suddenly soil conservation was no longer a Commonwealth responsibility and that the States should take full responsibility for policy and administrative matters. With this short statement, the Fraser Government beat a hasty retreat from its responsibilities and assured that the land degradation problem would continue to worsen.

All the posturing and side-stepping of the Government following the release of the major study was always only intended to buy time and the miserly promise of $3m in the 1980 election speeches was yet another example of political grandstanding. Arguments that the funds promised will be included in general grants to the States give no grounds for complacency since there can be little assurance that the States, already struggling to find funds, can allocate the money specifically to soil conservation work. Besides, the amounts promised are a mere pittance. More importantly, the States cannot be sure that any more funds will be forthcoming from the Commonwealth in the future. They cannot undertake any long term planning for soil conservation, given this uncertainty. The whole purpose of devising a national soil conservation program was to enable the problem of land degradation to be tackled on a planned and progressive basis. The Government will take resort in the fact that it has taxation deductibility for certain soil conservation measures. I do not doubt the wisdom of this. But tax deductibility is a particularly inappropriate policy for soil conservation. Some of those whose properties are most eroded, which affects other people's properties, are those people with low incomes.

The Fraser Government's approach to water resources smacks of the same empty rhetoric and lack of political will. Since 1977, the Government has made repeated promises to allocate $200m for water resources over the five years to 1982-83. With only one year to go, only $109.4m has actually been allocated. The Fraser Government's record in managing the natural resources of this country can only be described as dismal. Its ostrich-like approach to problems of environmental degradation in relation to the quality of land and water resources, upon which agriculture depends, has ensured that their future ability to sustain production remains in jeopardy. This is hardly a record to be proud of or an approach which would be taken by a responsible government. However, as we have seen on numerous occasions over the last few weeks, responsible government is hardly one of this Government's strong points when it comes to primary industries.

The Australian Labor Party is pledged to the maintenance and restoration of expendable resources of soil, water, air and forests. To this end a Labor government would ensure that the Commonwealth assumed a responsible and active role in tackling the problem on a national basis. Whilst the States have primary legislative responsibility for land, this is no excuse for a Federal government to turn its back on a serious national situation. Australian governments have always played a significant role in land policy relating to agriculture. The more traditional areas of Commonwealth involvement include land settlement and land development. We should take the opportunity when we develop land to insist on decent conservation policies. Commonwealth financial involvement in such policy areas has been justified on the basis of its being important to the national interest, and it is. Just as it has been seen to be in the interests of the nation for the Commonwealth to contribute to the development and settlement of its agricultural lands, it is also proper that the Commonwealth ensure that these lands are not allowed to degrade. There are a number of complementary means whereby the Commonwealth could, and should, take an effective role in dealing with the varying forms of land degradation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Trade and Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the House should be grateful to the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) for raising the importance of the preservation of one of the most important basic resources in the Australian community. There is no question that the preservation of the soil resource is fundamental to a country such as Australia which is so heavily dependent upon its agricultural and primary industries and which still relies significantly on generating export income from those primary industries. It is a country which ranges from the arid to the non-arid zones. It experiences severely changing seasonal conditions when flood and drought tend in cyclical form to generate the circumstances within which agriculture is carried out. It is for that reason that the Government has a great deal of support for at least the first part of what the honourable gentleman said and the consideration that needs to be given to this fundamental problem.

SPEECH.PARA: It was within one of the committees of the Standing Committee of Agriculture, which was one of my responsibilities as Minister for Primary Industry in days gone by, that the review of a basis for soil conservation policy in Australia was produced in 1978. Its report on the collaborative soil conservation study undertaken between 1975 and 1977 was, of course, subsequent to the report to which the honourable gentleman referred. It is interesting to look at this study, Mr Deputy Speaker, for I know your own concern in South Australia, a State which has been significantly affected by the problems of soil degradation of one form or another. The report remarks that, of the total land area of Australia, one third is not used for agricultural or pastoral purposes, nearly one-third is stable under present land use, and more than one-third-about 35 per cent-is degraded to varying degrees and needs some form of conservation treatment. The report identifies four types of conservation treatments-land management practices, such as cultivation and crop management, pasture and grazing management; conservation works on pastoral and farm land, which include land management work, such as contour banking, and erosion control work, such as gully control structures; change in the present use of land to a less hazardous use; and various treatments for degraded land used for other than pastoral agricultural purposes.

Having identified those four types, I think it is important that the House identify the ways in which they can be implemented. It is in the manner and responsibility for this work and the way by which stimulus can be given that lies the fundamental differences between the Government and the Opposition on this very important matter. The extent to which the land management practices that I identified can be pursued by government is, of course, minimal. Cultivation, crop management, pasture and grazing management are significantly the responsibility of two agencies. One is the State governments, which determine the terms and conditions of the occupancy of the land. They have responsibility for allocating irrigation licences for land which is irrigated, determining the land use and the stocking capacity of arid land and controlling land management practices.

The second type of management is conservation works on pastoral and farm land, such as contour banking and erosion control work, such as gully control structures. In the State from which I come the Water Resources Commission has developed very extensive services which were funded heavily during the Liberal-National Country Party coalition days so that it could provide supplementary services for the land holder. Again, the State governments and the land holders have the responsibility. The third area is the change in the present use of land to a less hazardous use. The Commonwealth has no responsibility for determining land use. Constitutionally, that responsibility lies with State governments. Again, it is a matter for determination by the State governments, which have the capacity to redesignate or reapply land for a particular use, and by the individual who is the land holder and the person utilising the land. The fourth area is the various treatments for degraded land used for other than pastoral agricultural purposes. The responsibility for that lies predominantly with the State and with the individual.

The history of Australian agriculture and the development of this country shows that European settlement has significantly increased pressures on Australian soils and vegetation. Native vegetation and timber have been cleared over large areas and cultivation of soils has been introduced. Some agricultural practices left soils bare, particularly in the days when tillage was not as scientific as it is today and when the equipment used tended to leave ground bared for long periods, particularly in the summer rainfall zones where heavy storms tended to wash away land. Native pastures have been subjected to increased grazing pressures. Crops and pastures have been introduced which differ from the native vegetation in their growth cycles, their nutrient needs and their demands for water. Hydrological regimes have been redistributed. Flood plains have been developed. Many of the more indistinct natural drainage lines have been cultivated. All this has contributed towards the degradation of the soil's surface. The result of all these changes has been soil erosion, flooding and salinisation of soils and water. Erosion products are the most widespread pollutants arising from agricultural, pastoral and even urban activities and are a major pollutant of water sources.

Those remarks come from the report to which I referred. There is no doubt that the position is serious. The assessment of areas needing soil conservation treatment shows, as the honourable member for Werriwa mentioned, that 52 per cent of the land in use in Australia needs some form of treatment for land or vegetation degradation. This area amounts to more than one-third of the entire land mass. Over five million square kilometres are used for agricultural and pastoral purposes. Of the total area in use 23 per cent needs treatment with land management practices only and 29 per cent needs conservation works of various kinds, almost invariably in conjunction with appropriate management practices. The Government does not deny-indeed, it recognises-the problems that exist in this area.

I need to make a couple of other remarks on the report before I deal with the substance of the responsibility and how the Federal Government is reacting to it. The private land owner is identified on page 21 of the report as having a central role in soil conservation. The report remarks that it may be taken that he is primarily responsible for sound management and maintaining his land in good condition. Protection of his own and neighbouring land and structures is unlikely to be assured under common law, but it is the rural land user and the city land user who generate so much of the land degradation. We should make no mistake about it-land developers and those who develop our cities and urban areas are as much responsible as the miner and the farmer who, in their more extensive areas and also through historical land practices, have caused soil degradation in one form or another.

In terms of involvement, the first person identified in the report is the private land holder. It is to him that the Federal Government is giving very significant help in an area from which the Labor Government, its predecessor, removed that help. That is most important in considering this matter of public importance. The second thing in the report in terms of involvement is the case for public involvement. Land degradation imposes costs on society. It affects productivity. It certainly affects the degree to which the natural beauty of an area is in one way degraded or in another way enhanced. On page 25 of the report there is a suggestion of the measure of public involvement. Let us look at it. The first area suggested is monitoring-assessing the extent and rate of land degradation and the effectiveness of control efforts. That demonstrably is a responsibility of State governments. The second area is research and development. The third area is participation-the provision of extension services, specialist services, construction of conservation works, the provision of incentives and subsidies. The report states:
Governments act as a source of knowledge and expertise in soil conservation. This is a vital function performed by the various State and Territory soil conservation authorities.

Having indentified those three areas the report suggests that governments act as a source of knowledge and expertise, and states that this function is performed by the various State and Territory soil conservation authorities. The report continued:
Continuing research into the causes and effects of land degradation, and into methods of control, together with the efficient dissemination of the knowledge gained, are important roles of government.

The principal area of concern is not whether there needs to be an approach taken at those two separate levels but rather how we go about it. Let us have a look at this. The first thing I say to the House and to the people of Australia with respect to this is that the origins of soil conservation and the present state of play with regard to soil conservation date way back. There certainly has been an involvement by State governments and the Federal Government for many years. Indeed, before 1972 the Liberal-National Country Party Government provided very generous concessions to the landholder. Honourable members will remember that there were two particular areas of responsibility-one was the land holder and the second was the State governments and those who have a particular involvement with the soil and with land management. With respect to the individual, the Whitlam Labor Government in 1973 changed the then available deductibility of expenditure for soil conservation purposes so that this expenditure, instead of being deductible in the year in which the expenditure occurred, became deductible over a 10-year period. So much for the record of achievement that the honourable member for Werriwa referred to. There was a complete removal of the incentive for the private landholder who has the major responsibility in the area with the removal of the tax reduction by the Whitlam Government back in 1973.

Let us see where we have got to now. There is no doubt that, in terms of the present position as far as tax concessions are concerned, the Federal Government has recognised its responsibilities. I draw the attention of members of the Opposition to the second reading speech on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1980 by my colleague the Treasurer (Mr Howard). The speech states:
Soil Conservation Expenditure

The second of the policy initiatives implemented by the Bill will authorise full deductions in the year of expenditure for the capital cost of a wide range of soil conservation measures on land in Australia that is used for primary production. Capital expenditures to qualify for the new deduction include outlays on the eradication or extermination of animal or vegetable pests, on the destruction of detrimental weed or plant growth and on the draining of swamp or low-lying land. Also specified are expenditures on the prevention or combating of soil erosion, on the erection of control fences to exclude livestock or vermin from areas affected by erosion or excessive salinity and on the erection of levee banks.

Honourable members will recall that in the report we identified a number of areas which referred not specifically to work that had to be done on the soil but to necessary measures in terms of land use. The prime responsibility in that area lies with the landholder. This Federal Government quite properly introduced a tax deduction in order to encourage the landholder to pursue his proper responsibilities. The Treasurer in the second reading speech said that, at present, expenditures of these kinds are generally deductible, as explained, by way of equal instalments over a period of 10 years. That, honourable members will recall, was a Labor initiative. In the case of fencing, landholders were subject to depreciation allowances over a number of years. All that was changed, specifically with the intention of meeting the Federal Government's responsibility to assist the landholder to pursue his soil conservation practices. The Treasurer's speech continued:

Eligible expenditure on soil conservation measures will qualify for the full deduction if it is incurred under a contract entered into on or after 1 October 1980 or on or after that date in an operation carried out by the taxpayer.

The Federal Government introduced a very significant tax concession. It provided an extension not just with respect to soil conservation but also with respect to fencing. It ensured that as a result there would be a capacity for the private individual landholder to undertake that soil conservation work. The second part of the proposal concerns the State governments' responsibility. The honourable member for Werriwa made a lot of what he said is the responsibility of the Federal Government to fund State government in this area. The Federal Government recognised that the State governments need to have a financial capacity to pursue that objective. As honourable members will recall, the report of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions stated that one of the objectives was to return to the States their sovereign responsibilities, to give them the financial sinews with which they could exercise them, and to give them the task of so doing. The decision of the RCF was implemented at the Premiers Conference on 4 May 1981 when the States were offered an additional 9 per cent in their share of tax revenues plus $69m in support of functions and programs being transferred to the States. The $3m in 1981-82 for soil conservation, promised to the States by the Government in its 1980 election speech, was included in that $69m, although not separately so identified. This allowance for soil conservation was built into the tax sharing base from which future tax sharing entitlements will be calculated. Not only was the $3m provided but also an increment was provided to enable the State governments to meet their tasks.

I think it is worth commenting that-I see that my time is running out-on page 85 of the Budget address delivered by the New South Wales Premier the other day, with respect to allocations for 1981-82 for the soil conservation facilities, an amount of $3,150,000 was allocated. This is down some 14 per cent on the amount provided the year before. I know that funds provided for the soil conservation services in that State have been increased. The point is that the Federal Government is providing a tax concession and, through our tax reimbursement grants, is giving funds to the States which properly have this responsibility. I share the honourable gentleman's concern that it is of prime importance to Australia that the landholder and State governments exercise their responsibilities. I hope that as a result of this discussion of a matter of public importance they do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before commencing my speech on the motion for the second reading of the Customs (Valuations) Amend ment Bill I would like the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) to take particular note that, just be fore he rose to speak in the debate on the matter of public importance raised by the Opposition, I was given a copy, for the first time, of a document which gave me the first indication that the Government intended to move 14 amendments to the Customs (Valuations) Amendment Bill. I give notice, so that the Leader of the House can make appropriate arrangements, that I will oppose every one of those 14 amendments at the committee stage unless the committee stage is postponed until a later hour this day. I am fed up.
—I am quite happy to do that.

—I think it is time that a stand was taken and that Ministers, in particular, have the courtesy to involve in their discussions about these matters those who are leading for the Opposition. Here are these 14 amendments distributed to the House only half an hour ago. No advance notice was given to my office as to their nature. I am not going to put up with it in future. I will be seeking the support of my colleagues to oppose amendments if they are given such scanty attention by the House.

—I raise a point of order in relation to what the honourable gentleman has said. I am quite happy to rearrange the proceedings to en able the honourable gentleman to have time to consider the amendments. I will be in consultation with the Manager of Opposition Business to arrange an appropriate time for discussion.
—You were offered all the facilities of the Department.

—I was not given any notice by the Minister's office, in spite of some telephone calls between my staff and the Minister's staff about these amendments. We were given a vague idea that there might be some amendments. We must follow the normal courtesies whereby a Minister's office gets in touch with the relevant shadow Minister's office and gives plenty of time for the particular amendments to be studied so that we are not looked upon as mere rubber stamps in this chamber to what is going through.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Adelaide to address his remarks through the Chair. I hope that he has made his point.

—I have made the point. I am grateful to the Leader of the House for postponing the Committee stages so that proper attention can be given to the amendments. The purpose of this Bill is to introduce new methods for valuing goods for import duty purposes. The new methods of valuation are in accordance with the customs valuation code which was agreed to at the Tokyo Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The new code replaces the current system which is based on the Brussels Definition of Value. This system was drawn up in 1950 and was adopted by Australia in 1976. Although about 100 nations have also adopted this code, others, including such important trading nations as Canada and the United States, have rejected it. The fact that this is so means that, indeed, the Opposition-when we learn this part of the information-gives even greater attention than might otherwise be given to what might be called a machinery measure.

SPEECH.PARA: An internationally agreed code clearly is significantly more acceptable than a profusion of rival codes, in particular, because where no standard is agreed, nations bring into use unfair valuation methods as an artifical barrier to trade. The importance of valuations for duty purposes is, of course, the fact that the higher the valuation the higher the duty. The codes used before the introduction of the new system, including the Brussels Convention, were open to some abuse in this respect because they were based on notional values-that is, the value declared at entry was not accepted as the value for customs purposes. Rather, it was based on a notional price which, it was assumed, the imported goods would obtain in open market between buyers and sellers, if those buyers and sellers were operating at arm's length.

The new system is more objective. It begins with the actual transaction price and it adds other objectively determined costs to obtain the value for duty. It is possible that this new system will involve greater administrative efforts by importers who must adapt to these new procedures. But this will be offset by the three main advantages of this new scheme. I want to relate to the House what those three advantages are, as I see them. The first is that it is internationally agreed and so this all contributes to the promotion of trade between nations. Certainly my party supports the facilitation of that trade. Secondly, it is an objective value. Thirdly, it is more easily administered by the Collector of Customs. For these reasons the Opposition, I repeat, supports this Bill just as it has supported, in general, the outcome of multilateral trade negotiations in the past, for example, the anti-dumping code and the subsidies and countervailing duties codes.

In supporting the code and this legislation we, in the Opposition are, however, concerned that it is monitored closely as the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) in his second reading speech and, I believe, on other occasions has promised. He has said that the adoption of the new valuation system will not have widespread consequences for levels of tariff assistance now provided for Australian industry. We take that to be true. We accept those assurances as being based on the very best information available to the Minister at this stage, but agree that in the event that any industry finds itself facing injury as a result of a significant unforseen fall in effective tariff protection, then a reference should be sent to the Industries Assistance Commission or, indeed, if it is more serious and more urgent, to the Temporary Assistance Authority in order that appropriate variations in duty rates and appropriate protection for those affected can be made.

Tariff protection is of considerable importance. There is an incorrect assumption in the thinking of a large number of our political opponents in the Liberal and National Country parties that levels of protection for Australian industry should be cut across the board. There is grave concern at the moment in the community about this. It would be most inappropriate, we in the Labor Party believe, at a time of temporary massive capital inflow to seek to dismantle large sections of manufacturing industry as a response. The facts are that Australia is facing, yet again, a sustained increase in the level of unemployment. Moreover our balance of trade has moved into deficit. The balance on current account is in a massive and unpredictable deficit.

These experiences highlight how inappropriate tariff reductions can be in response to short term economic conditions. The conditions that led to calls for tariff reductions earlier this year have already changed substantially. The manufacturing sector of the Australian economy, as the recent quarterly survey of the Confederation of Australian Industry reveals this week, shows a slowing of output growth and the halting of employment growth. Expectations are 'rather more subdued'. So, there is no cause for optimism about the state of Australian manufacturing industry right now. This is no surprise because it stems from the general economic mismanagement perpetrated by this Government.

I want to go through some of the errors in the economic strategy. The dollar has been appreciated at the cost of manufacturing competitiveness by about 11 per cent since last year. Although there may be a temporary devaluation at the present time, it is only very small in comparison with the general appreciation over the last 12 or 13 months. This is causing such grave concern to many who are creating employment in this country by competing against imports and, indeed, creating employment by getting out into the export world and competing against others. Any appreciation in our currency of this order will give them far greater difficulties than would otherwise apply. A second element of mismanagement-my list will not be comprehensive in this debate today-is the razor gang's operations where programs of business assistance have been cut and reduced consumer confidence has thereby resulted. There is the fact of increased taxes on most manufactured goods and also the fact that the monetary policies of the Government have reduced the availability and raised the cost of loan finance for business.

Lastly in this rather short and incomplete list, there is the threat to the motor vehicle industry which has damaged the prospects of the manufacturing sector in the vast range of industries which supply the automotive producers. The Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers is meeting in Canberra at the present time. Never has it met at a time of greater threat to its industry. The sooner the Government makes its decision and the sooner the Government realises that those decisions must be for the future health of that industry the better it will be for those who have invested in the industry, for those who work in the industry and for those who are sadly unemployed in this country at the present time and who need jobs so badly.

For all these reasons, and others, I believe it can be said that the Government has damaged the Australian economy, particularly the manufacturing sector. For that general reason as well we must ensure that further uncertainty is not caused by a new system for striking customs duties which are so important for local manufacturing industry. That puts this Bill into a correct perspective. With that note of warning I repeat the Opposition's support for this legislation. We want fair and open trade to develop with improvements made on a planned basis after due consideration by the IAC processes. We do not want random changes in areas of administration which have unintended effects. We certainly do not want the sort of inquiries that are going on at the moment into the general level of tariffs with the extraordinary request that such an inquiry by the IAC should be completed in six months and that other inquiry into the general level of assistance to industry also be completed in six months. It seems so unreal that anything of a worthwhile nature could be done in such a short space of time. The only result of such action is, of course, to increase the uncertainty in the manufacturing sector, one of the big hopes we have of reducing unemployment in our community. In my view the Government is destructive of the Australian economy more than enough, without added concern in an area such as this one.

While dealing with these matters I will say something about the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code which has recently been adopted and officially agreed to by the present Fraser Government. In a speech the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) made outside this Parliament to the Australian Industries Development Association annual general meeting on Friday 9 October. He said:

Governments of the major trading nations, including Australia, have devoted increasing attention to the problems of protectionism arising from the use of non-tariff barriers on internationally traded industrial products. A prime example of this is the use of standards to protect domestic industries and the emergence of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations of a Standards Code or, as it is more correctly called, the Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade.

This Code establishes rules and procedures to ensure that technical regulations or standards adopted for reasons related to health, safety, quarantine and consumer or environmental protection are not used to create unreasonable barriers to trade. Membership of the Code requires the use of international standards as the basis for technical regulations and standards, except where inappropriate for the protection of national security or similar reasons.

The Minister for Trade and Resources pointed out that the Government, when it announced several months ago that it would adopt that Code, said that our country would join the Standards Codes. He indicated:
That membership would assist our efforts to achieve improved access to world markets where our exports face unreasonable restrictive or discriminatory standards.
In part of his speech to the IADA he said:

The Government recently announced that Australia has joined the Subsidies and Countervailing Duties Code which seeks to ensure that subsidies do not harm trading interests and that countervailing measures do not unjustifiably impede international trade. Some time ago, I indicated that Australia had decided to join this Code only if appropriate arrangements could be negotiated to safeguard Australia's right to use export incentive arrangements which do not materially harm the interests of our trading partners. These negotiations were necessary because the United States considers the Government's present export incentives schemes to be contrary to the Code. Our membership of the Code was therefore effectively blocked which in turn meant that Australian exports were denied the right under US legislation to the benefit of a material injury test in US subsidy investigations.

The Australian Government's decision to join that Code has caused a certain amount of consternation in various business sectors. However, the Opposition is taking the statements of the Deputy Prime Minister and others at their face value that certain interests of ours have been safeguarded. He pointed out that the consequences of this United States attitude were highlighted when there was United States countervailing action on our lamb exports. If that precedent were established it would effectively enable the United States Government, on the request of any United States industry, to countervail any Australian exports which received assistance under a very broad range of alleged subsidies, including grants under Australia's current Export Incentive Scheme. A most serious threat was therefore posed to Australia's export industries. But the Minister has assured us, and the Opposition accepts it, that Code membership has put a brake on any future investigations of our exports to the United States which may be considerably more significant for Australian exports than just the case of lamb. So the decision to join the Code has been-and I reiterate, is being-supported by the Opposition because it has been made possible by a bilateral understanding with the United States which we have been told about and which involves the provisional application of the Code between the two countries on the basis of certain reciprocal expectations.

Our country we have been told-we accept this at face value-expects that the United States will not operate its export assistance system in a manner inconsistent with the Code beyond the middle of 1983. For its part the United States expects that Australia will not operate export subsidies on minerals and manufactured products which are inconsistent with the Code beyond that same date. That is worrying in itself except that we are assured that this does not preclude Australia from introducing new export incentive schemes, provided they are consistent with the Code. I am confused about this matter. At a recent meeting of the relevant Estimates Committee, when it examined the estimates of the Department of Trade and Resources-I have not had an opportunity to examine the transcript in recent hours-I thought that the Secretary of the Department of Trade and Resources, Mr Scully, in the absence of the Minister, told me fairly and squarely, without equivocation, that our existing export schemes were not in any way contravening the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade rules. But here we have, in the Minister's speech, the doubt raised whether or not they do contravene those rules. But we are given the assurance that the export subsidies will be altered, if necessary, to be consistent with the Code. I hope that at the same time that will not mean that the subsidies are less effective than they are at the present time because if ever there was a need for assisting the exports of this nation, it is now as we can see from the very adverse balance of trade announced this week. The announcement caused quite grave shock waves. The Minister went on to say in his speech:
Additionally Code membership will not limit Australia's right to maintain other subsidies which do not cause or threaten damage to other Code signatories.

We trust that that will be so. Australia has made it quite clear that it is dissatisfied with some aspects of the Code. For instance, the discipline on export subsidies for agricultural products are less rigid that those which apply to minerals and manufactured products. The Opposition expects this imbalance to be redressed and the Government has promised that it will seek to do something about the matter. If there is insufficient progress in this area or problems arise from our inability to continue export incentive schemes which may operate for non-agricultural products, Australia will, if necessary, the Minister promised us-the Opposition supports this-consider withdrawing from the Code. Our experience as a member of the Code will be reviewed, we are promised, and it is on this basis that the Opposition has supported the Government's actions in that area. I welcome the opportunity to put the Opposition's view, as this is something causing an amount of concern in some sectors of industry. Once again it is a bipartisan approach. Just as we support this Customs (Valuations) Amendment Bill, so, with the assurances given by the Deputy Prime Minister in that speech, we support Australia's adoption of the Code. I am happy to be able to say that we too will be monitoring the situation closely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this relatively straightforward and simple but quite important measure, the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), as usual, has not been able to forsake making a number of tilts at the Government's overall policies. The things he said are rather hollow, I think, coming from one who was a part of the Labor Administration of 1973-75 whose policies resulted in a massive boost to inflation, which saw the cutting of tariffs-beginning with the across the board cut of 1973-which had such disastrous effects on the confidence of Australian industry, which saw a halving of the then prevailing export incentive schemes, which saw the abolition of the investment allowance and which saw for most of that period a significant upvaluing of the Australian dollar-all of which contributed to the most disastrous fall in activity in the Australian manufacturing industry and the emergence of very high levels of unemployment. So, I think it perhaps ill becomes the honourable member for Adelaide to take the tilts at this Government's policy that he has taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Industry policy, which is affected by the measure before the House, is a wide-ranging matter that covers the general economic environment, and hence the Government's overall economic policy, as well as specific measures of industry policy and, of course, the tariff, subsidy and assistance structure which is part and parcel of the overall policy. In point of fact, as the Australian electorate knows well, as a result of the Government's consistent policy to contain inflation, the international competitiveness of Australian industry, that is, its ability to produce in competition with imports and to export, has been restored to the sort of situation that prevailed before all the events in the early period of the 1970s that I was detailing a moment ago. As a result of the sound policies of this Government, there has been a very significant expansion in non-farm product in this country. This country has set out upon an era of new development practically unparalleled in its history. I think we would have to go back to the goldrush days to see a parallel. In fact, over the last year there has been an expansion of demand and output in Australia of 4 per cent to 5 per cent, which is practically the fastest rate of real economic growth of all the major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries-the major industrialised countries in the world. Australia is the envy of the major industrialised countries of the world in this respect.

The honourable member referred to the impact of interest rates on industry. I take the opportunity, therefore, of stressing once again that the whole thrust of the recent Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is to ease and, hopefully, to reverse the upward pressure on interest rates. Of course, interest rates are of great concern to industry, particularly to small business and, indeed, to most Australian families. That is why that policy has been adopted as the key thrust of the Budget. The purpose of the large domestic surplus that was budgeted for is to reduce the totality of the Government's borrowing and, therefore, to take the upward pressure off interest rates so that the process of bringing interest rates down can be started.

That is the general environment in which industry operates and it has not been healthier for many years. Within that context, the Government has a positive industrial development policy, of which the export assistance to which the honourable member made reference is a key element and of which industrial research and development grants are a key element, to stimulate and to bring about the more export-oriented, technologically advanced, more specialised and larger scale industry that we all want to see. Part and parcel of that policy is an area to which the honourable member referred and which is raised by the Customs (Valuations) Amendment Bill now before the House: It is important that there be a concern that the adoption of this new valuation procedure does not adversely affect the degree of effective protection afforded industry. That concern can be allayed but as background to that the honourable member made reference to the Government's policy of assistance to industry including tariff measures, bounties and quotas.

Lest there be any misunderstanding, let me assert that this Government is committed to the reasonable and adequate protection of Australian industry, but it is committed to that within a long term context and objective of a gradual movement towards a lower and less complicated structure of assistance. I believe the Government's commitment there is in line with a widespread consensus within the community, including business and industry, that it is appropriate to look towards a gradual, planned and phased move towards a lower and less complicated pattern of tariff and quota assistance. But I stress-I am grateful that the honourable member for Adelaide who is responsible for these matters on behalf of the Opposition really agrees with me-that that consensus relates to a long term context of change. This looking to a gradual phased lowering of protection involves looking to a long term context of change and restructuring associated with a lowering of costs in industry and, along with that as both instrument and effect, a lowering of the degree of assistance. But I assert-I am sure he would agree with me-that there is no consensus at all; indeed, it is entirely wrong-headed to think of a major cut in protection as a short term policy instrument for controlling the money supply and exchange rate pressures, or as a direct counter to inflation. Specifically there is no case at all for anything of the nature of the across-the-board tariff cuts that we witnessed in 1973.

The pursuit of significant tariff reduction is a gradual, long term matter. It involves participating in international negotiations for reciprocal reductions of tariffs and in negotiations relating to the matters that are before the House at the moment, as embodied in the Customs (Valuations) Amendment Bill. Unfortunately, the absolutely exorbitant and prohibitive agricultural protectionism that we see in the European Economic Community hardly ever comes within the purview of such negotiations. It is very important that it should. Australia participates in those negotiations. Then there is the process involving the continuing thrust towards lower levels of protection and more flexible arrangements in particular areas, such as last year in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, where there was the introduction of bounties at the level of yarn production and spinning with a view to reducing costs at higher stages, a simplification of the quota categories and the putting of an increasing proportion of quota to tender with a view to reproducing more closely what would happen in a market situation. And indeed, confronting the Government at the moment is the motor vehicle industry decision. The honourable member has raised it, so I shall make a comment in passing on it.

We are talking of a decision about the motor vehicle industry which relates to the arrangements to apply in that industry after 1984, from 1 January 1985. Admittedly there are lengthy lead times in this industry and it is important to get the decision made, but the final report of the Industries Assistance Commission was received only at the end of June so that there has been a delay of only a month or two in order to give this very important matter effective consideration in looking to arrangements which are to apply, as I said, from 1 January 1985. It is carping criticism to suggest that the Government is, in some way, dragging its heels in this matter. It is a major decision which has to be taken with care. I can avert that it will be a decision which will look to a real but gradual reduction in the assistance afforded to that industry. Let me hasten to say that it is not a decision as to whether there should or should not be assistance to the industry. Substantial protection has been recommended by the Government's advisory body, the IAC. It is a question of the extent and the form of the assistance.

This matter has to be very carefully thought through. The motor vehicle industry is a major contributor, as the base load of Australian manufacturing. We want to see the retention of a sizable motor manufacturing industry in Australia. I am sure that the honourable member will agree with me that the current position is not an option. There has to be significant change in this industry and a principal matter at issue is not whether there should be significant change associated with a reduction in protection, but the pace of that change. The capacity to absorb change is a matter to which we have to take note. I am confident that an appropriate decision in this matter will be taken within the next month or so.

That is the broad thinking of the Government in this matter of tariffs and industry policy. The most important thing-I come back to this matter as I conclude-that one can do for industry is to get the overall environment right, to contain inflation and to set the general economic parameters of the economy so that one achieves significant economic growth in the context of the restored competitive position of Australian industry. This is the greatest contribution that this Government has made to the restoration of manufacturing industry in particular and other sectors of industry in general.

The main purpose of the present measure is, as the honourable member has said, to introduce new provisions for the valuation of imported goods for customs duty purposes. I do not know whether I misheard the honourable member. I thought he suggested at the beginning of his speech that the code which emerged, this basis of valuation of imports, from the Tokyo Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and trade had not been adopted by the United States of America. Did I mishear him? In fact, it has been.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous code.

—I see. It has been. We are adopting a code which has, in fact, been adopted by all the major trading nations and groups. It is in line with the valuation system practices in the United States of America, Japan and the EEC. I could list others. So it does, in this matter of valuation, bring Australia into line with the major trading countries of the world and thus with the mainstream of the international trading system. It is a process of valuation which, as the honourable member said, replaces the Brussels Definition of Value with a valuation which is more positive in the sense that it starts where appropriate, and in most instances that will be the case, from actual prices and charges for imported goods. The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore), in his second reading speech, set out the circumstances in which on ocassions that may not be appropriate and the steps that are then provided for in this legislation to be taken to ensure an appropriate valuation.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by stressing again the point that it is a valuation procedure which is in line with that adopted by the major trading countries and groups of the world. It is appropriate that we come into line. The second point is that the government expects-I notice that the honourable member has accepted this-that it will not have widespread consequences for the levels of tariff protection now provided to Australian industry. Indeed, the best estimates that can be made indicate that, at most, it is likely to affect marginally the import values for tariff purposes, perhaps by the order of one to 2 per cent in most cases. There may be some particular cases-perfumery was a particular case-where this valuation made a significant difference. That industry was, in fact, reviewed by the IAC last year and new recommendations were made in the light of this new valuation system. The Government has every intention, as the honourable member has suggested it should, of referring cases where there is any difficulty to the Industries Assistance Commission. In addition, the new system makes customs valuation more predictable for importers and, as I understand it, it does have the support of organisations involved in or representing persons importing goods as well as organisations representing local manufacturers. With those remarks, I commend to the House this change, which has the purpose, as I said, of bringing Australia into line with the major trading nations of the world and the mainstream of the international trading system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs (Valuations) Amendment Bill is straightforward. Indeed I was going to confine my remarks to the legislation, which would not have taken very long, but I feel that prior to doing that a few remarks made by the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards) should be answered. I believe that the honourable member misled the House earlier in his speech when he spoke about the Whitlam years of 1973-75. A few of the things, of course, that he failed--
—What did I say?

—If the honourable gentleman listens he will find out. It is not what he said, it is what he failed to say. He failed to mention that when the Whitlam Government came to office in 1972 it inherited an already overheated economy and an undervalued currency. International inflation was occurring with great spurts, due mainly to the United States policy of financing the Vietnam war. What was happening here with inflation was happening in other countries. Also during the period when the Whitlam Government was in office, as honourable members might recall, we had tremendous hikes in Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries' oil prices which had tremendous repercussions right throughout the world. In fact the economies of some countries, for instance Japan, were shot to pieces because of those tremendous hikes in oil prices during that time. I think what the honourable gentleman said earlier about the 1973-75 period was not correct. Irrespective of that, people are worried about what is happening in 1981 and in fact what is happening since this Government came to office. What we see at present is a very high level of unemployment, and it is continuing to grow. A lot of Australian industries presently are threatened. Despite the Government's promises to reduce the level of inflation below the 10 per cent mark, at present, it is on its way up again and presently is running at around 10.75 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps having made those few remarks, Mr Deputy Speaker, we can come back to the legislation. The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Act 1901 to introduce new provisions for the valuation of imported goods for customs duty purposes. The new valuation provisions are designed to give effect to the agreement on implementation of article 7 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The Government decided to adopt this agreement in May 1980 on a free on board basis. The decision to adopt the agreement took into account the views of State governments, industry associations and other interested groups within the importing community. Presently Customs valuation is based upon the Brussels Definition of Value which provides for the valuation of imported goods on a notional basis by comparing each actual transaction with an ideal transaction in which all the circumstances conform with an entirely open market or an arms length situation.

The new valuation system provided for by this Bill differs from the present system to the extent that it is a positive system, using actual prices and charges to arrive at a dutiable value for Customs purposes. The principal method of valuation of imported goods for Customs duty purposes will henceforth be based on the transaction value of imported goods. The transaction value will be the price actually paid or payable for imported goods when sold for export to the country of importation after certain adjustments have been made to that price. Where the transaction value of the imported goods cannot be used as the basis for their valuation a sequence of five alternative methods is provided. If all these methods fail to establish a value for Customs purposes there is provision under proposed new sub-section 157 (8) for the Comptroller-General of Customs to determine the value. The adoption of the GATT valuation will bring Australia into line with the valuation system practised by other major trading nations. Basically, under the valuation changes, imported goods will be valued on the basis of their invoice prices rather than on an average price of the goods in the country of origin. The aim of the change has been to provide more certainty to Customs valuation.

As the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) stated, the Opposition does not oppose these measures because the need for such a change in valuation of goods obviously has become necessary. However, one must ask this question: Why has it taken the Government since May 1980 to bring in these measures? While quite a long period of delay has been in existence the business community has been able to import goods into Australia at a value rate lower than the true rate. The Government's reluctance to quickly bring in these measures has benefited the business community and at the same time has denied the Government its proper revenue share through the importation of goods into Australia during that period. Whilst supporting the Bill we trust that the Government will closely monitor the situation to ensure that government revenue is not lost through the false valuation of imported goods. Trade in and out of Australia is very important to our economy and should be encouraged. The proposed valuation of goods for Customs import duty purposes will not impede trade but will only place the business community in Australia on an equal footing with its counterparts in most other trading countries that have adopted the GATT agreement.

I conclude by saying how important it is for Australia to retain a strong manufacturing industry. This in no way implies that I do not think that some improvements can or should be made to production methods and also methods to create greater economies in Australia's existing manufacturing industries. I feel that present statements by the Government in which it is suggested that some Australian manufacturing industries will have their assistance removed so that they can go to the wall, as some have in previous years, will do nothing but great damage to the Australian economy and the Australian community. I think it is a falsification to assume that if freer trade exists between Australia and other nations, prices will be lowered. Certainly they may be lowered in the short term, but in the long term if we remove the element of competition by doing away with our local manufacturing processors I believe that prices inevitably will rise. I feel that history has proved that to Australia and it certainly has proved it to other countries. I commend the Government on bringing forward this legislation but again query the delay in bringing it forward since the Government agreed in May 1980 to be a party to the GATT agreement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Progress reported.
Consideration of Report of Extimates Committee D
Debate resumed from 14 October.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the house is:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) That the following proposed expenditures be agreed to:
Advance to the Minister for Finance
(2) That the resolution agreed to by Committee D in relation to the Department of Transport be noted, namely:

That this Committee, recognising the disruption being caused to air services and the tourist industy in Australia and the substantial costs being incurred by air service operators because of the shortage of air traffic controllers, commends the Government in its immediate efforts to overcome the shortage of air traffic controllers and calls upon the government not to relent in those efforts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted last night I was discussing the fact that at Estimates committee hearings this year there was not enough time to cover the whole gamut of the Transport portfolio. It is a huge department; I understand that it is the second or third biggest department in the Commonwealth Government. I was appealing especially for more time to be given to debates on the Estimates in future years. I mentioned also last night that during the time that we had for discussing the estimates for the Department of Transport we did not manage to discuss the international aviation situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I expressed concern at what Australia's future policy may be in light of the fact that the Government is about to embark on yet another review of Australia's international civil aviation policy. I was pleased to hear the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), in response to a question of mine this morning, indicate that the preliminary work by Sir David Hay and members of the Department of Transport had almost been completed; that it was hoped that shortly we would hear the guidelines for the proposed review; and that, most importantly, the review would not be kept within the Department of Transport.

I suppose that our minds go back to the ill-fated international civil aviation policy review of a couple of years ago. That review was held behind closed doors and we had a situation in which the Department of Transport sat in judgment of its own decisions and its own policies. At a time when the international world of aviation is in a state of turmoil-indeed, the situation is difficult for a number of international operators-it is absolutely essential that the proposed review should be as broad-ranging as possible, as probing as possible, to make sure that Australia does not get itself into the situation in which a number of overseas countries find themselves.

I suppose that we have to look around the world today and see what is happening, with record losses being announced by operators such as British Airways and Pan American World Airways Inc. Indeed, I understand that Qantas Airways Ltd sustained quite a substantial loss during last financial year and that is extending into this financial year. It was reported in the Press this morning that, because of strikes and various other factors, Qantas could be facing a $20m loss for the first six months of this year. That must concern us all. There is a feeling abroad that there need to be some very real changes in the nature of Australia's civil aviation policies. I believe that this feeling comes not only from the travelling public but also from State governments, State tourist corporations, the travel industry generally and the hotel and other tourist operators that are now scattered around Australia.

Tourism has been expanding tremendously in the last few years. At a time when tourism is fast heading towards a situation in which it will become a net income earner for the country, we certainly do not want to lose any edge that we may have in that market at the moment. Of course, so much of the future of the tourist industry and the wealth that it can provide will hinge on the decisions which will be made in the coming weeks by virtue of the new international civil aviation policy review. It is essential that that review should look at the entire structure of airlines in Australia. There is no doubt that Qantas has had some difficulties in the past and that there is room for expansion of our domestic airlines into some of the regional routes.

I suppose that that has been exemplified in recent days with, for example, the announcement that Air New Zealand Ltd is dropping no fewer than 13 services between Brisbane and New Zealand and between Sydney and New Zealand. One of the factors which could be cited as a reason for the cancellation is not only a lack of patronage but also the type of equipment being used by a number of the international carriers operating on the short-haul routes into Australia is too big for the job. Air New Zealand is using 747s and DC10s and Qantas is using 747s on the trans-Tasman route, but those aircraft are just too big for the job. The 747 was never really designed for short-haul traffic anyway.

We can look at the situation that has existed since the opening up of the Christchurch-Hobart run, on which both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines are using 727-200 series Boeing jets. The interesting thing is that TAA's operations on that run are already profitable. That was a case of horses for courses-the 727 was an ideal aircraft to operate on that route. With hindsight it would be easy to say that perhaps Qantas should have ordered 727s, Airbus equipment or something smaller than the present Boeings which they operate, in order to operate that service. But that is with hindsight. We must look to the future and the last thing which I think we would want to see would be a deprivation of any services which may be operating in and out of Australia at the moment.
