Obviously one of the very real issues which should be faced by the new international civil aviation policy review is allowing the domestic operators to move into some of those short-haul routes. That is not to say that we should not be looking at the other side of the argument, too, whereby perhaps Qantas could be involved in some of the long-haul domestic traffic in Australia. We hope that that sort of rationalisation may come about.

We should also be looking at the competitive nature of the fare structures that can be set up between Australia and other countries. One of the interesting happenings of the last few weeks was that the Department of Transport dropped the prosecutions of Singapore Airlines Ltd, TAA and travel agents in Hobart for the price cutting of international airline tickets. Frankly, I welcome that move by the Department of Transport because we were saddled with section 106A of the Air Navigation Regulations, which was never really practical but which tried to enforce that old international civil aviation policy. I think we have already an indication of what a little open competition can do in that market-place as a result of that decision, because within days all the major international airlines were entering into the net fare field. Already it is possible for Australians to travel between Australia and London on the new open slather fares for less than $1,000 return. The international airlines are quite openly flouting these fares of $950 to $1,000. I think that can be commended. In fact Qantas-and quite rightly so-has entered into the net fare market. I appreciate that Qantas must also be competitive. I welcome that move by the board and the management of Qantas to start getting into the market-place and competing. Just how low the fares could go is not for me to judge. It is interesting, if one reads some of the London Sunday newspapers in the Parliamentary Library, to see the fares to Australia that are being offered at the moment through some of the travel agents in Great Britain. One fare that was offered in the Sunday Observer of 4 October from London to Australia was #Stg234. That is not an unusual fare. It is on a scheduled carrier. That fare is being advertised quite openly and obviously is being sold.

I believe there is some very real room to move in the structure of international air fares in these coming months, provided that the civil aviation policy review committee looks very closely indeed at getting the optimum amount of competition into that market. As I have said, at a time when conditions in the international aviation industry are tight, to say the least, it is interesting to note that those airlines that are competitive, that are going out after that traffic, are doing extremely well. I have mentioned once before in the House the situation on the London-Miami route where no fewer than five international carriers are now operating, including a relatively new airline in the United States of America called Air Florida. The fact that that route was opened to competition brought some interesting results. All five carriers on that route are operating profitably. The story concerning Air Florida is an interesting one. In the first 12 month period of operations, its traffic went up 55.6 per cent to 1.8 million people. It had a 156 per cent increase in revenue to $US114m and a 110 per cent increase in profit to $5.1m although it was operating on the lowest fares on that route. There is no reason why Qantas need not go into that sort of market and promote vigorously overseas and at home. There is no reason why more competition could not be introduced to open up the whole market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speek mainly on the estimates for the Department of Finance. During this debate we have heard mainly contributions in relation to the Department of Transport, but as a number of departments were covered by Estimates Committee D I hope that we will find that each one of the headings is related to in this debate when we are reporting the deliberations of what took place in committee rooms away from this chamber. First of all, I wish to make some general remarks about the committee system. In the past there has been criticism of the functioning of these House of Representatives Estimates committees. In my view some of that criticism has been well founded, but perhaps not enough of it has been of a constructive nature.

SPEECH.PARA: This year, I attended and participated in the deliberations of committees covering six departments of State, but only one under this heading of Estimates Committee D, that is, the Department of Finance as I mentioned earlier. Under other committees, the Department of Industry and Commerce, the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, the Parliament, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Trade and Resources and the Department of Finance-on which I intend to concentrate today-were dealt with.

Without wishing to be too critical, it is clear to me that this committee system, as it is presently constituted, has room for a lot of improvement. It is not by any means perfect. On the positive side, the committees provide a useful source of information for members from both sides of the House. They can provide a relatively speedy and time-efficient way of obtaining detailed views from Ministers, or from officers through Ministers, on the present workings of their departments, which information can be gleaned other than through this committee system only by the rather laborious and delay-riddled process of putting questions on notice and awaiting months, as is the present practice, to get answers to those written questions. In my experience, to the credit of the public servants present at those committee hearings, they are always well briefed and very helpful. Yet, as I indicated earlier, I believe there are imperfections. The time for preparation is inadequate. The Minister, if he so chooses, can be extremely unhelpful to a committee in its deliberations. We get some one-word answers at times from some Ministers. I hasten to add that that did not apply to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) who, in the case of the Department of Finance, answered for the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle). He is not used to one-word replies and I am glad that he did not give them in this instance. The endeavours of the committee can be constantly interrupted by other parliamentary duties such as the bells ringing, voting in the chamber and so on.

If the committees are to fulfil their potential, in my view, as a means of improving the quality of Government and the role of all back benchers, those committees must first be taken seriously by the Executive of this nation. At present the committees are too much of a mixed grill. There must be a certain understandable and necessary reluctance on the part of members to give committee work a high priority if they have the fear in the backs of their minds that, if a Minister wishes either to inhibit a committee's deliberations or, worse still, to use a committee to attempt to score political points from the Opposition or, indeed, his or her colleagues, he or she has the capacity to do so. A lot depends on the attitude of the Minister concerned.

Such a situation does not point to any high degree of efficiency in the running of the affairs of the Government or of the Parliament. Government must be open and democratic but it must be efficient also. I repeat that it depends so much on the attitude of the Minister. Perhaps that is one of the values of the committee system inasmuch as one is able to gauge to a greater extent the attitude of the Minister concerned to the Parliament and whether he has a respect for parliamentary procedures. Also, of course, beyond that, one can gauge whether a department is being run efficiently and a Minister has control over his or her department.

Stated generally, it is the function of the Department of Finance to which I now turn to evaluate government expenditure proposals and programs, collect and analyse forward estimates of expenditure, and to administer the public accounts and so on. To use the Treasurer's own words, the Department was founded in an attempt 'to give a greater concentration on specialist expenditure control'. Within that charter, the Department looks also at forward Estimates with a three-year horizon. To some extent, the Department represents a very tentative attempt on the part of the Government to engage in some form of planning. We on this side of the House are absolutely certain that we want to bring in a form of indicative planning in this country, more forward estimating and more forecasting. Indeed, it will be most important for the government sector that this Department improves its procedures. It is a form of planning which is a little, but not much more than that, indicative in nature. This Department is largely confined to monitoring the public sector.

As an exercise in planning, it is pretty unambitious at present. The Department has a proposed staff ceiling of 1290 to June 1982. I believe that more effective use could be made by the Government of the expertise of this Department than is being made at present. The results are not outward looking enough. Even we, as parliamentarians, have difficulty because of the lack of explanatory material provided by the Department in relation to statements on the trends of government expenditure.

In the course of my questioning at this Committee hearing, I asked the Treasurer a number of questions about the role of the Department and the formation of goverment economic policy and its relationship with other departments of State-that is, the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Public Service Board and so on. My concern was-indeed, still is-that there is unnecessary duplication between these and sections of the service as it is now structured. But, at the same time, I have a strong feeling that alternative advice ought to be given, particularly on economic strategy. All the talent in the bureaucracy in the administration of this nation should be encouraged, where there is indeed talent, to come forward and give views so that not just one set of views is being given to the Government through the head of the Department of the Treasury.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting I was speaking on the report of Estimates Committee D. I directed my remarks to the experience I had as a member of the Committee investigating the estimates of the Department of Finance. I said that in my view it is important that economic departments other than the Treasury should present economic advice so that a variety of advice is available to Ministers. When the Australian Labor Party takes over the reins of government it will introduce some medium and long term planning of worth for this nation for the first time in its history. We will then be able to compare ourselves with almost every other nation in recognising that there are longer term objectives as well as short term needs. In my view, the Department of Finance should look after the income or revenue side of government as well as the expenditure side of government. It would then, of course, have even more responsibility to give alternative economic advice.

SPEECH.PARA: To be frank, the Fraser Government's record in the area of economic forecasting has been less than inspiring. Some statistics have been, to use a word of the previous Treasurer, now the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), 'rubbery'. To illustrate this I point out, firstly, that since 1977 the present Treasurer has never got M3 right. Secondly, the Government, despite enthusiastic support at another Estimates committee by departmental officials for our export incentive scheme, is proceeding to dismantle that scheme and others which are of help to industry in the face of a deteriorating balance of payments situation. My third point is that the Budget strategy is wrong, as revealed by the balance of payments figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss the Treasury estimates. Before doing so I note in passing that this debate is remarkable in that the Government seems to be totally uninterested in it. So far I am the seventh speaker from the Opposition. There have been two speakers from the Government. Despite the fact that in this debate one can talk about primary industry, no one from the National Country Party has bothered to talk about it. One can talk about transport. I think that one speaker from the Government spoke about transport. It seems to me that the Government is pretty uninterested in these important areas-primary industry, transport, the Treasury and finance.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer to tax avoidance in particular. I make the point that a notable feature of the Government's action in this area is the way in which it has had to be spurred into action by the Opposition. A good example occurred during the debate on the Estimates Committee dealing with the Treasury. I raised with the Treasurer (Mr Howard) his lack of action on the blatant avoidance of the short term capital gains tax, under section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, by the Bell group of companies and the Bond corporation. This involved the simple device of placing shares bought in the process of a share raid in a subsidiary company, the sole assets of which were these shares, and selling the company rather than the shares at a greatly increased valuation, so avoiding short term capital gains tax. The Bell group did this in March of this year. We raised the issue then. On 9 April the Treasurer said in the House that he would put recommendations to the Government regarding this matter shortly. By 9 September when the Estimates Committee dealing with the Treasury met no action had been announced. The matter was raised that day and, quite remarkably, the Treasurer was able to make a statement to the House the very next day announcing action to prevent the use of this tax loophole. That is one example of the Government being spurred into action by the Opposition.

Another example involves avoidance through the misuse of the taxation incentives for the arts scheme. In April of this year it was revealed that a donation of pre-Columbian art to the National Gallery of Victoria was used to claim a tax deduction of $3.7m for a group of 22 businessmen who paid only $1.2m for the collection. This matter was raised by the Opposition at that time. The Treasurer said that he would ask the Commissioner of Taxation to examine the matter to see what legislative and administrative changes needed to be made. On Tuesday of this week, when debating the income tax Bills in this House, I drew attention to the fact that nothing had been done about this avoidance scheme six months after the issue had come to light. The very next day-yesterday-the Treasurer announced action to prevent tax avoidance by this means. He announced it by issuing a Press release rather than by making any statement to the House although the House was meeting yesterday. That statement bears all the hallmarks of hasty and ill-considered compilation. This is especially so in that it contains a glaring gap which will doubtless be exploited in the future to enable tax avoidance to proceed through this scheme.

I will say a few words in more detail about this tax avoidance scheme. It exploits section 78Aa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which allows a tax deduction for gifts of property to the Australiana Fund, public art galleries, libraries or museums. As the section now stands, the gifts qualify for deduction irrespective of when or how the property was acquired by the donor. The amount of the deduction is the value of the property at the time of gift based on the average of two or more valuations by approved valuers, subject to the Commissioner being satisfied that this amount fairly represents the value of the property. In the case I have already mentioned involving the National Gallery of Victoria the syndicate purchased the collection for $1.2m after being advised that it had been valued at $3.7m by three overseas valuers. Members of the syndicate knew before they bought the collection that they could obtain much more from the tax deduction than they would be able to obtain on a claim based on the outlay to purchase the collection. They knew that they would make a substantial tax gain from making this purchase and donating the collection. The deduction was based on the valuation rather than the lower purchase price. They were able to claim a deduction of $3.7m, three times their initial outlay. Total tax savings would thus have amounted to $2.2m if all investors were paying the top margin of tax rate. If each had contributed equally to the purchase price and paid $54,545 they could claim a donation of $168,182 and save tax of $100,909, almost double the initial outlay.

This scheme was successful only because the Government had liberalised the donation rules in 1978. Previously deductions had been allowed only when the property was purchased by the donor within the preceding 12 months and the deduction was limited to the lesser of the value at the time of gift or its cost to the donor. The 1978 changes abolished the 12 months requirement and allowed revaluation at the time of gift, regardless of the fact that this could be far in excess of the purchase price. The Treasurer's statement indicates that the Government now proposes to move back towards the pre-1978 rules. When the property is donated within 12 months of acquisition the deduction will be limited to the lesser of the value of the property or its cost except for property inherited by the donor. In an attempt to ensure that these rules are not avoided by holding property for over 12 months prior to making a gift, the deduction will again be restricted in such a case to the lesser valuation or cost where the property was acquired for the purpose of making a donation or is subject to an agreement about donation. However, these changes will still leave this scheme wide open for abuse. Rather than stopping tax avoidance, the Government has created scope for continuing dispute along the lines which have emasculated section 26 (a).

It will be easy for a potential tax avoider to obtain property which is kept for 12 months, ostensibly for investment or collection, and then donate it at a very high valuation and receive a large tax deduction along the lines of the Victorian scheme. This will be possible because, under the proposed changes, the deduction in this case will still be based on the value of the collection at the time of gift-not its cost to the donor. How will the Taxation Commissioner prove that the donor had the initial purpose of making a deduction rather than collecting? How can the collector be penalised for changing his mind? Similar questions have arisen with section 26 (a), which aims to tax capital gains on the sale of property purchased with the intention of making a profit. This section has been rendered useless by High Court decisions because the Commissioner cannot prove the intent of profit making in many cases. Yet, we have the same principle which has been destroyed by the High Court decisions in respect of capital gains being incorporated in this legislation which was announced yesterday by the Treasurer to overcome a tax avoidance scheme. Quite obviously that will not work. This is typical of the half-hearted way in which the Government acts against tax avoidance. It simply creates more loopholes every time supposed anti-avoidance action is taken. It further illustrates the hasty, ill-thought-out way in which the Government amends the tax Act to provide generous concessions to particular groups and then has to tighten up these concessions against abuse. The film concessions will be well in the minds of honourable members as having suffered the same fate.

I mention just briefly also the staffing levels in the Australian Taxation Office. In the Estimates Committee we raised the matter of the reduction of the number of staff in the enforcement section of the Taxation Office, which remarkably has been reduced by 179 persons. I would have thought that with tax avoidance and evasion at all time highs, the last place the Government would be cutting back on staff would be with respect to a tax office and that, in particular within that office, it would not be cutting back on the enforcement section of the office. That, in fact, is what has been done with this enormous reduction of 179 persons. When that matter was raised in the Estimates Committe the Treasurer said that the Public Service Board had been asked to review the consequences of staff ceilings on the Taxation Office. Well, what has happened to that review? The Treasurer said that the review would be completed soon. He said that on 9 September, that is, about five weeks ago.

The year goes on with the Taxation Office still with this much reduced level of staff compared with what it should have, particularly in the enforcement area. We have had no word from the Treasurer yet about the results of this review by the Public Service Board. It seems to us to be a matter of an absolutely very high priority that the Government, one way or another, ensures that the Taxation Office has in the enforcement section enough people to ensure that it can adequately keep up with its job of finding out tax avoidance schemes and rooting out tax evasion schemes and tax evaders and can be able thereby to ensure some equity in the tax system. To take away substantial numbers from this section of the Taxation Office just seems to us to be an absolute absurdity. To allow that situation to continue in the way that the Government has seems to us to be something for which this Government should be condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish also to speak about transport. The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) at the start of a 10-minute speech on tax avoidance made the assertion that no members from this House had risen to speak on the subject of transport. Up to that time there were two. The number has now got to four. The point is that up to that time there had been two. It seems to me that he is a doubtful witness. I would not be at all surprised if the Treasurer (Mr Howard) took into account the fact that he got his first fact wrong when he takes the rest of his speech into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The East-West Airlines Ltd organisation recently announced a no frills air service between this city-Canberra-and Sydney. The service is to operate on a fare of $49.50 with a $32 standby fare. That compares with $60.70, which was the fare offered by the two major airlines, Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines. Shortly after that announcement Ansett offered to meet that fare. A significant point was made by Ansett's Canberra manager, Mr Des Vidian, yesterday. I quote from a newspaper account of what he said. The article stated:
. . . he did not expect a reduction in Ansett jet flights between Sydney and Canberra because of the increased volume of services.

That is interesting in view of evidence that was given to the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. He also said that if a drop in traffic became apparent Ansett was more likely to bring in fare discounts on the route than cut services. This indicates that at least some of the Ansett staff believe that the demand for air travel is very elastic, that as the price falls more people will travel. This is consistent with the experience in the United States of America and, I submit also, it is consistent with what one would expect. If we see competition on a route that brings the price down we are catering for a demand that is there. There are people who wish for cheaper travel.

I shall tell the House of an incident that happened in my office. I will change marginally the events as they took place just to make it impossible for anyone to identify my constituent. A lady came into my office a little tearful. She told me that she had a daugher in Sydney, single and pregnant. She desperately wanted to travel across the continent to see her daughter and help her. That was a perfectly reasonable request. But what is significant to this debate is that she pointed out to me that had she been in the United States she could have afforded to have done so. At that stage it cost $US99 to travel the full length across the United States which is a distance only very slightly further than-but essentially the same distance as-it is from Perth to Sydney. She was prevented from travelling because of the airline system in Australia which is a highly regulated system as opposed to the deregulated system that exists in the United States. She did not want a sophisticated, frilly service. She desperately wanted to get to Sydney for a price she could pay. She did not care very much whether she travelled at night or whether she was seated at the back of the aircraft; she did not want meals; she wanted to get there. She was typical of the thousands and thousands of people who would be travellers if, in fact, the system would let them. The price for which they can travel is more important than any peripheral frills.

We have a situation in Perth where young people are travelling to Bali and companies are holding conventions in Bali because it is cheaper. It is cheaper to go to Bali than it is to go to Adelaide. Yet, if we had the fare prices that have been achieved in the deregulated system in the United States that would not be the case. It is bad for the Western Australian tourist industry. It is bad that Western Australians are, for financial reasons, going overseas instead of seeing Australia. It is bad for the unity of Australia that one State, because it is geographically isolated, should feel isolated by the system. It is bad that any part of this nation should feel that the other part of the nation is setting up an artificial barrier to contact between Western Australia, in this case, and the rest of the nation. It is bad politically, economically and socially. Yet, Ansett indicates that it believes that the market for air travel is elastic-that as the price comes down more people travel. That is precisely what one would expect.

It is surprising that the one route that has a three-airlines system is the one that the bureaucrats use, not on the long haul route between Perth and the eastern States where people really pay a lot of money to travel. No! It is the shortest trunk route, the one that the bureaucrats use. We go to a three-airline system that, with a bit of competition, has forced the price down. Perhaps they and their wives travel to Sydney to the opera. Good for them. But why should not the rest of Australia have access to the type of service that results from competition.

I want to say something about competition. It is important that Ansett and TAA compete with East-West Airlines on a fair basis and that the services of the two major airlines are not in some way cross-subsidised by earnings on other routes. I am hopeful that the TAA application will be rejected because I do not see how a straight 20 per cent discount can be other than a cross-subsidy unless the fare in the first place was wrong and was cross-subsidising another area. If the fare were set correctly in the first place, reflecting all costs, which is an enormously difficult thing to establish-but since we are going to have a regulated system somehow or other we have to establish just that-the 20 per cent discount must necessarily be a cross-subsidy. So, I am hopeful that that will be rejected. But I am also hopeful that they will get into the system with something that is as cheap to operate as East-West does. I welcome competition, but it must be fair competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —We always look after the constituents of the honourable member for Canberra.

—We are all heart. We will always look after the constituents of the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) if she looks after ours. I remind the House of some things that were said by the Holcroft Committee and to the Holcroft Committee so that the risk of this cross-subsidisation is not underestimated. The House might remember that Bizjets operated to Tasmania. The House might also remember that the Holcroft Committee received evidence that Bizjets was defeated in its efforts by the predatory pricing of Ansett. The inquiry said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Inquiry feels bound to observe that if the airlines' pricing practices were not exempted, some of them would be likely to draw the attention of the Trade Practices Commission.
The fact is that if the airlines had not been excluded from the ambit of the Trade Practices Commission, in the belief of the Holcroft inquiry their practices would have been illegal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my remarks to the Estimates Committee report on the Department of the Treasury. At the meeting of Estimates Committee D on 9 September the Treasurer (Mr Howard) expressed the view that a greater reliance on indirect taxation would reduce tax evasion. He further indicated that he was sceptical that a person who had evaded tax for five or 10 years would re-enter the taxpaying community even if tax rates were reduced. It appears that his solution to the problem of tax evasion is to require these people to pay indirect taxes. What happens to those pay-as-you-earn taxpayers who are presently paying almost 46 per cent of total tax revenue received by this Government? There is no escape for them. They continue to pay income tax but, in addition, the regressive indirect taxes will further reduce their disposable incomes by an amount estimated by the Australian Taxpayers Association at $3.50 per week for the average family. It appears that the Treasurer has decided to throw in the towel on tax evasion. The facts are that those people will pay indirect taxes while the honest Australians paying income tax will be further slugged by paying regressive indirect taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer further expressed the opinion that the field audit system of the Australian Taxation Office was very successful, but that it was not well received by some taxpayers. That is not surprising as the Treasurer admitted that the system of field audits was effective in the areas of direct evasion, tax avoidance and understatement of income. All of these practices are perverting our tax system and have caused the tax burden to fall on those least able to afford it. Who cares whether those people who are evading or avoiding tax or understating income are not pleased by the field audit system? It appears that this matter causes the Treasurer some concern. The resources of the Taxation Office should be increased, particularly in the area of field audits. But to the contrary, there has been a substantial reduction in full time employment within the Taxation Office. That is an extraordinary approach to a situation where the Treasurer admits that we have a grave problem of tax avoidance and an even graver problem in the area of tax evasion. Yet, as was pointed out by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), the enforcement areas of the Taxation Office have, in fact, been reduced from the point of view of manpower. The indirect taxes are a further indication of the deceit of this Government. The history of this problem should be spelt out.

In June 1978, the Treasurer announced an inquiry into the system of indirect taxation, including value added tax. In January 1979 he announced that plans for a value added type tax had been shelved. That was, of course, after the matter had been floated. There had been a community response which was adverse and then the Government changed direction. But on 19 October 1980, the day after the election, there was again speculation about indirect taxation. On 19 November, a month after the election, the Treasurer announced a major study of possible new forms of indirect tax. There was not a mention of it prior to the election. In fact, in January 1979 the Treasurer indicated that any such proposals had been shelved. Yet a month after the election we had an announcement that there would be a major study into possible new forms of indirect tax.

On 12 March 1981 the Treasurer made a ministerial statement that the Government was going to do nothing to change the tax system. The reason given was that a significant increase in indirect tax to enable reductions in personal income tax would be too inflationary. But what happened then? The 1981 Budget introduced a broad based wholesale sales tax on all items except food and medicines. The tax on goods formerly levelled at 2 1/2 per cent increased to 5 per cent; tax on goods set at 15 per cent increased to 17 1/2 per cent; and tax on goods at 27 1/2 per cent increased to 30 per cent. At some stage in the future, in a desperate attempt to hang on to power, despite the previous statements, there will be income tax cuts. But this time the electorate will know that this Government has again engaged in a confidence trick which the people of Australia will not tolerate on this occasion.

The question of interest rates is one which is causing untold suffering to those struggling with ever increasing mortgage payments, yet it appears that this crucial item of expenditure will not be included in the consumer price index. At the present time the Australian Bureau of Statistics is reviewing the consumer price index. However, at the Estimates Committee hearing we were told that the prospect of including the item of interest rates in the consumer price index was not very good. More than half of the countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development managed to include interest rates in their consumer price indices. It is difficult to see why Australia cannot manage it. It is such a significant factor that it requires urgent attention. The Government must pursue this matter.

One of the reasons given for the delays and problems in relation to the review of the consumer price index was the obsession that this Government has. It was stated at the hearing by an officer of the Bureau of Statistics that like every other Government department the Bureau is heavily constricted by staff ceilings. It is doing this work with a very small additional number of staff. It is not easy to find the right people to undertake it. A better job is done if it is spread over a longer term and carried out by a smaller number of more skilled people. The Government cannot continue to procrastinate on this matter. Action should be taken to step up that review in order that this crucial item of expenditure is included in the CPI so that it gives a reasonably true reflection of the increased cost of living to be borne by the people of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly want to refer to the works commitments of the Department of Transport and to a large extent the comments I make will be based on my experience as Chairman of the Joint Committee on Public Works which has had opportunities over recent years to look at a number of works undertaken by the Department. If honourable members look at the appropriation they will see that the Department of Transport has one of the largest capital expenditures within the Commonwealth Budget with the exception of Defence. The Department of Transport works commitment is very large indeed. To some extent this is partially caused by a backlog because certain works that should have been performed in the past have not been done. Also these estimates cater in part for the new generation of aircraft and for the increased traffic that is now developing at a number of airports. Unfortunately to some extent the expenditure is necessary to honour a number of election promises. This has required capital expenditure prematurely. I am concerned about a number of these things. Some of the election promises include airport terminals at Perth, Canberra, Darwin and a complete new airport at Brisbane. These promises in themselves involve substantial commitments by this Government and will have a substantial effect on reducing other expenditure which is also needed. I have not referred to the problem of Sydney airport where, due to political and other difficulties, a major problem is developing. The existing airport is operating very close to its capacity. So a massive task is before the Department of Transport in planning the capital expenditure required to meet immediate needs over the next few years.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to several aspects of which I am critical of the Department and its methods of planning expenditure. For instance, in recent times the Public Works Committee has been looking at a new air traffic services centre and control tower for Perth Airport. This of course is of concern to a number of Western Australian members who are in the House at the moment-the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde), the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) and the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean). It has been one of our efforts to get this work undertaken because there is definitely a requirement for development at Perth Airport. But in doing this we have found that there has not been a master plan developed for the airport; so we are not sure, in siting such a work as the control tower, whether it will fit into the long term designs for the airport. The people who appeared before the Public Works Committee recently in Perth and advocated that the work should be deferred until the master plan was available had a very valid point. The Committee will, in its report, be forced to weigh up the views that they put and the fact that this work is critical, from a safety aspect. I think it is an indictment of the Department that there is no master plan for Perth airport to indcate exactly where necessary development should be going on.

One of the greatest comedy of errors is in relation to the Brisbane Airport where, of course, in 1979 the Public Works Committee recommended deferring commencement of that work so that the completion date would be in the 1990s or so. At that stage, the airport, with a capacity of 165 aircraft movements a year, would have been adequate until 1991. The plan advanced to the Committee at that stage-in 1979-was that a new major runway would be constructed which could be used in conjunction with one of the existing runways at the airport. But from recent evidence given before the Public Works Committee we have now found out that this operation reduces capacity to a stage where it is not sufficient to meet the needs even in 1986. We find also that this plan, which was advocated in 1979, requires 37 additional staff and that it also requires about $1.2m additional capital expenditure to make it work. The Committee was not told these facts in 1979 and I doubt very much whether the Department knew about them. I think the very fact that the Department has not taken into account such important factors makes one critical of the planning methods of the Department in relation to capital works.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to respond to Government decisions.

—Okay; perhaps the Minister is telling me the Government decision is wrong and not the Department. This may well be the case. One other element I refer to is the fact that there seems to be a proliferation of international terminals within Australia. It worries me that international terminals are expensive facilities to provide because of the additional staff required for immigration and for a number of other security and quarantine functions. It seems to me that we should be looking very closely at whether further international terminals should be developed in Australia, because all this expenditure has an effect on the cost recovery program. For instance, just the $265m being spent on Brisbane Airport will have the effect of increasing the average domestic air fare by between $3.50 and $4. That is a substantial increase purely to repay the domestic commitment in the cost recovery program. The old Brisbane Airport has the capacity for 165,000 movements per annum which would have met the forecast traffic needs until 1991. The new runway that has been approved has a capacity of 130,000 movements per annum which will meet requirements only until 1995, and the runway is to open in 1986. We now have a revised provision of 183,000 movements a year which will meet the needs until 1994. So the early recommendation of the Public Works Committee in 1979 that the work be deferred for some time was very valid; and I take note of the Minister's early interjection.

SPEECH.PARA: I am heartened to some extent because I believe there is an interdepartmental committee responsible for looking at airport strategies. I understand that this interdepartmental committee will be reporting later this year or some time early next year. I understand that it is charged with the responsibility of trying to put the various works within the Department of Transport in order of priority. I emphasise that the complaint I am making is that it is very clear now that we have never had clear orders of priority in the way in which works in the Department of Transport should be scheduled. I hope that the report of the interdepartmental committee will provide this.

I referred earlier to the master planning of Perth Airport. I request the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) to make every effort to ensure that master planning of airports proceeds and is available before works are committed within those areas. My plea with regard to the works aspects of the Department of Transport is that we should be able to put them in order of priority and that we should be able to plan the expenditure for a number of years. In that way I am sure we will get better co-ordination and planning in our airports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government's monetary and budgetary strategy for 1981-82, centering as it did on an expected massive level of private capital inflow of $7 billion to $8 billion, was always ill-conceived. The adoption of such a strategy reflected two persistent themes underlying the management of the economy by the Fraser Government: Firstly, its total ineptitude in the conduct of monetary policy year by year; and, secondly, its willingness to accept unconditionally foreign money from any source.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Budget was introduced into the Parliament nearly two months ago, the Opposition warned the Government against relying on the net balance of payments position to provide nearly half of total growth in money supply in 1981-82. We suggested, firstly, that private capital inflow was too volatile an item on which to pin one's monetary strategy hopes and, secondly, that the private capital inflow that has found its way to these shores had been predominantly portfolio investment-hot money-buying up Australian real estate, shares in Australian companies or simply speculating on trends in the Australian dollar exchange rate.

The totally inadequate response of the Government and its apologists among the economic and financial commentators has been: Well, if private capital inflow falls short of the target, the authorities can always shift round quickly by easing up the restrictions on domestic credit creation, by selling fewer government bonds or by releasing some of the $1,900m locked up in statutory reserve deposits. However, the question is: How long will the Government wait before some of the necessary adjustments are made? The figures for the September quarter point to an all-time record quarterly balance of payments deficit, hardly the launching pad for a substantial full year balance of payments surplus. Without the expected flow of funds from overseas into the banks, in combination with the massive $1,500m withdrawal from money supply via the Budget, there will be a rapid drying-up of credit in the community. While the Government ponders its next move, the home buyers and the businessmen seeking finance must grit their teeth and wait or chase fringe finance at exorbitant rates of interest.

It was clear at the time of the Budget that the forecast flood of foreign money, unrestrained by any coherent set of controls protecting our national interest, was to be offset principally through massive increases in family taxation. It is equally clear now that if this expected level of private capital inflow does not materialise, as many commentators are now suggesting, the Government has no intention of handing back any of the 22 per cent increase in income tax or the 39 per cent increase in sales tax. The Government's total failure to acknowledge or to act upon the clear evidence of a massive buying up operation of Australia's industry, real estate and resources must be brought to the attention of the Australian people. Its willingness to incorporate this largely unrestrained flood of foreign money into its monetary policy strategy must be condemned.

Since 1976-77, more than $13 billion of foreign investment has flowed into enterprises in Australia. Excluding undistributed income, more than 60 per cent of that foreign investment has been portfolio investment-hot money-in shares, real estate and the like. It is speculative investment. From the Foreign Investment Review Board statistics, we learn that in 1980-81 two-thirds of the value of foreign investment scrutinised by the Board was for the takeover of existing business in Australia. The Foreign Investment Review Board, as it is presently constituted, appears to be little more than a welcoming committee for every get-rich-quick merchant in Europe, North America and South East Asia.

Before this Government abolished the section of the Australian Bureau of Statistics which compiled data on the extent of foreign ownership of Australian industry, we knew that about half of Australian industry in the early to mid-1970s was foreign-owned; that is, apart from Canada, Australia had the highest foreign penetration of its economy in the world. We can only guess at what is the current level of foreign ownership. The paucity of recent information on the degree of foreign ownership is scandalous when all the evidence points to there having been a massive buying-up operation of Australian industry under the Fraser Government.

Let me tell the House what a Labor government would do-the Government after 1983. A Labor government would re-establish the very important foreign participation section of the Bureau of Statistics. Another major impediment to gaining a clear picture of the true extent of overseas ownership of Australian industry has become apparent from a study by Mr Peter Davies of the Australian Financial System Inquiry. He conducted an analysis of the BHP share register over the period 1970-79. He found that nearly 70 per cent of bank nominee holdings of BHP shares were on behalf of non-residents. He concluded from his analysis that 'overseas ownership of BHP would now be headed towards 25 per cent'. The drama of that is simply this: It is in marked contrast with the figure of 9 per cent foreign ownership cited in the BHP annual report. It is our contention, the Labor Party's concern, that the operation of nominee companies needs to be overhauled. It is true that, in many instances, nominee holdings are quite validly held on behalf of overseas investors and superannuation funds use nominee companies for convenience or because they are not recognised as a legal entity by share registrars in their own right. The significance of being able to identify beneficial ownership has been highlighted by Mr Davies' study. Labor in government would move to require beneficial ownership of nominee shareholdings to be made known, to be declared publicly.

If the extent of hidden overseas ownership apparent in BHP is true for other Australian companies, questions need to be asked about the ability of the Foreign Investment Review Board to police the foreign investment guidelines. Can we now be sure that all broadcasting and television is at least 80 per cent Australian owned, that uranium projects-putting to one side the Labor Party's clear commitment to its policy-are at least 75 per cent Australian owned, and that mining and primary industry projects are at least 50 per cent Australian owned? We want to know whether we are being taken to the cleaners by the shroud of secrecy which nominee companies provide. Of particular concern to the Opposition is the potential for breaches of agreements by companies granted naturalising status. The Opposition is not satisfied with the procedures for checking the progress towards the attainment of majority Australian ownership by naturalising companies.

These companies should be required to apply formally for registration with the Foreign Investment Review Board and be subjected to annual scrutiny by the Board as to their true beneficial ownership position and their progress towards majority Australian shareholding. We would require companies also to agree to some broad time scale for the achievement of majority Australian shareholding. A divestment procedure would be applied in the case of companies which the FIRB considers to be failing to fulfil their obligation to achieve majority Australian ownership. The granting of naturalising status is a privilege which, under present procedures, is open to abuse by foreign companies. With proper safeguards, the naturalising procedure would become a valuable means of achieving greater Australian ownership and control of our resource industry. Clearly, the Government must require that the national interest is enhanced by granting approval to naturalise and that progress towards majority Australian ownership is not made through the takeover of existing Australian enterprises.

To conclude, Labor believes that the conduct of foreign investment policy by the Australian Government needs to be clearly separated from day to day economic management considerations. Foreign investment and the development of Australia's resources are necessarily long term considerations requiring sensible, clearly enunciated policies which maximise Australia's national interest. The conduct of a foreign investment policy which puts an end to the unchecked bargain basement sell-out of Australian industry and Australian resources must necessarily involve having access to up to date information on the extent of foreign ownership in Australia. A Labor government, post-1983, will also be anxious to ensure that the guidelines governing naturalising status operate to provide genuine progress towards majority Australian ownership of Australia's resource industries. Without these measures, and others such as a profits related resource rent tax, the benefits of the resources boom will not accrue to all Australians, but rather, and inexcusably, to foreign investors and an elite few Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a couple of matters which I believe are most important to this transport debate. They are firstly, the matter of country airports and, secondly, the situation in relation to the provision of finance for roads throughout Australia, particularly in the country areas of Australia. A large amount of money is to be spent and is being spent on the airports in some of the capital cities and on other major airports throughout Australia. I draw the attention of the Government to the fact that it is most important that the facilities actually available in many provincial cities and towns throughout Australia be improved to meet the needs of the communities concerned and the travel industry. I feel that as time goes by greater pressure must be brought to bear by the local authorities and the owners of the aerodromes concerned for a building up of the services and facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken a number of times in the House of the most unsatisfactory situation concerning road finance in Australia. I particularly want to refer to the situation in New South Wales. I am very conscious of the fact that we are at present in the second year of a five-year agreement between the Commonwealth and the States on the provision of $3,650m for three categories of roads. It concerns me that as the third, fourth and fifth year go by there will be a general reduction in the overall percentage of the moneys available. The major answer to the problem is for the Commonwealth and the States-Government generally-to make a greater allocation of funds for roads. Local government throughout Australia generally looks principally to the Commonwealth for assistance because it is the body which collects the petrol tax moneys. Local government has always-perhaps rightly so-been able to divert attention to the Commonwealth as the body which is basically responsible for road funding.

I illustrate the situation by saying that in New South Wales the funds collected directly from the motorist are the only funds allocated to roads and for road safety throughout the States. In other words, the priorities for New South Wales in the eyes of the New South Wales Government are such that that government does not allocate any of its funds to the vital area of roads. The councils and, I am sure, every member of this House would want the Government to look more closely at the importance of road funding throughout Australia. I know of no more important matter than this to my electorate, which is a country electorate in a growing area. I am sure I speak for those who represent the interior of Australia when I say that the country areas are very dependent on roads and communication facilities.

Three categories are mentioned in the Commonwealth and States agreement-national roads, arterial roads and local roads. I am beginning to wonder whether there should be a general reclassification in this respect. If one goes into any of the country shires throughout Australia today one will find that the most neglected roads are in many cases the main arterial roads that service the towns. The primary producers are terribly dependent upon them and the local school bus travels on them. The safety of the children is a most important aspect as far as we are concerned. These roads are the ones that are deteriorating. They are the ones that are used for bringing the produce to market. They are the roads which people generally use to travel from one major town to another.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ones for which the State governments accept the most responsibility.

—That is quite true. If one looks at the remark of the Minister for Transport a while ago one will find that over the last four or five years the New South Wales Government has reduced its funding assistance to local government in real terms. What is taken from the motorist does not all go back. No extra money is provided for this most important aspect of life today in country areas. I represent people and councils which are concerned about this matter. I believe that next week the President of the Shires Association of New South Wales and the Local Government Association of New South Wales will be speaking again to the Minister on this matter. I believe that they have a very real case for extra funding for roads. If we consult the Australian motorists' associations we will find that they have the figures to prove that a lesser percentage of our overall Commonwealth expenditure in going directly to roads now than there was in the early 1960s. I believe that on their figure alone it is now 1.78 per cent. So it is necessary. I think the Department of Main Roads in New South Wales has pointed out that the actual cost to date, forgetting the consumer price index which was about 8.8 per cent last year-the inflationary trend-to bitumen or to upgrade a road is up between 12 per cent to 16 per cent per year.

SPEECH.PARA: These circumstances are very disturbing for country people and, I believe, for city people as well. They are all concerned about their local roads and about their national roads. The sooner we develop better roads between the capitals of Australia and around the vast circumference of Australia the better for everybody. But those local roads and development of arterial roads of which I spoke earlier are the important ones for which we have to get greater finance. One could go on and talk about the safety aspect of roads, fuel economy, and the growth of the tourist industry within Australia. Many of these aspects have been covered by many people before, but the answer still has not been found. As far as I am concerned there is only one answer to this and that is that there must be a greater allocation to road finance throughout Australia. Also the tidying up could be done through the Commonwealth Grants Commission or some other body. The allocations are the responsibilities of the States. They have to live up to their obligation also.

In fact it disturbs me that year after year when we look at a Budget we see a lesser percentage of this nation's wealth going into the material things that matter to this country. When I speak about material things I speak about roads, natural resources of water within Australia and the preservation of our soil. These are the things that really will cause productivity and will build the economy of Australia that will create work for people and bring a better social life generally. We all want to see this happen in our country. I wanted to add my few words and say that there must be a greater recognition by the Commonwealth and the States of the need for roads and for better bridging within Australia in order to service those who live in those outlying areas and to build up the industries that surround them and that are so dependent upon a better form of communication.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) is at the table for the discussion on these Estimates because I wish to pursue, within the context of the estimates for the Department of Transport, the replies that the Minister gave to two questions, one yesterday from the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie) and one today from myself. The matter relates to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and particularly is in response to the question I raised this morning in which I asked whether the Minister proposed to take further action on the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that there should be a second Sydney airport. I wish to make it very clear that the Prime Minister at last has agreed that there is a necessity for a second Sydney airport. In a letter dated 15 April to the Premier of New South Wales he said that he required the co-operation of the Government of New South Wales in the determination and securing of a suitable site for the construction of a Sydney airport of international standard in the vicinity of Sydney to meet the contingent demands of the community from the end of the century and beyond. Further on in that letter, to underline the Prime Minister's priority concerning a second airport, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There must be a long-term development of a new airport . . .

I, as the member for St George, was delighted to see what in fact has been a change in the Federal Government's policy because the officials in the Department of Transport, particularly those participating in the Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee, remarked that the close spaced parallel runways avoided a commitment to a major second airport for Sydney. So we have it very clearly. I remind the Minister of the Prime Minister's promise. I must confess that he may give only the same degree of credence to a Prime Minister's promise, as a lot of other Australians may, but there is that promise that there is a need for a second airport. We trust that the Prime Minister will carry out for once and for all at least one of his promises.

Various comments have been made by the Minister about the time scale involved in the construction of the second airport, and this ranges from 12 to 20 years. The only thing I can say about that is nonsense. If one looks back to the construction of the second Melbourne airport at Tullamarine, one will see the sort of time scale involved. Certainly no more than nine years are involved in the construction of a second airport. But when we look at the close spaced parallel runways, the Government underestimates the time involved. Again the time taken to construct close spaced parallel runways at Sydney airport will be of the same order as constructing a second airport. I will give some reasons why. When the Minister talked airily about the close spaced parallel runways he missed a few very important technical matters. The first is that the construction of those runways will require appromixately 20 million cubic metres of fill. No study has been made of where that fill will come from. There also has been no mention of the requirement for detailed hydraulic modelling of the effects of putting a runway into Botany Bay.

The other point-I suppose this is a point a lot of people seem to forget-is that when we look at Sydney airport now we see that there are terminals: The Ansett Airlines of Australia terminal, the Trans Australia Airlines terminal and the Qantas Airways Ltd maintenance base. They will all have to go if the Government's proposal for close spaced parallel runways comes into effect. All those structures will have to go. That is the order of things that have to be taken into account which the Minister, in making his various statements, has not mentioned to the public. But these are very serious problems that have to be considered. What we can say is that the timing involved in the construction of close spaced parallel runways will be of the same order as a second airport. A great number of cost estimates have been put out. In fact in the Prime Minister's letter he states a cost of approximately $700m for a second airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eleven hundred million.

—I am quoting the Prime Minister. If the Minister wishes to point out that the Prime Minister is incorrect, I am prepared to believe that again. But in terms of the investigations carried by the Government of New South Wales the cost of the close spaced parallel runways would be of the order of $600m. Here is the proposition of the Prime Minister: First we build close spaced parallel runways and then later on, because he already has promised it, we build a second airport. So we are up for the order of $1,300m. It seems to me to be eminently sensible that all we have to do is to build the second airport and save the Australian taxpayer the sum of about $600m. But also on technical grounds there are reasons against the close spaced parallel runways. These are that in order to have simultaneous operations the runways should be approximately 4,300 feet or 1,300 metres apart, but the Government is proposing that the runways be about 1,100 feet or 335 metres apart. This means that the runway will cost nearly as much as a second airport, but in addition the runway will not be technically efficient because we will not be able to have simultaneous operations.

SPEECH.PARA: I agreed with the Opposition Whip that I would not proceed any further but I make the point that I believe the Government has a responsibility to build the second airport and it should stop fooling around and get on with the job.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, or rather a point for clarification. Are we to understand that again the Minister for Transport is not going to participate in this important debate? Four expensive officers have been sitting in this chamber for several days and the Minister has made no contribution to the debate.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.
—You did not say anything worth answering.
—I call the House to order and ask that private conversations cease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage, until I have had an explanation of these amendments, I think I will do what I threatened to do earlier; that is, oppose all of the amendments. I must confess that I did give leave for all of these amendments to be moved together, on the assumption that there would be an explanation of them. I am not aware that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) has made available to honourable members a memorandum explaining why these amendments have been brought in. As I have said before, I find the Minister a personable bloke. I enjoy his company. I do not like being critical like this of the way in which he is conducting his portfolio. But I think that it is an insult to this Committee that he just walks in here and moves the amendments, having made arrangements for them to be distributed to honourable members. I understand now that they were distributed yesterday afternoon, but they were not drawn to my attention. The Minister is attempting to interject. If he wants to participate in the debate, I welcome him to do so. But he should stand on his feet at that dispatch box and give us an explanation, not just make his speeches sitting down, interrupting me in my speech when I am on my feet.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that I have over the last few hours had some time to look at these amendments in detail. But I still assumed that the Minister would carry out his ministerial duties and explain to the House why these amendments were moved and what is the nature of each one of them. I would have thought that other honourable members have not had the time or the opportunity to do any homework-

TALK.START.PARA: —I waited for them and could not get them.

—As the honourable member for Port Adelaide said, he is in the chamber waiting for them and wanting a full explanation of them. He does not expect to hear it from me. I will resume my seat now, Mr Deputy Chairman, in the hope that the Minister will explain to the Committee what it is all about. If he does not do so, I will ask you for a further opportunity to say something on these measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am more than delighted to make a few explanations of the amendments. Firstly, the amendments were circulated yesterday, contrary to what the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) has said. I regret that they were not delivered to his office. In future they always will be. I think that regrettably they were delivered to the office of the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown).
—I say that it is not good enough.
—I am sorry. It was intended that they be circulated. I regret that they did not get to the places to which they should have gone, but they were in fact circulated yesterday.
—The honourable member for Prospect did not get them in his office.

—I will put the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) on my list. The purpose of amendment No. (2) is to insert a definition of 'container' for the purpose of the new definition of a 'place of export'. The purpose of the amendment No. (3) is to redefine the definition of 'place of export' to enable the continuation of the present practice of treating overseas freight as commencing with goods that are picked up in a container of a type defined by amendment No. (2), as circulated. The purpose of amendments Nos (4) and (5) is to make it clear that the cost of marketing and propotional activities of the purchasers, undertaken for their own benefit, shall in no way be treated for valuation purposes as forming part of the price for imported goods. The purpose of amendment No. (6) is to ensure that a person who is informed of the view of the controller as to the possible effect of the relationship between the purchaser and the vendor on the price of the goods is also informed of the controller's reasons for forming that view.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of amendments Nos (7) to (13) is to remove a possible avoidance device, whereby parties may artificially reduce the apparent sale price or computed value of goods by contributing material, components, et cetera, towards the production of other materials and the component used in the production of the goods so valued. The purpose of amendment No. (14) is to insert a new clause 10A into the Bill to make a formal amendment to section 237GA of the principal Act and to insert a provision in that section to ensure that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be able to review all of the administrative decisions made in the course of valuing imported goods. That is a brief explanation of the amendments. They were brought about by representations from people who operate in the area-namely, customs agents-to make the Customs (Valuations) Act more workable in their interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) for explaining to the Committee these amendments as the Government sees them. In relation to the first group concerning the definition of the place of export, I must confess that the Customs Agents Federation approached both my office and the office of the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), who is the shadow Minister in this area. That group of amendments was known to us. We understand that the current system excludes the costs which arise after goods have been containerised in assessing customs duty. We recognise that the amendment inserted now gives a definition of 'containers' and allows for the costs after containerisation to be excluded from the value for customs duty. That applied previously and it is equitable that it should continue. As is often the case, the Opposition was not approached in relation to the other amendments. It was necessary for me to learn how they arose. The second group of amendments relates to the treatment of rebates. This is clarified in that the costs of promoting or advertising goods are not now taken into account by the Collectors of Customs where such costs are incurred on the account of the purchaser. I believe that this was the original intention. These amendments clarify the matter as provision has already been made in another place in the legislation for this to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: The third group of amendments really involves whether the particular transactions that are taking place are being done at arms length. A provision is inserted that the Comptroller must give reasons why he believes that a relationship between the buyer and the seller could affect the price in a transaction; in other words, if I have understood it correctly, if indeed he believes that the buyer and the seller are not at arms length, I understand that amendment now, although no one actually approached us or gave us any previous indication as to why that amendment was necessary. As the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has just said, the final amendment, (14), inserts a new clause altogether relating to a review of decisions. Provision is made now to extend the rights of persons in dispute with a decision under section 167, that is, a dispute in relation to amounts of duty payable to decisions prior to and relevant to a decision as to duty.

In view of those explanations, the Opposition approves of all of the amendments. We understand, from discussions with the Customs Agents Federation that at least the first amendments were necessary. We now learn from the Minister that perhaps he had had representations from the same source. But he has had representations from other sources which have given rise to these amendments. I thank him for the promise that his office will be in touch with the relevant shadow Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the honourable member for Parramatta. I believe that he knows already that, due to inadequate staff being made available to the Opposition, the person who serves the honourable member for Parramatta serves me also in relation to these matters. I assure the Minister that I took the trouble to make sure that nothing had been delivered, as far as I could ascertain, to the office of the honourable member for Parramatta in view of the fact that he is absent from Australia at present and would have otherwise dealt with this matter. I was assured that nothing had been delivered. I am glad to hear that steps will be taken to ensure that there are not these misunderstandings in the future.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.
