SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill 1981 is an extraordinary piece of legislation that seems to have come from a government that appears to be in a state of paralysis as to what it is all about. There will be an amendment to the Bill because even in the first draft the Government could not get the Bill right. The Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill we regard as being a special benefit amendment Bill. It benefits one particular judge-a pretty handsome benefit-on the basis that the judge will get a pension after a relatively short period of service. That pension will be pretty substantial.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill makes some rather ludicrous changes to the 1968 legislation. It updates references to the Papua New Guinean judges for whom the Government is responsible. It contains the rather delightful expression that it is changing legislation as to the rate of pensions payable to the widow or widower of a judge from five-eighths to 62 1/2 per cent. Every one of us has always thought that five-eighths was 62 1/2 per cent. Every computer or abacus with which I have ever dealt says the same thing. But here it is in the Bill. I thought that changes like that certainly could have been made in a statute law revision Bill because they are purely draft measures.

The real reason for this piece of legislation is to carry out a promise. I thought that legislation should be based more on what applied to the community and to standards rather than to a specific promise. But no. Apparently last year, the then Minister for Industrial Relations, appointed what we would call two 'hired guns' to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, Mr Justice Marks and Mr Justice Maddern. As it turns out, Mr Justice Marks is apparently 59 years of age and he must retire at 65. It seems extraordinary that we have to have a special piece of legislation aimed solely at a benefit which the Government has so comprehensively botched.

TALK.START.PARA: —No marks for that.

—No marks for that. But plenty of marks in the future. I remember making submissions on behalf of a judge in the Family Law Court, and another judge, on the basis that they were going to miss out in respect of other entitlements. The Government did nothing about them. The Family Law Court judge was appointed on the basis that he at least would have been given some consideration. But my submissions fell on deaf ears. The other judge, who was in the Australian Capital Territory, certainly was not going to get any entitlement. But now, because of a special promise made by a Minister to one person, the whole of the law is to be changed to give a special benefit. I think that is to be deplored.

SPEECH.PARA: For Mr Justice Marks to be eligible, the legislation has to be amended by altering section 6 to a qualifying period of six years rather than the present 10 years. Thereby hangs the argument that I am putting forward. The other judges that I have mentioned might have had cause for concern as they would not be able to achieve the 10-year period because their retiring age was altered to 65 years. The Government did nothing about that matter. I hope that these judges benefit under this legislation-I think they might. This legislation seems to be a backward way of doing it, all because of a promise made by a Minister to a particular person.

At present, judges receive a non-contributory pension which is not insubstantial. To that extent one ought to draw a distinction between the parliamentary pension which, admittedly, is substantial but it is also contributory. Judges receive 60 per cent of current judicial salaries but the Government has gone to the trouble of trying to adjust that in this legislation that it has got wrong. It now has to move an amendment to that legislation. When the Government drafted the legislation, it said that the specific period would be seven years. We now have an amendment to make it six years. I say to the Government that we will not approve of it. We will oppose it on the basis that we think it is ridiculous to have this sort of approach given to us as being something that is a considered opinion of a government in relation to standards when, as we say, it is a matter that relates to a specific promise.

When we look at other people in the community, particularly pensioners, we find that, prior to the last election campaign, the Opposition was castigated because it was talking about bringing pensions up to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, and ultimatly 30 per cent when economic circumstances so permitted. That was pooh-poohed as though it was ridiculous. We cannot have one standard for one section of the community and none for the majority. If the stringiness of the Government towards pensioners is to apply, it should apply across the board. As I said, a great deal of Press comment has been made about pensions and what politicians, for example, might get. I make the point that any Labor politician elected at the same age as Mr Justice Marks would not be entitled to a pension. He would never get there in time. When it comes to the Liberal Party no such prohibitions apply. With the greatest of respect to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, we seem to be recycling politicians in that a number of politicians from State parliaments have come into this Parliament on the Government side.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your side? What about Clyde Holding?
—He is only a young man. He has a future. We have never seen him ask three questions that have been ruled out of order.
—He will be recycled again and again, too, in different ways.
—If the Minister has a chance he will do it. We indicate that we will always have fair and open debate.
—The honourable member for Melbourne Ports got a very good pension from a State parliament.
—He paid for it, too.
—I remind honourable members to address the Chair.

—The Minister is worried about the facts and I cannot stop him interjecting. In any event, we think six years is too short a period for qualification for a non-contributory pension. The Minister who made the promise should not feel too badly if we say that he cannot expect us to agree. It is well known that this Government has made a number of promises which it has felt unable to keep, so this one should not cause any embarrassment. There are other factors which ought to be considered. This is a generous pension. Other provisions relate to judges and their children. One does not want to cavil too much at the provisions for the children of judges but there is a disparity between the benefits given to their children and those of other people in the community. This is a cause of comment.

SPEECH.PARA: To summarise the situation, the Bill is necessary to redeem a promise. It has not been properly drawn. We feel that the promise should not have been made. It is lowering standards to suggest that substantial pensions can be paid for a relatively short period of service, particularly when the pensions are non-contributory. I think the Government is embarrassed to have to do this. It is another gaffe. We cannot do much more at the moment than say that we note the embarrassment of the Government. We will oppose the amendment in the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am deeply concerned that we are bringing about changes to the 1968 legislation that will, in effect, in future allow a man to be appointed to a Federal court for a period of only six years and have an entitlement, on a pro rata basis, to a pension for the rest of his life. I am very much aware of why the Government proposes to introduce an amendment to the amendment. Honourable members in the chamber will also be aware that the Bill, as it presently stands, requires a member of the bench to serve for 10 years before he or she will become eligible for a pension. There have been lots of talk and efforts to reduce that period to five years. Some people have consistently opposed such a reduction on the grounds that if a person is to be entitled to a pension for the rest of his living days he or she should at least make a considerable contribution to the nation and 10 years is a reasonable period. However, the wisdom of others decreed-I see some justice in it-that after seven years service a person would be entitled to a pro-rata pension. Often extenuating circumstances exist which cause a late appointment or an early departure. Nevertheless, the period of six years probably creates a new national record in terms of the entitlement of anyone in the country on the Federal payroll to a pension.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in bygone days there was acceptance by the public of the non-contributory nature of the pension for judges. I have discussed this subject in the House. I think the last time I did so I was severely attacked by the then honourable member for Wentworth, who is now Mr Justice Ellicott. That is history. I have been consistent in my belief that the proliferation of the judiciary has brought about a need for change. I believe that the public originally accepted the non-contributory nature of the pension because there was but a handful of Federal judges. At the time of Federation the writers of the Constitution designed a High Court of Australia with a Chief Justice and two judges. That number has now been expanded to seven. I have no argument with that-none whatsoever. I have no argument with the salary level of $87,000 which is now paid to the Chief Justice of the High Court or the $79,000 which is paid to ordinary justices of the High Court. Those men are given the responsbility of making decisions of the highest order. To obtain men of such calibre we need to pay a suitable remuneration. However, when the people of Australia first accepted the principle of judges' pensions the situation was very different from that of today.

In recent years we in the Parliament have seen the creation of the Family Court of Australia, a Federal court. Hey presto, we now have 39 judges earning salaries of between, I think, $55,000 and $67,000 who also are sharing in the advantage of a non-contributory pension scheme. It is a pension scheme and not a superannuation fund because they contribute nothing. It is proper to reflect on the fact that this Bill is being introduced in this chamber and not in the Senate. It is a Bill that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) should have introduced but the reason it has originated in this chamber is that it is a money Bill. The decision we are making today could in the long term be a very costly one for taxpayers.

As well as the creation of the Family Court, we have seen in the last five or six years the creation of the Federal Court of Australia. Whilst I concede that a number of the judges of the Federal Court also serve in other areas of jurisdiction we have seen the appointment of 25 Federal Court judges. When one adds those numbers to the number of Family Court judges, and when one compares those numbers with the original three positions which existed at the birth of the Commonwealth, one sees an expansion, taking all those numbers into account, representing an increase of 25 to 30-fold. Although the pensions have been provided for judges only in the last 40 or so years, I really believe that for a privileged group we are indulging in generosity of a kind that cannot be justified in view of the vast numbers of judges that now exist.

When one considers the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia-I have already said that I have no argument with the level of his salary or with the quality of the work done by that court-and when one looks at a pension worth six-tenths of $87,000, which he will receive for the rest of his natural life, one sees figures the magnitude of which the ordinary person would find it difficult to comprehend. When we relate those figures to Family Court judges, of course, the pension would be considerably less, but it would be far more than the person earning average or even above average wages would ever be likely to earn. All I am saying is that it is high time an amendment was brought into this chamber to provide for a contribution from those on the Bench to their own pension benefits or to their own superannuation schemes. I will not sabotage the workings of the Government today by moving an amendment to that effect but I give notice to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), who is at the table, that should this Bill experience difficulties in the Senate and be returned to this chamber to be subjected to further consideraion by the joint parties I will have no alternative but to move an amendment to the effect that those on the Bench should start contributing to their own superannuation fund. Frankly, I cannot understand the mentality that exists that would change legislation which was introduced to amend existing legislation in order to pick up the needs of one man. That has been explained, but I still find it difficult to stomach, as I believe do most fellow citizens of this country.

In conclusion I refer the Minister again to the fact-I am sure that he is looking up notes to assist him to respond-that the judges or those who have the status of judges number 87 in the Federal area. I know that the argument is used that the State governments give the judges of the Supreme Court and their various other courts access to non-contributory superannuation or pension schemes and that the Commonwealth is only following. I say to the Minister in his capacity as the Minister representing the Attorney-General that if we are to justify what we are doing on the grounds that we have to do it because the States do it, that if we do not do it nobody will come to the Federal courts-they will all stay back home in their various States-it is high time that there was a little bit of morality injected into State thinking with the Commonwealth as leader. Instead of simply saying that we have to follow it is time that the Commonwealth said to the States when they are clamouring for additional funds that this is an area where they can increase their funds by requiring a contribution. To my knowledge there is no other superannuation scheme funded by a government anywhere in this country where the recipients and the later beneficiaries do not have to put in a razoo themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill 1981 I am taking the opportunity to draw attention by way of contrast to the zealous way the Government ensures that the professional elite which controls our society is adequately rewarded for its enthusiastic support of our conservative Constitution. This scrupulous benevolence, which I am most pleased to note the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron) does not support, is not extended to the poorer sections of our society, however. Let us face it; they do not have the numerical strength or the resources to change our social structure, whether it be by constitutional or revolutionary means. By revolutionary means I mean, of course, not a violent revolution but one which accepts that the disadvantaged and poorer people should have a greater say in the decisions which affect the distribution of resources in our community. For members on the Government side of the House this represents a revolutionary view. For them it is the Hancocks and Murdochs of the world who should decide the future direction of Australia's social and economic development.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we discover about this Bill which is, of course, no different in its provisions from many other similar remuneration Bills which have preceded it over the years? As an example, clause 2 (4) provides that the amendments relating to pro rata pensions and amendments of a machinery nature shall come into operation on the 28th day after the day on which the Act receives royal assent. Clause 2 (3) provides that pension entitlements and increases shall be backdated to 1 July 1981. It is interesting at this point to note the determination of the Remuneration Tribunal, which operates under parliamentary procedures, whereby increases in the salaries and allowances for members of parliament, senior public servants, justices and judges, also virtually takes effect immediately. In the case of the determined increases of pensions, salaries and allowances for judges and their dependants the increases are payable virtually immediately and, in some cases, even backdated.

Let me contrast this almost nepotic generosity with the increases for pensioners who are subject to the administrative machinery of the Department of Social Security. In this case the pensions are adjusted to accord with movements in the consumer price index, but the actual payment of the increases lags six months behind the June and December consumer price index figures. This six month delay in the payment of social security pension increases for age and other pensioners is disgraceful when contrasted with the provisions of this Bill. There can be no excuse for such a skinflint procedure in relation to our age pensioners. It is estimated that this lag in the payment of increases will cost pensioner couples $172 in one year. This represents a saving for the Government of $90m this year at the expense of pensioners. I call on the Government to explain why this six-month delay is necessary at a time when many pensioners are finding it difficult to make both ends meet, particularly when this unreasonable delay is contrasted with the speedy payment of pension increases to judges and their dependants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the House but I just raise a matter of principle. On page 3, clause 7 (2) the Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill 1981 states:

SPEECH.PARA: If a widow or widower in receipt of a pension under this section remarries, the pension ceases.

I do not have terribly strong views on this but I think this is different from some of the other legislation which we have passed. I would like the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner)-he may not be able to do so immediately-to tell me whether this sort of restriction applies to superannuation, for example, under the Public Service Act or, for that matter, for parliamentarians. I would like to see the case argued as to whether pensions should cease. I know, in my capacity as a member of the finance committee of the Australian National University Council representing this Parliament, that that question has arisen there. I have an idea that the argument there was that as far as the Public Service is concerned and, I think, as far as this Parliament is concerned, this sort of exclusion no longer applies. In other words, the widow or widower is not forced to 'live in sin' so as to qualify for the pensions. I would like the Minister to take this into consideration before the Bill goes to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will consider the matter raised by the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), discuss it with my colleague the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and provide what information I can to the honourable member. As to the substance of the Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen) has not criticised any part of the Bill except that which would provide for a retiring judge, who cannot qualify for a full pension on the 10-year qualifying period basis, a pro rata pension if that judge has served seven years as the Bill provides or, as is proposed by the amendment, six years.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the House to the second reading speech made on my behalf by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh). I will repeat some of it so that the matter is clear in the minds of those honourable members of the House who are in the Chamber at the present time. After referring to the present 10-year qualifying period I said that that requirement was introduced at a time when federal judges enjoyed life tenure. I then pointed out that as a result of the 1977 Constitution alteration, the retirement age of judges was compulsorily fixed at 70-that is, for Federal judges. Furthermore, in the case of Family Court of Australia judges Parliament has fixed, independently of the Constitution, 65 years as the retiring age. In my second reading speech I said:
As the Act now stands, a judge appointed at an age at which he is not able to complete 10 years service is not entitled to any pension at all when he retires on reaching retiring age.

It was known by the Government that there were some situations where, both in the Family Court and in other federal jurisdictions there were judges who would not, because of the age at which they had been appointed, reach the 10-year qualifying period. So it was considered by the Government fair that they should be entitled to a pro rata pension. That is the position in a number of States. Originally the Government thought of a qualifying period of five years and an entitlement to a pro rata pension in that event. That entitlement applies in New South Wales, Queensland and South Australia with respect to judges in those State jurisdictions.

In the end the Government fixed on a period of seven years. As was the Attorney-General's state of knowledge at the time, it was thought that that period of seven years would cover the situation of all present Federal judges both in the Family Court and in other jurisdictions. Now the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith referred to a Federal Court of Australia judge in the Australian Capital Territory and a Family Court judge. I will not name the two judges who I have been advised in both those jurisdictions, will, in fact, benefit from this Bill and the proposed seven-year qualifying period. But I point out that there is a judge in the Federal Court who was in the Australian Capital Territory jurisdiction and a Family Court judge who will benefit by the seven-year qualifying period.

It came to the attention of the Attorney-General that there was a judge in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission who could, by reason of age at the time of his appointment, only have six years on the bench and therefore would not qualify under the seven-year period proposed in this Bill. The Attorney, supported by the Government, thought that it was a matter of simple justice, no more than that, that this judge, whose name has been mentioned here, Mr Justice Marks, should be brought within this pro rata entitlement when an amendment was being made specifically to benefit other known judges in the Federal jurisdiction. I challenge anybody in this House to question the simple justice of the proposition. That is the way in which I view it, the Attorney-General views it and the Government views it. I think it is to be deeply regretted, indeed, that the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith should have spoken about this matter in the way in which he did. It is to be greatly regretted that the honourable gentleman, who is a legal practitioner himself and who knows the integrity of the legal profession, should feel that there is anything but a sense of simple justice which will cause the Government to move the amendment for the six-year period.

I am advised by my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) that no promise of the kind which the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith has spoken about was given. Certainly my colleague, in his discussions with Mr Justice Marks, said that if there was to be any changes to the pension rights of judges, then the gentleman's position would be taken into account. I would have thought that that was a perfectly honourable thing for my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs to do. If one needs any more verification than what I have said, that there was no such promise as has been said to this House, it can be gauged from the fact that the original intention of the Government was to amend the Bill by putting in a qualifying period for a pro rata pension at seven years. It was only after the position of Mr Justice Marks was drawn to the attention of the Attorney-General that the Government proposed six years. So I do feel that the tone, language and approach of the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith is to be deprecated. I might say also that the tone, language and approach of certain press reports of discussion in the joint parties room yesterday about this matter is to be deprecated. I end on the note that the amendment that I propose to move, as I and the Government see it, is a matter of simple justice for the judge concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask for leave to make an explanation about the last remark made by the Minister.
—You may speak with the indulgence of the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the debate. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) saw me and said he made no promise to the judge. I accept his word. I always do. I think he is a man of the utmost integrity. To that extent I withdraw those remarks of mine that it was a promise made. Whilst I will say a few more words during the Committee stages I want the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) to note that I raised the matter about the other two judges in early 1979. I think if there should be any deprecation it surely must be on the fact that it took until now for some Bill to be introduced to achieve results for those two judges.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Messages from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 3, line 24, omit ''7'', substitute ''6''.

There has been some discussion in the course of the second reading debate which really canvasses the reason that the Government is moving this amendment. I take my comments no further than those I have already made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated now, the Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill has no relationship to any one judge. It regularises the whole matter of judges pensions in terms of public interest and the amount of pension that is payable to a widow and children who are beneficiaries. A widow appears to receive 62 1/2 per cent of the rate of the relevant pension. If there are three children they will receive 100 per cent of the pension; so the children, in addition to the widow, get a pension. A very substantial amount of money is being given on a non-contributing basis. Whilst I now welcome the fact that, after I raised the matter in early 1979, the Government has seen fit to introduce legislation to encompass the two judges who I made representations for, it is very clear that this measure benefits one particular judge. I am wondering how far can we go in supporting the Government if we find a judge who will serve for only three or four years. We will reach the ridiculous situation of needing to have some standards. From the point of view of the Opposition, it seemed appropriate that seven years was a reasonable time. It certainly covered all the judges at that time I made representation. I accept the point that no promise was made to this particular judge. I have already withdrawn any inference that there was. In fairness to what has been said in the course of the debate, seven years is a reasonable time. It is a most substantial pension which applies, as I say, not only to a judges widow but also to his children. The Opposition sees no reason why the qualifying period should be reduced further from seven years. We oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Estimates Committee E, which examined the estimates of the Department of Industrial Relations, met on 8 September. Of course, it was those proceedings which gave rise to the subsequent censure motion in this House of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner). In speaking to the report of the Committee at this stage, I draw the attention of the house to the very disturbing fact that we may be up for additional expenditure because of the result of another case of this Minister misleading people in the field of industrial relations, particularly in the area of the National Labour Consultative Council. On 4 December 1980 the Minister's predecessor, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), gave an indication that he was going to move a motion requesting an inquiry to be undertaken in respect of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which would lead to its simplification and make it an instrument which would be more useful in the area of industrial relations. He confirmed that to the House on 9 April this year when he indicated that Mr Richard Searby, Q.C., and Deputy President Taylor had been commissioned to undertake such an inquiry into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. On both those occasions-in December 1980 and again on 9 April 1981-the firm promise was made that the inquiry to be undertaken would be confined to technical matters.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, the predecessor of this Minister made that statement in good faith to this House on 9 April. Just one week later, on 16 April, the present Minister took over that portfolio. Just a short while later, on 27 April, there was a meeting of the National Labour Consultative Council. At that meeting on 27 April the Minister referred to the review of the Act which was to be conducted by Messrs Searby and Taylor. On Monday, 27 April the Minister specifically confirmed to that meeting of the NLCC that the inquiry would be concerned only with technical matters of simplifying and clarifying the Act and would not go into questions of policy. That was Monday, 27 April. The unequivocal and specific undertaking was given to the supreme body in the industrial relations area, the peak councils of employers and trade unions, that the inquiry by Searby and Taylor would not go to questions of policy. That is what the Minister said to the NLCC on Monday, 27 April. By the Friday of that week-1 May-the Minister was actively engaged in breaking that specific and unequivocal undertaking he had given the previous Monday to the NLCC. On that Friday he was specifically asking that the inquiry should go to matters beyond mechanical matters-that it should go in fact to questions of policy. That is confirmed in a letter which he wrote on 8 May to Mr Searby.
He wrote:
I write following the talk I had with you and with Mr Taylor on Friday afternoon last (May 1).
Amongst other things, we discussed three additional particular matters the Government would like you to examine in conjunction with your consultancy to the department.
He then listed the three matters concerned:

. . . the possible need for legislation as to: Qualifications and accountability of officials of organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act; Accelerating the process of securing stand-down orders from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or providing a right of stand-down by legislation; Complementary legislation between the Commonwealth and a State in cases of deregistration.
You were kind enough to tell me that you were willing to examine these matters alongside the work you would be doing as part of the consultancy.

There we have in writing by the Minister on 8 May confirmation that, on the Friday after the Monday on which he had given a specific and unequivocal undertaking to the national employers and trade unions that the inquiry by Searby and Taylor would be confined strictly to mechanical matters, he was breaking that undertaking.

It is interesting to see how this matter developed. On 21 May, Mr Boulton, who is the legal officer of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, met with Messrs Searby and Taylor and Mr Fogarty of the Department in the offices of the Department in Melbourne, having been informed again at that stage that the review concerned technical matters and non-policy matters. That is what he was told and on that basis he met with them on 21 May. What had been given to him to confirm that that was the nature of the inquiry was the terms of reference of the consultants. I read the terms of reference given to the ACTU after the Minister had broken his promise on Friday, 1 May. The terms of reference were:

1. To consider the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 and the conciliation and arbitration regulations and to make recommendations as to how the provisions of the Act and regulations can best be simplified and clarified.

2. Review the large number of amendments that have been made to the Act and regulations with a view to formulating proposals for their integration into a more coherent and cohesive legislative framework.

In other words, the terms of reference were completely to do with the technical matters of the Act, with no reference to any suggestion of policy. At that meeting on 21 May, therefore, Mr Boulton indicated that the ACTU would support such a review and, indeed, would advise affiliated unions to co-operate. That was the undertaking given at that point.

After Mr Boulton had given that undertaking in the discussion on 21 May, as Mr Dolan, the President of the ACTU, has since made clear publicly, the first indications of the deliberate duplicity of this Minister emerged. Mr Searby on 21 May, in conversations that he expressed to Mr Boulton to be off the record, asked whether the ACTU would consider it controversial if one of the recommendations went to the question of prohibitions on people holding union office. Of course, the legal officer of the ACTU on 21 May objected very strongly and naturally, as was his duty, reported the thrust of that discussion to officers of the ACTU. But they, on the basis that Mr Searby's comments were off the record and on the basis of the specific terms of reference which had been conveyed to them and which mentioned none of these policy matters, went ahead on the basis that the ACTU would co-operate. So it stood at that point.

It was not until 23 June when the Australian Financial Review published that letter of 8 May that there emerged for the first time to the knowledge of the ACTU and of the employers for that matter-the first time it came to the knowledge of the participants in the NLCC-the fact that there had been this deliberate duplicity and a deliberate contradiction of the unequivocal undertaking given to both the employers and the ACTU that the only matters to be considered in that inquiry by Searby and Taylor would in fact be matters of a technical kind. When that emerged on 23 June in the Australian Financial Review, the President of the ACTU, Mr Dolan, naturally got in touch immediately with the Minister. In his telex he said:

If the report in the Australian Financial Review is correct, it would appear that the Government has been less than frank in disclosing the purpose and scope of the review. In fact, it would indicate that the Government has been deceitful in its relations with the Union Movement over this matter. Needless to say, this is not an approach that will foster co-operation or understanding between the Government and the Union Movement, nor will it contribute in any postive way to the improvement of industrial relations in this country.

The Minister telexed back the following day and said: 'Well, it is all right. I have got in touch with the people who are doing this inquiry and I have told them not to go ahead'. But that letter was sent on 29 May. Why did he send the letter on 29 May saying: 'We do not want you to go ahead with this'? It was because the gaff had been blown in the conversation with Mr Boulton on 21 May. In other words, for a month from 27 April, when he had deceived the NLCC, until 29 May-his cover having been blown on 21 May by Mr Searby to Mr Boulton-he allowed that deception to go ahead. In the event, of course, when the report was made available to the NLCC, both the national employers and the ACTU expressed their total condemnation of the Minister for this misrepresentation that had taken place.

The Minister, in total contradistinction to the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr Street) and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) who have held this position before him, is not a man whose word can be trusted. He has done it now a second time. The taxpayers of this country may be up for additional expenditure because of the additional investigation that those two people were requested by the Minister to undertake on 1 May in deliberate contravention of what he told the employers. The national employers of this country and the national trade union movement of this country do not trust this Minister; nor does anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about the estimates for the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. I was a member of the Estimates Committee which considered that Department. Naturally most of its time was devoted to the Government's decision, which still stood at the time, to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme. Again I take the opportunity to congratulate the Government on reversing its Budget decision and deciding to continue the funding of CYSS. I hope that some of the recommendations that I made in this Parliament on 24 September will be given consideration when the new CYSS guidelines are introduced. I certainly hope that the review of these guidelines, which I consider to be a most important exercise, will take into account the views of the various CYSS project officers throughout Australia. In my electorate, many of the project officers have been putting a lot of time and effort into this matter because they recognise many of the deficiencies in the previous guidelines for the Community Youth Support Scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: One matter which I raised in the Committee referred to the Special Youth Employment Training Program. I think it is an excellent scheme for unemployed youth provided it is well monitored by the Department. The scheme provides a subsidy of $55 a week for 17 weeks for employers who take on and train unemployed young people aged between 15 and 24 years. The scheme is fine so long as employers do not use it as a source of cheap and expendable labour. I was advised at the Estimates Committee that there was a retention rate of about 60 per cent of youths in this scheme who were in employment 12 months after commencing participation in the scheme. That is a good record and I do not want to be negative about a scheme which is producing positive results; but I am anxious to ensure that the scheme is not abused by employers. It should not be seen by the young unemployed as a 17-week wonder. This would only reinforce negative attitudes towards employers and towards the scheme itself. I wrote to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) some months ago regarding the possible exploitation of this scheme by employers. He responded in a letter dated 29 July 1981 by saying:

Administrative guidelines have therefore been written in such a way as to minimise as much as possible any avenues that may be used by employers to exploit the program. For example, employers must lodge any vacancy in which they intend to employ a trainee with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and select from among those referred to the position by the CES.

Certainly this minimises the possibility of employers using the program as a means of obtaining a subsidy for persons they would normally employ anyway. That kind of guarantee is provided. The same letter went on to say:

In addition, before payment of the training subsidy can be approved, employers must enter into a written training agreement which specifies the duties of the position, the training to be undertaken and the award wage which is to be paid. Any default by the employer of part or all of these aspects is regarded very seriously and if not rectified will result in cessation of the payment of subsidy and/or recovery of any subsidy paid. Furthermore, defaulting employers are given a low priority for any future placements.

That also is an essential guarantee. These guarantees do not refer to the possibility of the scheme being used solely as a source of cheap and then expendable labour by employers. Most of them, I must say, have behaved responsibly towards the scheme but, of course, one does get feedback that there is perhaps a minority of employers who are not abiding by the spirit of this scheme. I hope the Department continues to monitor carefully this situation. The new extended Special Youth Employment Training Program whereby subsidies to employers are paid over a 34-week period is a very good and much improved scheme and will probably result in better employment retention rates for unemployed youths. I congratulate the Government for that initiative. In summary on this Department, I congratulate the Minister and the Government for the very high priority given in this Budget to job training and work experience programs. The 67 per cent increase in funding for youth training programs and the large increase in funding of overall job training and work experience programs represent a real and genuine concern by this Government for the unemployed in the community.

I also attended the Estimates Committee for the Department of Housing and Construction. I would like to say a few words on that. We discussed appropriations of some $980m to this Department for 1981-82. One of the biggest problems facing the average Australian at the moment is undoubtedly the difficulty he is having in meeting his home mortgage repayments. Australia traditionally has a proud record in the area of home ownership. At the Estimates Committee on 17 September the Minister for Housing and Construction stated that Australia has the highest level of home ownership in the Western world with 71.9 per cent of our relevant population either owning their own homes outright or in the process of purchasing them and 35 per cent of this population owning their own homes outright with absolutely no mortgage. Interestingly enough in response to my question at this Committee the Department has subsequently given me information which indicates that the majority of those families which own their own homes outright are those on the average weekly earnings level of income or those in the middle income brackets. I seek leave to have this question, answer and table incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned that this record could be placed in jeopardy. As I said in my speech on the Budget, the average family unit with normal family obligations of mortgage repayments, education bills, health bills and the like is having great difficulty in surviving financially given the present levels of interest rates and State and Federal charges. I think that any threat to the family unit in our society is a threat to the very future of this country. This is a matter I have pursued in this House and will continue to pursue with the Government. I simply say here that there is a great need to introduce family impact statements on a national and continuing basis involving all three levels of government because, after all, each level of government takes money out of, and puts money into, the family unit. We must know exactly and officially how families with mortgages have fared in recent years given their other obligations and the policies of each level of government in this country. Only then will the Government be in a position to target accurately the tax relief which we are told will be coming at some time in the future. Whether this is in the form of tax deductibility for home repayments and the increased interest component of these repayments or whether it is to be targeted directly through tax reductions for the family unit is a matter of judgment, but relief for the home purchasing family is imperative. Professionally prepared family impact statements should be introduced in order that the extent, the nature and the direction of financial relief for the family unit can be soundly based.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to give some bouquets to the relevant Minister for some of his recent initiatives. I congratulate the Minister and the Government for the increased commitment to the Homes Savings Grant Scheme arising from the Government's previous decision to increase substantially the maximum value limit for homes savings grants and to provide a family bonus, recognising the needs of the family unit, all of which means that expenditure on this scheme will increase from $45m in 1980-81 to $74m in 1981-82, which is an increase of 64 per cent. This does not overcome the major problems of high interest rates confronting home owners in Australia faced with record mortgage repayments; that is the responsibility perhaps of other Ministers. It does go some way towards helping those who are facing the purchase of their first home.

I would like also to congratulate the Minister and the Government for introducing the program of crisis accommodation for families. This commitment of $2m honours an election promise of the Government and it will be provided either directly to charitable organisations or indirectly through the States. On my own experience in welfare matters, I urge the Minister to press for these funds to be made available directly to voluntary, church and charitable organisations because I believe that they are better placed to identify areas of real need in society and are better placed to ensure that the administration of these funds is handled in a way which ensures that the $2m is spent on needy families rather than on expensive administrative machinery.

I would also like to congratulate the Department of Housing and Construction for being awarded the Bronze Medal this year for its contribution to the International Year of Disabled Persons. Although this Department has not committed large or massive funding to this area of need, it has provided very practical and obvious assistance for disabled people of the kind which is often overlooked in large, universal welfare programs. I am advised from the estimates of that Department that this three-year program will be continued at a reasonable level of funding in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering the report of Estimates Committee E in relation to the Department of Industrial Relations, the Department of Education, the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and the Department of Housing and Construction. I say at the outset that this debate is a farce. It is a farce in that the time a member has to make a contribution to the consideration of the Estimates is extremely limited. There was a time when an honourable member could speak in this chamber for 15 minutes on two occasions on each department. Now the departments are thrown together and there is no continuity of discussion. I will limit my contribution on housing and construction. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) has made a contribution on industrial relations and on employment and youth affairs. The Executive controls this Government and this Parliament and the Parliament has very little say. Back bench members are being restricted year after year, are being gagged and are not being allowed to express themselves in the way they should.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I will now make a contribution, limited by time constraints, on the matter of housing and construction. Next to unemployent, housing is the most serious social problem in this country. This Government clearly has set out to sabotage and completely wipe out the housing industry. It will downgrade it completely because of the financial policies it is following. The fact is that money is being drained out of the housing industry. The government is not only attacking the private sector but also the public sector. For instance, the cuts in public sector housing are so serious that if we take into consideration the last full year in which a Labor Government governed this country-that was 1974-75-we see that the amount in constant terms given to public sector housing was $789m. After interest repayments and capital repayments from the States to the Commonwealth the net amount was $573m. This year-the equivalent period-the gross amount of money is $255m and the net amount of money is $47m. That is an appalling condition. It is an enormous cutback. What is making the situation worse are the conditions in which the Government is placing private home buyers.

For instance, the situation is so bad that in Australian Business of 22 October, in a major article on housing, a table sets out the median price costs of housing in the respective capital cities. In Sydney the median price was $79,500, in Melbourne it was $45,400, in Canberra it was $52,500 and in Perth it was $42,100. The table shows that in Sydney one needs a loan of approximately 53,000 and a deposit of $26,500. With a 12.5 per cent interest rate a person would have to pay $552 a month for such a loan. We know that is an impossible dream if we look at average earnings. Average earnings at the end of the July quarter this year were $290 a week. The maximum loan a person on that income could get from a savings bank would be $29,350. That means that a person would have to repay $320 per month. Even if we did not take the median price in Sydney but took the bottom end of the market, that is approximately $50,000. So these people, if they are on average earnings, would be able to borrow $29,300. They would have to find about $21,000 deposit and then, of course, pay $320 a month for 25 years.

The situation is that 70 per cent of all workers earn less then average earnings. That means that nearly four out of every five people are excluded from owning a home in the private sector. Therefore, according to those figures I have just given in regard to public sector housing, more and more pressure is being placed on them. At present in Australia 150,000 people are homeless. One quarter of a million people live in makeshift, temporary accommodation and 80,000 families are waiting on housing commission lists in New South Wales alone. From the figures I have given, it will be seen that the situation will be aggravated so greatly that the public housing sector will be in a state of great crisis. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard that table from Australian Business of 22 October 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article in Australian Business states that the climbing birth rate and increasing immigration has led the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry to suggest that the rate of new housing would reach 150,000 dwellings per year for the rest of the decade. Building approvals for new dwellings have dropped from 120,000 to 106,000 a year. I bring to the House's attention the fact that the Indicative Planning Council, the Government's advisory body on housing for the future, says that for the next decade we need another 150,000 dwellings a year. Yet in the last six years the highest figure was 135,000 new dwellings. This year it is estimated that only about 106,000 dwellings will be built. In regard to the projections of the population of this country, Borrie said that in the middle 1970s there would be a population of about 17.5 million people, but the latest information tabled in this House by the Minister for Immigration (Mr Macphee) estimates that there will be between 19.5 million and 20 million by the turn of the century.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Government for heavens sake to start to re-examine the situtation. What it is doing by putting all its eggs into one basket of resource development is squeezing out the little people. It is transferring wealth to the big corporate sector and it is squeezing the little people, both in the private and public sectors. It is even forcing semi-government authorities to borrow to build electricity power stations to back up aluminium smelters. They are paying 15.5 per cent and 15.7 per cent in interest. How can the housing authorities, the banks or the permanent building societies compete with that interest payment level? We want a realistic policy for housing. We want a policy that will allow first home buyers to get their foot on the home ownership rung. We need to protect those people who are now paying off their homes. Because of increasing interest rates we need to protect those people who cannot meet their repayments from being forced out of their homes. We need a policy which will give the public sector housing a high priority in this country where only 4.5 per cent of all houses in Australia are owned by public sector housing. We need to see that by the end of the decade at least 10 per cent of all housing will be in the public sector.
