TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to answer the matters raised by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) because they are clear enough to answer. I think we have seen from the honourable member today the malevolence which he is prepared to bring to bear in debates in this House. I suspect that the longer the honourable gentleman is with us and the deeper his frustration grows, the more malevolence he will pour upon this side of the House. I think that comment extends beyond myself to other members on my side of politics. I think that is clear enough from the way in which the honourable gentleman has approached his role in this House. We have seen it more and more from the beginning and, as I said, I suspect that as his frustration deepens we will see even more of it in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation regarding the Searby-Taylor consultancy and the matters raised by the honourable gentleman are clear enough. That consultancy was implemented by my predecessor, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and Mr Richard Searby, Q.C., and Mr J. E. Taylor were engaged to undertake that exercise. Mr Searby is a skilled barrister. I remind the House that he has done other work for the Government, notably in the area of trade practices law, when a year or so ago amendments were made to the law to cover the situation of a garage proprietor being discriminated against by the unions and the major oil companies. The engagement of Mr Searby, Q.C., as a consultant to the Government is not a new phenomenon.

It so happened that, within the Government and within the Government parties, notably, in our party room, a member knowledgeable in and concerned with industrial matters, raised the matters referred to in my letter-not of 8 May, I might mention, but of 6 May-to Mr Searby. Those three matters were: First, the qualifications and accountability of officials of organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act; secondly, accelerating the process of securing stand-down orders from the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or providing a right of stand-down by legislation; and, thirdly, complementary legislation between the Commonwealth and a State in cases of deregistration. As is well known publicly, the last mentioned matter was raised with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) by the Premier of Western Australia some time ago. The second matter, relating to stand-downs, has been a matter of concern to employers and the Government. The first matter, relating to qualifications and accountability of officials, is one which has been raised in the Government members party room.

Upon consideration it was thought that those three matters might be ones which could be incorporated in legislation in the then current session of the Parliament. It was thought further that Mr Searby might be able to assist the Government as he had done in drafting amending legislation to the Trade Practices Act. So it was that I approached Mr Searby after the National Labour Consultative Council meeting of 27 April, as is indicated clearly enough in my letter to Mr Searby of 6 May. Indeed, I approached Mr Searby on 1 May and asked him whether he could assist the Government in the way I mentioned. The House will notice the language I used as I read part of that letter:
Amongst other things, we discussed three additional particular matters that Government would like you to examine in conjunction with your consultancy to the Department.
The three matters were then mentioned. I went on to say:

You were kind enough to tell me that you were willing to examine these matters alongside the work you would be doing as part of the consultancy. We discussed the possibility that you could formulate proposals which might be considered by the Government with a view to appropriate legislation being introduced in the current Session of Parliament. On present indications, the Session will end during the first week of June.

Those three matters had arisen within the Government subsequent to the meeting I had with the NLCC on 27 April. In those discussions Mr Searby advised me that he would consider the matter. He thought that it might be possible not to intrude into the timetable of his general consultancy on the Act in looking at those three specific matters. He said that he would advise me whether it would be possible to examine the matters within the time frame I had mentioned to him, that is, within the then current parliamentary session, in May this year, or whether it would take longer. His advice to me was that he could not do it within the then current session. He said that, if it was the Government's intention to introduce legislation, we would have to look at introducing it during the Budget session or later.

I noticed that the honourable member for Wills referred to a meeting held on 21 May. I take it that he was referring to a meeting by Mr Searby-I am not aware whether Mr Taylor was present-with the Australian Council of Trade Unions as part of the consultation process he had always intended to undertake in his review of the Act. Of course, I was not informed by Mr Searby what his precise timetable of discussions was to be. I was aware that he proposed having discussions with the ACTU and other unions, the Confederation of Australian Industry and other employer groups; indeed, with whomever he thought it advisable to hold discussions.

Early in June I was about to leave for overseas to attend the annual conference of the International Labour Organisation. In the course of reviewing what work was current in my Department, I considered the advice Mr Searby had given me about his timetable for looking at those three matters. I came to the conclusion that I should not authorise Mr Searby to proceed with the engagement concerning those three matters and I notified him of that by letter of 29 May. I informed Mr Searby that I would be leaving for overseas on Sunday, 31 May. I said:

. . . I have been considering what you have said in your letter and, in particular, the implications of including these three matters in your discussions with interest groups including peak union councils and employers. All three topics clearly go to matters of policy which would normally be raised with employers and unions through the National Labour Consultative Council. In the circumstances, I have concluded that they should not be included in your consultancy.
I have sent a copy of this letter to Mr Taylor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, will the Minister table the letter?
—The request is that the Minister table the letter. Is he prepared to do that?
—Yes, the letter can be tabled.
—It is so ordered.
—Let me read the whole of the letter. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: 29 May 1981 Dear Mr Searby,
Thank you for your letter of 13 May 1981 about the three specific topics which we had been considering for inclusion in the review of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

I shall be leaving for overseas on Sunday, 31 May and I regret that I will not be able to speak personally to you about this matter prior to then. I do hope, however, that we will be able to get together again on my return.

In the meantime, I have been considering what you have said in your letter and, in particular, the implications of including these three matters in your discussions with various interest groups including peak union councils and employers. All three topics clearly go to matters of policy which would normally be raised with employers and unions through the National Labour Consultative Council. In the circumstances, I have concluded that they should not be included in your consultancy.
I have sent a copy of this letter to Mr Taylor.
The next event-

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. As the letter which the Minister has now read can be understood only in terms of the letter of 13 May from Mr Searby, I ask that the letter of 13 May also be tabled.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have not quoted from that letter and I do not-
—You referred to it.
—It is referred to-

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I repeat my request. We have had so much experience with this Minister. In his letter of 29 May, which he has now tabled, he refers to the letter of 13 May, in which Mr Searby talks about the implications of the discussion. It is quite clear that the purport, intent and circumstances of that letter of 29 May from the Minister cannot be understood unless the letter of 13 May from Mr Searby is tabled. I repeat my request that it be tabled. If the Minister is not prepared to do so, he has something to hide.

—That does not necessarily follow, Mr Deputy Speaker. This matter goes to advice to the Government on legislative proposals concerning the Government. I do not propose to table the letter. Mr Deputy Speaker, the next event--
—Mr Deputy Speaker-
—Order! If the honourable member for Wills wishes to make the same point of order, the Minister has said that he will not table the letter. There is no future in that point of order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, we can have a try and ask the Minister to read it.
—The next event was a Press report in the Australian Financial Review of 23 June.
—When will you ever learn?
—Order! The honourable member for Wills was heard in silence.
—Yes, because I was telling the truth.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I referred to the malevolence of the honourable member beforehand. As his frustration grows so his malevolence grows deeper. I think the honourable member will appreciate that, where there is cor- respondence on matters such as this, I am not obliged to table it. On 23 June, the Australian Financial Review published a report-speaking of confidential correspondence-of a letter it dated 8 May, which is the letter I referred to as dated 6 May. That letter is set out in full in the Australian Financial Review of that date. Obviously some person chose to make that letter available. I have no idea who did it. I telephoned the president of the ACTU, Mr Cliff Dolan, that day-indeed, it may well have been before Mr Dolan's telex reached me-and I expressed to Mr Dolan my concern at the Press report in that day's Australian Financial Review. I informed Mr Dolan also that the matter to which my letter of 8 May referred had been withdrawn from Mr Searby. I pointed out to Mr Dolan that the Press report did not refer to the letter of 29 May.

SPEECH.PARA: I put out a Press statement that day. The relevant parts of that Press statement are:

The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Ian Viner, today said that the disclosure of the letter quoted in today's Australian Financial Review is a good example of a malicious act taken without knowledge of all the facts.

Mr Viner said that on 29 May he had written to the consultants, Mr Richard Searby, Q.C. and the Honourable J. E. Taylor, C.B.E. advising them he did not wish them to consider the matters referred to as part of their consultancy.
I then quoted from the letter and said:
I have advised the President of the ACTU, Mr Cliff Dolan of the true facts and reassured him that the consultants will only be examining technical aspects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
I telexed Mr Dolan that day in the following terms:

Thank you for your telex message regarding the Australian Financial Review article. I can understand your concern. The disclosure of the letter is a good example of a malicious act undertaken without knowledge of the full facts.

The Government had asked me to explore with Searby the matters mentioned in the disclosed letter. However, before I left for overseas, I wrote again to Searby advising him that the matters were not to be included in his consultancy. I said in my later letter and I quote, 'All three topics clearly go to matters of policy which would normally be raised with employers and unions through the National Labour Consultative Council.'
I will be raising these matters in the normal way at the next NLCC meeting on July 8.
I hope this clarifies the situation for you. The purpose and scope of the review is as originally stated, concerned with technical matters only.
From the conversation that I had with Mr Dolan and the Telex that I sent him, I believed-and I still believe-that he was quite satisfied as to the circumstances of the matter.

This matter was raised at the NLCC meeting on 8 July. Naturally enough the ACTU sought clarification. Clarification was given as I have explained it to this House. The ACTU, again not unnaturally, sought assurances that the review that was to be carried out by Mr Searby and Mr Taylor would be made available to the ACTU for comment before the Government took any action on it. That, of course, will be done. I think that as the House knows the facts, in a form neither twisted nor distorted as they were by the honourable member for Wills, the House will understand that what happened was a perfectly normal series of events in the ordinary course of government. Only the malevolent mind of a person such as the honourable member for Wills could distort these events in the way in which he has sought to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not take up much of the time of the House. However, there are a few matters that I wish to raise. This Government has a long record of confrontation in the industrial relations area. Since this Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) took over the portfolio in April this year, that confrontation has increased dramatically. In fact, the industrial relations record of this Government has gone from bad to catastrophic.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) got into the act in the telecommunications dispute in May of this year. Singlehandedly, for and on behalf of the Government, he nearly brought telecommunications in this country to a standstill. The Government refused to negotiate some very reasonable demands by the Telecom Australia union and the postal union. Those demands are reasonable when one considers that those bodies are well down the wages list for statutory bodies. In fact, the Queensland Electricity Commission had by far the highest paid workers. At that point they were receiving some $40 more than the Telecom workers. But the Government refused to negotiate. It then attempted to use the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to ratify an agreement. This Government uses the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission when it thinks it fit to hammer the unions, but never really for the purposes of conciliation.

I wish now to raise a few matters which were brought up in Estimates Committee E on 8 September. The Government and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) keep saying that we are in a year of restraint; yet we see that already nearly three-quarters of a million dollars is earmarked to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation. At the Estimates Committee E meeting, Mr Power had this to say:
Referring to my notes, the correct figures is $693,500.
That amount has already been earmarked to deregister the BLF. At one stage at that meeting, Mr Viner said:
It could well be beyond 30 June 1982.

Therefore, it is possible that the deregistration of the BLF would cost the people of Australia over $1m. Yet at the same time, as the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) has already said, the money allocated to pensioners, sporting clubs, and the fields of education and housing has been cut in no uncertain terms. Here we have an amount of $1m set aside. Yet the Industrial Relations Bureau has been expanded and its staff ceiling has been lifted. Last year its inspections doubled from 14,000 to 28,000. We never quite got to the bottom of that as the time of the Committee ran out before further inquiries could be made into that area. It seems to me to be a body that should have been abolished. The Prices Justification Tribunal went out of the window. But the Industrial Relations Bureau-the Government's big stick-was kept going and, in fact, has been expanded. The Trade Union Training Authority-TUTA-which is recognised from all sides as having done a wonderful job in training unionists and others in the area of industrial relations and conciliation and arbitration, has had its staff reduced. I asked the following question of Mr Heagney at the Estimates Committee:
Is the reduction in staff ceilings for TUTA likely to hamper TUTA's operation?
The answer was a fairly long one. I picked him up and said:
So it will have an effect.
The answer from Mr Heagney was:
It has that effect.

This has happened at the same time as the Government is spending $1m or more to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation. Normie Gallagher must be laughing at the expense to which this Government is going to wield the big stick. A good Liberal, Mr Searby, is being paid by the Government as an independent consultant to help with its industrial relations. Page 20 of the explanatory notes indicates that over $53,000 has gone to the consultants in more ways than one. An amount of $33,500 has been paid in consultants' fees and the other $20,000-odd is made up of travelling allowances, air fares, car hire and secretarial allowances for Mr Searby and Mr Taylor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Searby, Q.C.

—That is right, he is a Queen's Counsel. I think his last public exploit was to referee one of the rounds between the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) some months ago. At the same time he was a consultant for the Government on industrial relations matters. If this Government were fair dinkum about industrial relations it would consider conciliation more. It never does so. The Minister should be reminded that it is the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is not the other way round. It never has been. It was deliberately called the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for that specific purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has always taken the big stick to industrial relations. People are continually told that it is always the fault of the unions in dispute after dispute. Members of the Opposition have never said that the unions are always right but one surely must start to wonder whether it is the fault of the unions all the time. It is like the little boy who gets punched on the nose by 10 different kids. Is it the fault of the other 10 kids? After the first three or four occasions one begins to wonder whose fault it really is. I ask the people of Australia to consider whose fault it really is. Industrial relations in Australia are in an absolute shambles, mainly caused by the Federal Government. The Victorian Government is desperately trying to cause some trouble because it is the only way it will win the State election. It will go down the drain whenever it calls an election. Conservative governments have no idea how to bring people together through conciliation so that they can work in harmony and not in continual confrontation. Those are the few remarks I wished to make. On the one hand money is being thrown around with gay abandon when it suits the Government and on the other hand great restrictions are being brought forward in many areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to the opinion of Estimates Committee E in relation to the proposed expenditure for the Department of Education. First, in relation to the Government's decision to change from retrospective cost supplementation to a prospective allowance, the previous arrangements have been changed over in their entirety. The Government believes that this arrangement provides for all anticipated cost increases. The allowance is not an artificially scaled-down one. In fact, the methodology and level of the allowance were determined after consultation with the education commissions. The Government believes that this change will promote greater efficiency by giving education administrators greater certainty as to the level of funds available, thus enabling them to meet additional costs as they arise instead of experiencing the lags in payments inherent in the previous retrospective system.

SPEECH.PARA: In the discussion with the Committee, it was not made clear that non-government schools have been receiving a prospective allowance in their recurrent grants for cost increases since the cost supplementation arrangements were introduced. The procedure is that, before the commencement of each year, the Government announces recurrent grants at a level which includes a prospective allowance for cost increases in the first half of the year. In the second half of the year, any necessary adjustment to the prospective allowance is included in the grants for estimated cost increases in the second half of the year. The differences between the prospective allowance and actual cost increases have been minimal.

The question was also raised by the Committee as to the effect of sales tax increases, announced in the Budget, upon the cost of building materials for schools, and hence the effect on the level of capital grants for 1982. Honourable members will recall that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) clearly stated in his Budget Speech that education institutions will retain their exempt status. This means that all goods, including building materials, for educational institutions will continue to be free from sales tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also refer to the expression of opinion by Estimates Committee E which was moved by me at that Committee meeting and carried by the Committee. I am grateful to the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) for having provided us with his views on the expression of opinion, as he has just done. I add that it is a great pity that he was not able to respond at the Committee meeting in the way he did today. The expression of opinion has as much to do with the Committee's inability to get satisfactory answers to important questions as it has to the questions themselves. The Minister referred to the question of the impact that sales tax may have had on the building costs of schools. He said we should have known about that because the Treasurer (Mr Howard) mentioned in his Budget Speech that sales tax on building materials would not apply to educational institutions. If it is so obvious now it is a pity that the Minister, or at least one of his several advisers attending the Estimates Committee, could not have answered that simple question.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the questions in greater detail. I do not think that the explanation that the Minister has now provided is anything like adequate. I think that the House should, at the very least, note the expression of opinion agreed to at Estimates Committee E. First of all, I will deal with the Government's change from cost supplementation to the out turn prices basis for determining funds for education. In the past the Government at Budget time announced what it proposed to appropriate for education-schools, universities, colleges and so on-in the forthcoming period. If there were cost increases during that period the Government would provide later special appropriations to take account of those increases, the net result of which was that the educational institutions were compensated for them and did not themselves have to bear the brunt of inflation. In fact, the real value of the moneys appropriated in the preceding Budget was maintained. What has happened on this occasion-the Minister passed over it lightly as though it were a fairly trivial change-is that the Government is making prospective estimates of what the cost rises will be in the forthcoming period and building them in to the appropriations in this Budget. Now that might be all very well if the Government had a perfectly reliable crystal ball and could accurately determine what the cost increases were going to be in the forthcoming period. It is quite clear from my calculations that the Government has not accurately predicted what the changes in costs will be and, in fact, the estimates it has made do not even agree with the estimates in the Budget itself.

The first point is that the amounts provided for universities, colleges and schools were first announced in June. It was in June that the estimates were made in relation to cost increases during 1982. Of course, what has happened, between June and August is that circumstances have changed and the estimates by the Government itself have changed also. Let me say that it is not easy to work out what estimate the Government was using in June. It is a very great pity that the Government has not come clean and tabled the basis of that calculation so that we know the actual basis on which it was made. From the information that is publicly available to us it is apparent that the Government was using a figure of about 9.2 per cent for the estimated cost increases during 1982, and that is what it built in to the grants which it subsequently made available in the Budget.

However, in the Budget statements the estimate for cost increases in 1982 is, in fact, 10.75 per cent, that is, an estimate of 1.55 per cent more than the estimate in June. The problem is that the Government did not then increase the amounts which it had determined would be available back in June. To that extent it is already clear that schools, universities and colleges throughout Australia will be shortchanged by the Government as a result of this apparently trivial change from cost supplementation to this prospective estimate of cost increases built into the grants. What that means in dollar terms is that universities and colleges throughout Australia will be shortchanged by an amount of $23.6m and schools throughout Australia will be shortchanged by an amount of $14.3m a year. What this really represent is a sort of sleight-of-hand, a sort of devious attempt to reduce further the amounts of money which the Government is making available to education; that is, the shortchanging comes on top of the quite deliberate, quite specific funding cuts which the Government is determined to make.

As I said, as an absolute minimum the Government ought to make available to the Parliament the basis on which those calculations were made back in June so that everyone can be clear about the extent to which those calculations are out. Ideally the Government ought to abandon this scheme and return to the much fairer system of cost supplementation. The Minister said just a few moments ago that this is a better method because it provides for greater certainty in relation to the funds available to the educational institutions. What he really means in saying that is that the institutions are now faced with a certain poverty rather than delayed security in terms of the amount of money which they will get.

The Government said also back in June that one of the reasons for this change is that it will force the educational institutions to be far more responsible in dealing with cost increases and they can apparently resist those cost increases. That, quite frankly, is nonsense. Eighty per cent of the cost of running most educational institutions is by way of salaries and wages. There is really no way in which universities, colleges or schools can resist those increases in wages. All the wage and salary levels are set by independent arbitral bodies of one kind or another. Of course, the salaries in universities and colleges are set by the Academic Salaries Tribunal, which is a body established by the Commonwealth. There is really no way in which the universities and colleges can resist these cost increases; they are increases over which those institutions have no control at all. I have had the Parliamentary Library prepare a document and I have asked the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), who is at the table, for leave to have it incoporated in Hansard. I now formally seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I really want to say in this regard is that this will have very serious consequences if, as I suggest, the estimates of the Government are substantially out. Whilst the Schools Commission regrettably seems to take this change on its face value and makes no comment about the impact of this change, the Tertiary Education Commission at least draws attention to the problem inherent in the change. I will not read all that the Commission says in relation to funding cuts for the forthcoming period. Having referred to those cuts, the Commission says in referring to the fact that there is something like $54m less than the Commission recommended available for expenditure on universities and colleges and the technical and further education sector:

SPEECH.PARA: The consequences of this reduction in funding will be even more serious if the prospective allowance for cost supplementation falls short of actual cost increases.
So much for the Minister's suggestion that the commissions have, in fact, concurred in their estimates. Quite clearly, the Tertiary Education Commission has some doubts about it.

In relation to building costs, I accept now what the Minister has belatedly discovered, that educational institutions will not be liable directly to pay for these new sales taxes or sales tax increases. I put it to the Minister that there is absolutely no question that the imposition of sales tax on building materials will flow through to building costs, especially with small projects. It will be quite impossible and, I think, quite unrealistic to expect that builders involved in contracts for building schools and so on will have the time to make claims for exemptions in relation to what might be individually quite small amounts of sales tax. What they will do is make some guess about what the impact will be on their total costs. They will build those costs into the costs of their contracts. I think that the Government should have taken much more account of the impact of these new sales taxes on building costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr N. A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a few brief remarks in response to the contribution made by the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean) in which he directed his comments to the estimates of the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs. The honourable member referred to the review of the guidelines of the Community Youth Support Scheme. He expressed the view that the opinions of project officers in this scheme should be taken into account. The answer to the query is yes, indeed, the views of project officers in the scheme will be taken into account. Indeed, I go further than that and say that the Government would welcome those views and would hope that they would be expressed by project officers. Not only will the views of project officers be welcome and taken into account but also the views of committee members of the local committees which have the day to day responsibility of running this scheme will be welcome and taken into account. Indeed, the Government's concern goes even further than that. The Government is concerned to get from interested community groups also views on the scheme and on reforms that should be made to the scheme, and in particular on changes, if any, which it is desirable to make to the guidelines under which this scheme operates.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to take the time of the House unduly, but I refer to a Press release, which was issued today by me, which sets out more of the details of the consultation process in which the Government will engage with community interests in the course of determining the future guidelines for the conduct of the scheme. Naturally, I do not wish to read out the whole of this statement, but I draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that the statement has been issued and, with good grace, it might even get some coverage in the newspapers so honourable members will be able, I hope, to read more details of it there. In any event, steps have been taken to bring to the attention of honourable members the Press release which was issued today. The Press release makes it plain that the Government has established within my Department a task force which will have the immediate responsibility of conducting the consultation process.

The task force will be conducting consultations. It will also be receiving submissions from community interests with respect to the changes which community interests suggest are desirable to be made to the scheme and changes, if any, which it is suggested should be made to the guidelines under which the scheme should be conducted. Furthermore, this week letters will be sent to community interests throughout Australia inviting them to make written submissions to the task force. Some of those letters have, in fact, already been sent. Many more are in the course of being sent now, particularly, but not exclusively, to those community interests and community representatives who made submissions and representations to the Government after the Budget decision with respect to this scheme was announced. So, those invitations have been sent to community interests. I urge all community interests who are concerned with this scheme and, indeed, concerned with the whole field of youth unemployment to respond to the Government's very genuine invitation that they should make submissions to the task force. Indeed, I hope that they do.

A further attempt will be made to bring this consultation process to the notice of a wider public by means of advertisements which will shortly appear in the newspapers. Those advertisements will invite community interests and individuals to make submissions to the task force. Once again, may I emphasise that the Government hopes that interested individuals and community organisations will accept that invitation and will, indeed, make their submissions. There will, of course, also be a consultation process in terms of discussion and interviews with individuals and with organisations. Indeed, I have done some of this already. I hope that I will be able to continue to do so.

I emphasise that the Government wants a full consultation. I make the point finally with respect to CYSS that that, of course, requires some reciprocity from those who are interested in this scheme, concerned about it and concerned about the young unemployed. I hope, therefore, that people concerned will apply themselves and will make a special effort to prepare submissions and put them into the task force so that the Government can have the benefit and the advantage of their deliberations and their suggestions.

The honourable member for Perth also referred to the Special Youth Employment Training Program, under which, by means of subsidies to employers, certain categories of young unemployed people are able to obtain practical work experience. This scheme has been successful. The scheme has, as a result of its operation, been able to give to many young unemployed people the work experience which they need so much and which is subsequently of very great value to them in obtaining employment and keeping it. The honourable member for Perth expressed the concern that that scheme, the Special Youth Employment Training Program, should not be used by employers as a source of cheap and expendable labour. The Government shares that concern. Not only does the Government share that concern, but also it is determined that any attempt to abuse the scheme will be brought, very smartly, to a halt. That has been the Government's practice through the agency of the Commonwealth Employment Service and it will remain the Government's policy and the Government's practice.

The Government, therefore, agrees with the comments made by the honourable member for Perth that a special effort should be made to ensure that employers do not abuse the program. In those cases where it has come to the notice of the Commonwealth Employment Service that an attempt might have been made by an employer to abuse the scheme, those allegations have been thoroughly investigated. On those occasions where it appears that there has been such an attempt made, the employers have found, as similar employers will find in the future, that they will not have referred to them by the Commonwealth Employment Service any young unemployed people under that scheme. Such employers will not receive, as they do not deserve to receive, subsidies under that scheme. The Government, therefore, shares the concern of the honourable member for Perth about that matter. It will use its very best endeavours to ensure that that concern is continued to be put into practice.

Finally, with respect to that scheme and with respect to other schemes, some further material has been put into the Table Office of the House in response to some queries put by honourable members during the hearings of the Estimates Committee. I refer only to one part of that material, although an important part, because it relates to the subject that I have just been discussing, and that is, that the Bureau of Labour Market Research, which is a body under my Department and which, as the name implies, engages in labour market research. It is undertaking a 'comparative study of national manpower programs which cater for youth' including an analysis of the characteristics of young people placed in the main youth programs in 1980-81. I am sure that honourable members will agree that that will be a worthwhile inquiry and will result in the Government's obtaining a quantity of very valuable information touching on the sort of problem which has been raised by the honourable member for Perth and, indeed, on the operations of the Government's manpower programs as they affect and cater for young people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a couple of items on the expenditure of the Department of Education, some of which I raised in the course of the Estimates Committee hearings and a couple which have come to my attention since. Firstly, I want to deal with a matter which I did raise in the Estimates Committee on the question of payments to the States for the School to Work Transition Program and specifically, a small item of expenditure under that-the Education Program for Unemployed Youth. When one looks at the statistics for this program one sees what would appear to be substantial discrimination against Western Australia. I saw it in the Estimates Committee. I have sought since to discern which of the governments is responsible for the relative lack of generosity in this program to Western Australia. I think, in the course of my investigations, I have come to the conclusion that this is yet another, albeit a fairly small, but nevertheless significant, failure on the part of the Court Government to properly protect Western Australian interests as a result of its obsessive ideological position which causes it to try to get as little money as possible from the Commonwealth Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Estimates Committee the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) revealed that under EPUY, $945,000 went to New South Wales, $918,000 to Victoria, $898,000 to Queensland, $878,000 to South Australia, $354,000 to Tasmania and $124,000 to Western Australia. We just managed to beat the Northern Territory which received $77,000. In population terms that bears no comparison. This is an extraordinarily low figure for Western Australia. When I sought advice as to why this should be the case, I was told that when EPUY was introduced in 1979 the Western Australian Government informed the Commonwealth Government that it lacked interest in the offer as it felt that it was dealing with the question successfully through its own programs. I sought to obtain from the Department what programs the Western Australian Government felt were so superior to anything else going on around the place that it could afford to do Western Australians out of a Commonwealth handout. The Department came back with the answer that in 1979 the Western Australian Government, in secondary schools, was offering pre-vocational options for secondary children with pre-vocational centres, provision of guidance and counselling officers in Western Australian schools, the provision of youth education officers and alternative courses for year 11 students not suited to academic courses.

In the technical and further education sector there were pre-apprenticeship courses and certificate of admission studies courses to upgrade school standards for those who did not have entry requirements for TAFE. If one looked around any education system anywhere in the Commonwealth, one would have found those programs or ones very similar to them operating. Yet they were put forward by the Western Australian Government as its reason for not encouraging the Commonwealth to provide it with a similar sort of grant to that which was being received by other States. One would also find, as one went through them, that some of those particular projects do not have as their main focus providing jobs for young students or encouraging them in the direction of vocational studies that will enable them to obtain employment. So what has been put up on behalf of the Western Australian Government is clearly a facade to conceal the very grave inadequacies that exist within its decision making processes. The Minister, when it all boils down, was compelled to admit, after subsequent questioning, the following:

As I indicated to you, the West Australian Government did in fact have transition programs in place, at the time of the commencement of the Commonwealth's transition program. That does not apply only to Western Australia. I am not sure whether it was all States but certainly, a number of States, had a vareity of programs running at the time the decision was taken by the Commonwealth in 1979.
Having been advised by an officer who sat near him at the time, he concluded:
I am advised it was all States.

So we have a situation where the Western Australian Government has once again failed to defend Western Australian interests. It is not the first time that the Western Australian Government has done this. It is perhaps one of the more blatant examples of the Western Australian Government becoming obsessed with right-wing ideology. It really is the only State government genuinely obsessed with the principles of new federalism. As far as the Ministers in the Western Australian Government are concerned, this ideological obsession, they believe, seems to impose upon them the obligation to go very easy when it comes to dealing with offers of assistance by the Commonwealth Government. They feel there is a loss of dignity on the part of Western Australians in accepting them. When the question of Federal-State financial relations has come to apply to things such as the operations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission and the determination of formulas under which grants will be made to Western Australia, then this ideological failure represented in these appallingly poor statistics of Western Australia comes well and truly to the fore. Our State has lost some hundreds of millions of dollars. I think that the Western Australian population is extremely poorly served by this Government. The only thing that I really appreciate about this Estimates Committee report is that it has provided members on this side of the House with the detail to present to the Western Australian Government and encourage it in the future to make some effort, on behalf of the Western Australian population, to secure its just desserts.

I proceed to look at a couple of items on assistance to students. One particular item stands out because it was the only area in which an increase in a degree of assistance to a large number of students was made. That was in the small and quite parsimonious increases to post-graduate students. I am in the process of checking this matter out. But from what I can see of the statistics my suspicion is probably correct. I am advised by a number of post-graduate students that, in fact, all that the increase has done-an increase which comes to about $8 a fortnight-is take the students over the allowable limit for free receipt of Commonwealth health benefits. So what that increase has done has put the average post-graduate student in a position where he on the one hand has that increase but on the other hand has to pay out at least for hospital insurance under the current health benefits arrangements. That is a stirring example of government generosity on that matter!

These estimates also contain the Government's first assessment on what it is likely to receive from its decision to charge fees for second degrees and other post-graduate tertiary qualifications. Its estimate is that in half a year it will be $4m and in a full year $8m. That estimate is based on the assumption that the normal amount of enrolment will take place in subsequent years to that which is the norm to this point. I think that that is a very shaky estimate indeed, a very optimistic estimate that will not be confirmed by experience. What will take place is that large numbers of students who would have entered universities and who sought an opportunity to provide themselves with qualifications to become useful participants in the work force are now going to be denied that opportunity. I have special knowledge of this matter because I taught, until last year, at a university which took a large number of students who were in precisely this sort of situation. In particular, I refer to women in their 30s who are attempting to re-enter the work force. They will be gravely discriminated against by this Government decision. They will find it extraordinarily hard to obtain the qualifications they need to work. They will be obliged, in many cases, to rely much longer, for example, on supporting mothers benefits than would otherwise have been the case. So this is going to be, at that level and at the level of the cost of the collection of these charges, an example of false economy-a false economy with which this Budget as a whole and the education expenditure in it is replete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will say a few words about the estimates of the Department of Education which were dealt with by Estimates Committee E because this Government is constantly telling us about the wonderful future which faces Australia, due no doubt to the inspired economic policy followed in recent years. But I would have thought that a booming education system would go hand in hand with a booming economy. The Government must see things differently. The continued squeeze on Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme entitlements, the reintroduction of tertiary fees and the forced closures of colleges of advanced education can only serve to drive more prospective students out of the education system.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak specifically about the amalgamation of the 30 colleges. Although the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) may try to tell us that this was recommended by the Tertiary Education Commission, I want it recorded that the Commission has been advocating a re-direction of effort away from teacher education and has advised that the amalgamation of some colleges can assist in this process. It has also recommended that colleges involved should have three years in which to adjust to the merger. It has never recommended the forced amalgamation of 30 colleges within such a short space of time.

If the Commonwealth Government is insistent that Melbourne State College should enter an amalgamation for the sake of amalgamation, the College has shown that it is prepared to continue discussions that it has been having with other institutions to find an appropriate amalgamation, which has a sound academic basis and which provides educational and other benefits. But calculations show that if the only staff appointed in 1982, 1983 and 1984 are those who currently have permanent appointments or who have tenure through 1982, 1983 and 1984 respectively, and if the allowances proposed by the Voluntary Youth Program sector to meet the special needs of colleges and to reduce teacher education enrolments are not taken into account, then the College will have deficits of the order of $2m in 1982, a further $3m in 1983 and an additional $3.8m in 1984. As the College has always taken a responsible attitude to employment of staff, particularly since information about teacher education reductions became available, the problem is not of its own making. The Commonwealth Government funding levels have been exacerbated by VYPSEC policies on enrolment allocations. Government assistance in finding solutions is essential. The financial problem forced on the Melbourne State College has affected amalgamation discussions and will substantially affect any further such discussions. No institution will wish to inherit a financial problem of the magnitude of this one. More importantly to the taxpayer, amalgamation does not provide a solution.

I also re-urge the Minister for Education, as I have done on other occasions, to reverse the decision to ask the Institute of Early Childhood Development to amalgamate with any other Victorian college. Australia should be willing to learn from the experience of overseas amalgamations. I suggest that there is overwhelming evidence from Britain and the United States of America to show that amalgamations in the field of early childhood development just do not work. The disappearance of specialist early childhood colleges and institutes in Britain, due to amalgamations and cut-backs, resulted in a loss of quality in early childhood courses. It did not result in any savings for the Government.

Australia has only one specialist centre for early childhood studies-the Institute of Early Childhood Development. The Institute is recognised throughout the world as a centre of excellence in the quality of its graduates and its capacity to undertake special studies related to early childhood development. I urge the Minister to reverse this decision. There will be no savings for the country in the amalgamation. If we do not reverse the decision, we will probably have to re-establish-as Britain is doing-and to rebuild the Institute in years to come. As in Britain, this will prove to be a difficult and costly exercise. We keep getting told that these amalgamations are going to save money. On page 201 of Hansard of Estimates Committee E, for almost a whole page, the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) questioned the Minister for Education about how much money we were going to save. I might say that the Minister for Education avoided answering pretty carefully for almost a page, but at the bottom, for some odd reason, the Minister said:
I cannot give you the figure now but I will be able to do so within the next 10 days or a fortnight.

How can he? According to his own words reported on the next page, there are still eight colleges which have not amalgamated and which have no amalgamation proposals before them. Although he is reported as saying on page 201 that there will be 650 fewer staff positions, we do not know which ones are going and so we do not know how much it is going to cost. From where is the Minister going to pluck this figure within the next 10 days or a fortnight? Further, the honourable member for Fremantle went on questioning him. He is reported on the top of page 201 as asking:

Do you imagine that a large part of the savings will be related to staff reductions, and, if so, who will pay the cost of shedding, say, tenured staff, where there are contractural obligations between the colleges and the staff?
The Minister for Education answered:

Obviously a high percentage of the cost of running the institutions is directly attributable to staff costs and there will be some savings in that area. The Commonwealth will expect the institutions and, where appropriate, the State authorities, to meet those costs.

Already the States have had tremendous cut-backs in their grants for primary, secondary and tertiary education. Where will Victoria find the money to pay off $2m for Melbourne State College alone for one year? I suggest to the Minister that the amalgamations were a mistake. He could put his pride or his prejudice aside and reverse a decision which has been not only unpopular but which will also reverse our education trends for the future and take us into a highly technological age without the expertise to meet it. It is no problem to admit that one has made a mistake; everyone can make them. It is only those with courage who can admit that they have made mistakes. I believe this is a mistake, particularly with regard to Melbourne State College and early childhood development.

There are some other questions that I think the Minister has to answer. I will set them out here. Firstly, why was there a deadline of 17 August set for the amalgamation proposals when the Tertiary Education Commission suggested that arrangements be made over three years? I point out here that successful amalgamations elsewhere in Australia and overseas have been voluntary and taken up to five years to complete successfully. Secondly, if the Government insists that amalgamations are going to produce savings, why has it not produced costings of its proposals? I have pointed out that the honourable member for Fremantle tried hard to get an answer from the Minister for Education but did not do very well. Thirdly, why has the Government not indicated how access to tertiary education and the quality of tertiary education will improve when these amalgamations are completed when all the evidence points to the reverse? Fourthly, why has the Government ignored the selective impact of the cuts on women students and employees? I agree with the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) that the effects on women students will be very great, particularly on the mature age students struggling to get a second qualification, having been out of the work force for some years, perhaps living on a widow's pension, wanting desperately to get back into the work force and not having the money to pay the fees that are proposed. Lastly, and importantly: Why has there been virtually no consultation with the colleges, councils, staff and students-those who are going to be most affected by the cuts-over the amalgamation proposals?

I still say to the Minister for Education: It is never too late to reverse. It is never too late to say: 'I have made a mistake in these areas. We will go backwards'. The Minister reversed the decision with regard to the Institute of Catholic Education. It was highly predictable that he would do so because there was in Victoria no other institution with which the Institute of Catholic Education could amalgamate. As one who has been closely associated with the nine State colleges in Victoria over a long period, I tell the Minister now that there is nowhere with which the Institute of Early Childhood Development can successfully amalgamate and continue to be a centre of excellence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to direct my remarks to the report of Estimates Committee E in relation to the departments of Employment and Youth Affairs and Housing and Construction. The hearing of Estimates Committee E on the proposed expenditure for the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs was held on 15 September prior to the decision of the Government, taken on 24 September, to continue funding of Community Youth Support Scheme projects until 28 February 1982 and, after consultation with various interested organisations, to continue CYSS under new guidelines after 28 February 1982. That consultation was a matter of grave worry to many people because the significance of it was such that, unless the consultation took place, there was no way known that the new guidelines would have worked. I had intended to deal with that matter but I was very pleased to hear the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) announce a short time ago that the process had started to allow the consultation to take place. It is obvious that that consultation has to take place because the Minister and the Government had no idea of the background and the needs of the participants in the CYSS projects. However, it now appears that fortunately the Government has realised the error there and it is hoped that the consultation will cause to come into effect guidelines which will allow CYSS projects to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: However, today in this Parliament in answer to a question the saga of confusion on the issue of the CYSS projects continued. The current funding does not take into account increased expenses such as wage increases. This was indicated today by the Minister in answer to a question. It seems that the Minister is of the view that such wages are determined by local committees. The fact is that such committees are obliged to employ project officers pursuant to awards. The funding of the projects is a Commonwealth Government responsibility through the State committees, and it is absurd to suggest that the current funding will not take account of such increased items of expenditure as wage increases. The Government must be prepared to take the responsibility in this regard, and the answer from the Minister today was most disturbing. Does the Government expect local committees to go to the community pleading for money to pay wages? Despite the fact that the consultation referred to by the Minister has taken place, I think it imperative that the Government at this stage direct its attention to the question of current funding. What does it mean by 'current funding'? If that current funding is not going to cover increases in expenses between now and 28 February we have not made the advances we had hoped we had made in the Community Youth Support Scheme.

I now wish to turn to the expenditure of the Department of Housing and Construction. I would like to examine particularly the issue of home ownership. That is a matter we hear a lot about in this Parliament, particularly from the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh), the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and various other members opposite. Despite the claims by the Government on this issue, the rate of home ownership has decreased. This was, in fact, admitted by the Minister at the meeting of Estimates Committee E. This trend will continue unless this Government dramatically changes direction. Increased interest rates, together with a lack of funds, will guarantee that fewer Australian people will be able to purchase a home. Repayments on a 25-year bank loan of $30,000 have risen by at least 57 per cent in the past 11 years. The repayments on a building society loan of the same amount over that period have increased by at least 69 per cent. The value of loan approvals of banks grew by 5.2 per cent in 1980-81, of building societies by 2 per cent and of finance companies by a staggering 44 per cent. The increase in the value of loan approvals of finance companies has arisen to a large degree because so many people are now forced to borrow on second mortgages at exorbitant interest rates. The record of this Government in both the public and the private sectors of housing has been disgraceful. Unless the Government is prepared to fund adequately in particular the public sector of housing, the waiting lists will grow and grow in all the States.

On present figures the housing position in Victoria is absolutely desperate. It is not good enough for honourable members opposite, particularly for Ministers, to come into this House and talk repeatedly about the record home ownership in this country. That is a matter which relates only to the past. Given the problems arising with repayments at the moment and the lack of funds available, whatever claims the Government may have been able to make in the past in relation to home ownership will not continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to some matters which arose during the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Education, specifically to the areas of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, fees and student loans. It was pointed out at the meeting of Estimates Committee E that, while the number of enrolments at tertiary institutions is increasing, the number of students receiving the TEAS allowance is decreasing. The honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) pointed out during the meeting that it is estimated that over the period from 1980 to 1982 enrolments in tertiary institutions will increase by about 4,000, whereas the number receiving the TEAS allowance will decrease by about 5,000. The reason for this, on the admission of the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), is that the Government has failed to adjust the conditions of qualification for TEAS, the marginally adjusted family income, in line with movements in average weekly earnings and, consequently, year after year more and more students are being cut off from assistance. In some years, in fact, this condition of qualification has not been adjusted at all. For 1982 it has been increased by 7 per cent, but that figure has to be evaluated against the background of wage and salary movements of about 14 per cent in the same period.

SPEECH.PARA: The solution which the Government offers to bridge the gap is the loans scheme. There is a very real possibility that this loans scheme will not be ready for 1982. When questioned on this matter the Minister said that he hoped it would be ready, but he admitted that the Government had not yet determined the criteria. There has been no determination as yet as to who will be eligible, what interest rates will be charged and what the mechanism for repayment of student loans will be. All these matters have not yet been determined by the Government. The Minister said that he was hoping that the scheme would be ready for next year. If it is not, he said that there will be no review of the TEAS level. So we can anticipate a further increase in student poverty and a further restriction of access to tertiary education.

It is estimated that the re-introduction of fees for second and higher degrees will raise $4m in the current financial year. A couple of things need to be said on the fees question. The first one has been said many times, but it needs to be said often; that is, that the re-introduction of fees for second and higher degrees is a clear breach of the pre-election undertaking given by the Minister in September of last year. The Minister said:

I have given an assurance both publicly and privately to a number of representative groups, and I repeat that assurance, that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible re-introduction of tertiary fees.

There is no fine print there. There is no reference to second and higher degrees. It was a blanket assurance on fees and that assurance, like so many pre-election promises of this Government, has been broken. The second point that needs to be made about the re-introduction of fees in tertiary institutions is that Australia already has a very low tertiary education participation rate compared with other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. The re-introduction of fees certainly will not improve the participation rate. There is no doubt, in fact, that it will discourage people from taking courses in second and higher degrees. I must add that the Minister does not necessarily agree. At the Estimates Committee meeting he said:
We do not anticipate that-
That is, the drop-off-
but no one could be absolutely certain.

I think that we can be reasonably certain that numbers will fall. A survey was completed recently on the likely student response to the re-introduction of tertiary fees. It was a very thorough survey and covered over 2,800 students in four tertiary institutions in Sydney. It reached these conclusions:

The results have shown that significant numbers of students in need received no assistance from the Commonwealth, and that large numbers of students, both those in receipt of TEAS allowances and those not, are living well below the Henderson Poverty Line. . . .
From the results of this survey and others conducted in 1980-81, there is a strong indication that the reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees would have an enormous effect on enrolments.

Admittedly the survey figures are based on the question of the re-introduction of fees for all courses, not just second and higher degrees; but the response from the various institutions suggests that about half the students currently following courses would defer them or not enrol again with the introduction of a fee of around $1,000 a year. I think it is a good guide. It is strong evidence to support the contention of the shadow Minister for Education, the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), that there will be a drop of around 40 per cent. The survey also indicated that fees would have a serious effect on those groups already discriminated against in terms of access to higher education. We are talking here about the enrolment of women, people of mature ages, part-time students and students from low income families. All these enrolments could be expected to decline significantly. The effect of such a move on any efforts to equalise opportunity in higher education would be extremely damaging, as would the effect on industry in this country. Industry is seeking people with increasingly higher qualifications. If we do not train them here we will simply have to import them to compete in a world market with people with higher qualifications. One can be certain that industry in this country will also suffer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Queensland Grant (Special Assistance) Bill is to authorise the payment to Queensland of $58.5m in 1981-82 as special grants in respect of 1979-80 and 1980-81. The payment of this amount is in accordance with the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission contained in its forty-eighth report 1981 on special assistance for states, which was tabled on 23 September 1981. Successive Commonwealth governments, from time to time, on the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission following applications by States, have provided special financial assistance to the less populous States to compensate them for such factors as lower capacity to raise revenue and higher costs of providing government services of a standard comparable to those provided by the financially stronger States.

Since self-government, the Northern Territory has also had access to the Commonwealth Grants Commission on the same basis as a claimant State. The Grants Commission has recommended a special grant of $3.3m for the Northern Territory in 1981-82. However, by virtue of phase-in provisions included in the memorandum of understanding in respect of financial arrangements agreed between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory governments, the Territory will receive an additional assistance grant of $20m in 1981-82 in lieu of the special grant. Provision for the additional assistance grant to the Northern Territory is made in Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1981-82. When special grants were first paid they constituted the only regular form of general revenue assistance to the less populous States for this purpose. However, for many years now, the main way in which special compensatory assistance has been provided to these States has been through the payment of higher per capita amounts of other general revenue funds. This situation is reflected today in the fact that tax sharing grants paid to Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania are higher, in per capita terms, than similar grants paid to New South Wales and Victoria. Special grants are made available to supplement a State's tax sharing grants.

The overall distribution of general revenue assistance to the States is currently undergoing a fundamental re-assessment. The Grants Commission is itself closely involved in this exercise. Arising from consideration by the Commonwealth and the States of its report on State tax sharing entitlements 1981, the Commission will be asked to review its report and in so doing to take into account a number of matters including those that will be raised by the Commonwealth and the States. As an interim arrangement in 1981-82, the Commonwealth has provided additional general revenue grants to New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland in recognition of the likelihood that, following the further review, relativities could be adjusted in favour of these States.

Clearly the role of special grants in the future will need to be determined in the context of the re-assessment of the distribution of general revenue funds. The interim funding arrangement for 1981-82 has therefore been adopted on the basis that there will be no applications by any State for special grants in respect of this financial year. As I mentioned earlier, the special grants which are the subject of this Bill are in respect of the years 1979-80 and 1980-81. Queensland has been the only claimant State in recent years. It has applied for and received special assistance in each year since 1971-72.

The practice of the Grants Commission, in arriving at its recommendations in relation to State claims for special assistance, has been to make an assessment in the financial needs of a claimant State. In making such assessments, the Commission compares in detail the finances of the claimant State with those of the standard States-the Commission has regarded New South Wales and Victoria as standard States for special grants purposes since 1959-60. Normally, special grants recommended by the Commission have consisted of two parts. One part is based on a preliminary assessment of the financial need of the claimant State usually in the financial year concerned, and is an advance payment subject to adjustment usually two years later when the Commission has compared in detail the finances of the claimant State and standard States for that year. The other part of the special grant represents the final adjustment to the advance payment made earlier and is known as the completion payment. This adjustment might be positive or negative and therefore might result in the final grant in respect of the year being higher or lower than the advance payment for that year.

The payment to Queensland in 1981-82 of $58.5m provided for by this Bill consists of a completion payment of $33.5m in respect of 1979-80 and an advance payment of $25m in respect of 1980-81. The completion payment in respect of 1979-80, when added to the $11m advance grant paid to Queensland in that year, brings the final grant in respect of 1979-80 to $44.5m, that is, $21.8m above the corresponding figure for 1978-79.

The advance payment in respect of 1980-81 normally would have been provided during that financial year. However, Queensland requested an advance grant only towards the end of that financial year, after the Commission's methodology for its review of tax sharing relativities and the processes surrounding the review became known. A completion payment in respect of 1980-81 will be assessed by the Commission in 1982-83. The Commission's recommendations in relations to the special grants arrangements have been adopted by the Parliament since the Commission's inception and the Government considers that they should be accepted on this occasion. I commend the Bill to the house.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The provisions of the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill (No. 2) before the House embody the results of a very thorough re-examination of the Census and Statistics Act, much of which stands as it was drafted in 1905. Successive amendments over the years have resulted in a patchwork of provisions which badly need pulling together. I invite the attention of the House to the following aspects of the Bill.

Preservation of the confidentiality of information provided to the Australian Bureau of Statistics is regarded by the Government as of the utmost importance. Moreover, it is central to the relationship of confidence and trust that exists between the Bureau and those businesses and households which are asked to provide information for statistical purposes. Therefore section 19 would make it an offence for the Statistician or an officer, present or past, to divulge or communicate information furnished in pursuance of the Act, except to the person from whom the information was obtained. Section 12 would ensure that statistics issued by the Statistician shall not be likely to enable the identification of information relating to a particular person or organisation.

It has, however, emerged from the re-examination to which I referred earlier that literal adherence in all circumstances to those provisions is regarded by respondents to statistical collections as unnecesary and would in a number of respects curtail severely the statistical service which the Statistician can provide. For example, many businesses make publicly available figures on their monthly or annual production, as well as providing them to the Statistician. If they are the sole, or by far the largest, producer of a particular commodity in a particular area, release by the Statistician of producton statistics in the desired detail would show a figure which would be identifiable as necessarily relating to, or as a close approximation of, the production of that business. The Act ought to provide a mechanism authorising the Statistician to publish such figures collected under the Act, with the consent of the business involved.

Some information of this nature relating to businesses or government bodies is in fact currently released by the Statistician and the Government has taken the view that the precise categories of such releases and the safeguards by which they are accompanied should be spelled out. Because the intention is that there should be no weakening of the general principle of confidentiality of information provided to the Statistician, information which the Statistician is to be authorised to release needs to be specified in considerable detail. That degree of detail would be inappropriate in legislation.

Section 13 would therefore provide that the Minister may, by means of a written determination, authorise the Statistician to release information of a specific kind under specific conditions. It should be noted that no determination may authorise the release of information of a personal or domestic nature in a manner that is likely to enable the identification of any person. It is also important to note that it remains the responsibility of the Statistician, within the specific authorisations, to decide whether to release particular figures. In making those decisions he will continue to be guided by an overriding concern to maintain the confidence and trust of respondents to statistical collections. A determination made under section 13 would be tabled in the Parliament, published in the gazette and be subject to disallowance.

I turn now to the other provisions of the Bill. These do not alter the substance of the powers, functions and duties of the statistician or the method of operation of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. They retain the Minister's power to give general directions to the Australian Statistician to collect statistical information on prescribed matters. Instead of the present separate provisions for the population census and other statistical collections, the Bill substitutes one set of machinery provisions relating to both. Operational detail of the kind now included in the Act regarding the population censuses will in respect of future censuses be set out in regulations. Topics to be included in each population census will be prescribed in one regulation, rather than set out partly in the Act and partly in a regulation.

Maximum penalties incorporated in the Bill are similar to those enacted by Parliament in the autumn sittings, with the exception that the provision for imposing a sentence of imprisonment for the offence of knowingly providing false information has been omitted. Detailed explanations of the amendments are set out in the explanatory memorandum available to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the house.
