PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I remind honourable members that on 27 August 1981 I tabled in Parliament the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission on its recommendations for the calendar year 1982, which was in response to the Government's guidelines for financial assistance for schools in the States and the Northern Territory. The guidelines also included provision for some expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory for certain of the Commonwealth's specific purpose programs. Funds for these programs have been appropriated for Australian Capital Territory schools in the normal budgetary process for the 1981-82 financial year.

The Government has accepted all of the Commission's financial recommendations in its report for 1982, apart from changes in relation to the transition program which the Government itself has made following consultations with the States, the details of which I will be taking up later in this speech. The Commission's recommendations were based on the policy and financial guidelines for Commonwealth education programs issued on 4 June 1981.

The estimated overall value of the Commission's recommendations for 1982 is $1,008.1m, an increase of some 4.6 per cent in real terms over expenditure in 1981. Most programs will be at least maintained in real terms, while others will be increased. The only decreases relate to capital programs for government schools which have undergone a reduction of $6.3m in real terms, compared with a total Commonwealth expenditure on government schools of almost $400m in the Special Projects Program to reflect the discontinuance of the school-level Innovations Program and in the Capital Grants Program for non-government schools where the reduction in real terms is occasioned by the non-supplementation of the new places element. Part II of the Bill contains provision for programs in government schools. Part III deals with non-government school programs.

General recurrent grants to non-government schools have been increased in accordance with movements in the government school standard cost and also to accord with the Government's election commitment to compress the present six subsidy levels to three funding groups. Group 1, replacing Levels 1 to 3, will receive per capita rates of 20 per cent of government school standard costs. Group 2, replacing Levels 4 and 5 will receive 30 per cent and Group 3, replacing Level 6, will receive 38 per cent. Group 3 schools will receive 40 per cent of government school standard costs in 1983.

In the guidelines statement, the Government announced several changes to the procedures for assessing non-government schools' subsidies. These included changes in the ranges of expenditure from private scources and the consideration of schools' disposable income. It was also announced that the Minister will allow schools disadvantaged by the changes in expenditure ranges to remain at a higher subsidy level for up to two years until they adapt their resources to the new arrangements and that the Government will review any cases in which this is not achievable within two years.

New non-systemic schools, formerly assisted during their initial years of establishment by being categorised to Levels 6, 5, 4 and 3 in the first, second, third and fourth years of their existence respectively will, under the new arrangements, receive additional subsidies at the rate of 10 per cent, 7.5 per cent, 5 per cent and 2.5 per cent of average government school standard costs respectively in each of their first four years of operation.

General recurrent grants for government schools have been retained at their existing real levels, despite the fact that government school enrolments in 1982 are expected to continue the downward trend which became evident after 1977. In continuing to maintain this program at previous levels, the Government has in effect slightly increased the real per student allocation in government schools. Expenditure per student on recurrent resources in government schools has long since exceeded the expenditure targets set by the Karmel Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission in 1973.

In addition to direct Commonwealth expenditure for government schools, through programs administered by the Commission, the Commonwealth provides untied revenue-sharing grants to the States. These grants are available to State governments to spend according to their own priorities and represent the bulk of the total funds for government schools-in fact, some 89 per cent- the States having the responsibility for the administration and delivery of educational services in government schools.

In November 1979, the Commonwealth announced the introduction of the School to Work Transition Program for young people aged 15 to 19 who were likely to be 'at risk' in the transition process. At that time the Commonwealth and the States had agreed that concerted action should be taken from both quarters. The Commonwealth undertook to provide a total of $150m in real terms over five years from 1980 for the program and asked the States to match this expenditure dollar for dollar for government schools and technical and further education colleges from 1982 onwards. This was designed to provide a total additional effort costing $250m over the five-year period. The program commenced in 1980, and the Commonwealth agreed to continue it in 1981 without a state contribution for that year.

In my statement to the House of 4 June 1981, I indicated that because the States had not at that time indicated their readiness to make additional contributions to match the Commonwealth's expenditure in 1982, we felt compelled to take special action to increase significantly the resources devoted to transition activities. We therefore proposed to earmark up to $27m within the Commonwealth General Recurrent Grants to the States for government schools for expenditure on transition education. From that sum grants at the rate of $10 per pupil were to be provided to each government secondary school. We also proposed to earmark about $19m of government schools capital funds for equipment and facilities for transition education. Following consultations with the States since 4 June, they have, in general, now indicated that they have increased or propose to increase their recurrent expenditure on transition programs in schools and TAFE over the base year 1979-80 by amounts which approximate, and in some cases exceed, the amounts proposed to be earmarked.

In these circumstances, the Commonwealth no longer needs to proceed with the recurrent earmarking, since its principal objective has been met. On 22 September, I announced that we did not propose to proceed with the capital earmarking or insist on the allocation of a cash component to each government secondary school. This means that the Commonwealth's own expenditure on the transition program of $27m in 1982 will now be provided on the same basis as this year, that is, a reasonable balance in expenditure will be observed between schools and TAFE. The Commonwealth will expect the States to continue their increased effort in transition programs and will seek the provision of information on a continuing basis to monitor progress with the combined Commonwealth and State contributions in schools and in TAFE. The Commonwealth hopes that, in appropriate circumstances, the States will arrange for school communities to participate in the development of transition projects.

In accordance with the guidelines, this legislation will no longer contain provision for State governments to request transfers of funds between the Commonwealth's general recurrent and capital allocations for government schools. The Commonwealth has allowed this provision over a number of years but as it tends to distort the basis of the Commonwealth's allocation of recurrent and capital programs it should no longer, in the Commonwealth's view, be applied.

A change in the administration of the Capital Grants Program for non-government schools involves the absorption of the annual allocation from the unsupplemented triennial allocation of $25m provided for new places in non-government schools from 1981 to 1983 into the existing new enrolments element of the general capital grants allocation. As each non-government school building project requires Commonwealth approval, there will be no difficulty in seeing that this element of the general capital program is properly applied, and separate provision for this element in the legislation is no longer considered necessary. A further change in this program allows for capital grants to new non-government schools to be applied to the leasing of facilities for a period of up to three years.

The present Contingency Program for Refugee Children administered by the Commonwealth Department of Education will from January 1982 become part of the Commonwealth Schools Commission's programs. It will become one arm of the Commission's English as a Second Language Program, with the Commission's Migrant Education Program, retitled 'General Education in English as a Second Language', forming the other. Within the limits of the available funds, up to $750 per eligible student will be made available for intensive English courses for newly arrived immigrant or refugee children whose first language is not English.

Because of the difficulty in forecasting the number of such children arriving in Australia and their destination on arrival, no attempt has been made to provide a State by State allocation of the funds for new arrivals. These funds will be made available to both government and non-government schools in States as the Commonwealth is advised of the numbers of eligible students undertaking appropriate courses. Provision has been made to allow transfers of funds between government and non-government sectors and also from the new arrivals element to the general education element of the program. Funds provided for both elements of this program have been increased in both government and non-government sectors. The opportunity has also been taken of partially adjusting the distribution of general education in the English as a second language element among the States to accord with the results of a recent national survey of students of non-English speaking background.

Funds for English as a Second Language Program for non-government schools have not been allocated on a State by State basis in the Bill. This reflects the Commission's wish to give responsibility to State planning and finance committees for distribution of funds to non-Catholic schools. However, the Government intends that the allocations to Catholic schools in the various States and Territories will be in accordance with the recommended distribution in the Commission's report.

An amendment has been made to the definition of 'program of ethnic education' to clarify the position of part-time ethnic schools in providing some instruction in the political and religious aspects of culture, as an adjunct to language instruction which will continue to be the major component of the course as a whole.

Funds for special education programs will remain at the same real levels as in 1981. There are, however, changes in the legislative provisions for these programs to enable funds to be more widely used to provide services to handicapped children beyond those provided in segregated special schools, centres and classes. In line with this philosophy, the former joint program for the Integration of Handicapped Children has been apportioned to each of the government and non-government special education programs as an identifiable element. To reflect the wider application of the funds, the basis of allocation of funds among States has begun to be changed from that of enrolments in special schools and classes to an overall school enrolment basis. The new allocation formula will be fully utilised within three years.

Non-government special schools will for the first time be eligible to participate in the General Recurrent Grants Program for non-government schools. They will not be subject to the assessment procedures applied to regular schools and will receive subsidies at the Group 1 primary rate.

In joint programs for both government and non-government schools, which are dealt with in Part IV of the Bill, major changes involve: The increase in funds for the Country Areas Program and relaxation of the criteria by which eligible areas may be selected for funding, and discontinuance of the school-level innovations element of the Special Projects Program; the widening of provisions relating to multicultural education to include projects involving instruction in Aboriginal language and culture which are to be eligible for funding; and revised provisions for programs of education for severely handicapped students to enable them to participate in educational activities outside the institution or private home in which they normally require constant care.
The Government has approved the allocation of funds to programs of national significance in 1982 on the basis recommended by the Commonwealth Schools Commission as follows:

$,000 Choice and Diversity in Government School Systems 300 Gifted and Talented Children 199 Schools Exchange and Travel Scheme 150 School Evaluation 150 Schools and Community 100 Education of Girls 100 General Projects of National Significance 503
Total 1,403

In accordance with the Government's guidelines, the Bill will provide for both educational and financial accountability statements to be supplied by State and non-government school authorities in relation to the expenditure of Commonwealth funds. The Commission has been asked to consult with State and non-government authorities in the development of the revised accountability arrangements. Allocations of grants for 1982 for the various programs for the States and the Northern Territory are detailed in Schedules 1 to 10 of the Bill. Grants as shown now include provision of a prospective allowance for forecast cost increases. The prospective allowance takes account of cost increases in all programs to the beginning of 1982. During 1982, the allowance is in respect of projected increases in the salary and wage components of recurrent grants. This means that the previous arrangements for cost adjustments have been converted in their entirety to a prospective basis.

Grants for current programs for the calendar year 1981 are also adjusted under Part VI and Schedule 12 of this Bill in accordance with Government policy. The salary and wage components of recurrent grants are adjusted to June quarter 1981 price levels, except the non-government general recurrent and migrant education grants which, in accordance with established practice, include provision for cost increases to the end of 1981. The additional cost of these adjustments is $40.8m. Finalisation of the adjustment of 1981 grants will be effected in legislation to be introduced during the autumn 1982 sittings of the Parliament. Part VI also contains an amendment rewording a provision in the legislation applying to programs of education of severely handicapped children for 1981 to allow education activities which involve the movement of such children from the institutions or homes in which they are normally cared for.

The education of children in all schools, whether government or non-government, is a shared responsibility of both Commonwealth and State governments. The continuing substantial overall level of support will enable further real improvements in schools' resource levels. The provisions of this Bill demonstrate the Commonwealth's continuing commitment to high standards in all Australian schools. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Blewett) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend certain provisions of the Non-government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act No. 106 of 1977, which presently covers the giving of loan guarantees to non-government schools in the States. In September of this year I announced that the necessary changes to the current Act would be the subject of amending legislation in the present Budget sittings. The effect of the amendments will bring the arrangements for the giving of loan guarantees in the States more into line with those for non-government schools in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory which are contained in the Independent Schools (Loans Guarantee) Act No. 23 of 1969. The first amendment seeks to extend the coverage of the 1977 Act to include proposed as well as existing non-government schools in the States. In normal circumstances proposed new schools do not have the necessary capital assets to offer as collaterial in order to raise moneys for projects by borrowing. It is also the case with many proposed schools that they do not have an extensive parent body which can support heavy loan repayments. The widened definition of a non-government school contained in this amendment would then be similar to that used in section 3 (1) of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act No. 135 of 1980. The second amendment would extend the scope of a loans guarantee to cover the payment of interest moneys in addition to the repayment of principal moneys for the purpose of expenditure on an approved building project at a non-government school.

The Bill will continue to provide that a guarantee will not be given by the Treasurer unless the Minister for Education certifies that: Firstly, the terms and conditions of the loan agreement are satisfactory; secondly, in the absence of a guarantee a school authority would not be able to obtain a loan on satisfactory terms and conditions; and, thirdly, a guarantee will not cover any part of the cost of a project that is or is likely to be the subject of a Commonwealth grant, including a grant under the advance approvals scheme. The Bill also provides for an extension of the recovery provision to cover any payments made by the Commonwealth in respect of both the interest and principal components of a loan. These changes will result in the scheme being more attractive to both proposed and existing non-government schools in the States which are faced with increased enrolment pressure. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Blewett) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On 4 June 1981 the Government announced the guidelines for the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the 1982-84 triennium and asked the Commission to recommend the detailed distribution of grants. On 23 September I tabled Volume 2 of the Commission's report, which responded to the guidelines. The purpose of this Bill is to provide a legislative framework for the allocation of funds following Government approval of the financial recommendations put forward by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in respect of State institutions, although some funds yet to be allocated for 1983 and 1984 will be included in subsequent annual amendments. The grants are for recurrent expenditure by universities and colleges of advanced education for the 1982-84 triennium and 1982 expenditure for technical and further education and for capital and equipment expenditure in universities and colleges. Amounts expressed in the Bill for the 1982-84 triennium reflect new cost adjustment procedures adopted by the Government whereby, from the beginning of 1982, a prospective allowance is made for cost increases. Grants for 1983 and 1984 are expressed in the same terms, on the basis that each year they will be adjusted for further cost movements. The Bill also amends the existing legislation for the 1979-81 triennium to provide for cost adjustment in respect of the existing tertiary education program.

Before describing the detailed provisions of this Bill, I should like to set the Government's funding decisions in context. Notwithstanding our overriding objective to contain public expenditure as an integral part of the Government's economic strategy, there has been a small increase in real terms in the sums made available in 1982 for tertiary education. Within the total funds provided for tertiary education there has been a reallocation of resources between the sectors. In real terms, while total expenditure in higher education has been slightly reduced by 0.4 per cent, funds for TAFE have been increased by 6 per cent. The additional funding provided for TAFE reflects the high priority which the Government accords to TAFE where enrolments are rising substantially and where important initiatives are being taken in relation to transition programs. The Bill provides for the continuation of a number of substantial TAFE capital programs. In total 72 projects will be under construction in 1982 at 58 locations. Of these projects 35 will require a Commonwealth contribution in excess of $5m. In 1982 the Commonwealth Goverment will provide more than $112m for TAFE capital.

The Government has also continued to provide priority for higher education in the context of its overall Budget strategy, notwithstanding that enrolment levels have stabilised. In this context, the Government has noted the concern expressed by the Commission on the declining proportion of young people who are proceeding to higher education. The Government will be asking the Commission to undertake a more detailed study of this decline against the background of the enrolment patterns and prospects for tertiary education as a whole. The Government has noted that the planning ranges originally proposed by the Commission earlier this year for enrolment levels for universities and colleges of advanced education, for the 1982-84 triennium, should be achieved.

The Bill provides funding consistent with the decisions taken by the Government for the rationalisation and consolidation of resources in higher education. The Commonwealth is firmly convinced that its policy of consolidation will not only improve the efficiency of the institutions and enable them to be more responsive to community demand but also improve the quality of education provided for students. Its program of consolidation was initiated following advice from the Commission and the Government will continue to look to the Commission, in consultation with the States and institutions concerned, for advice on the consolidation and rationalisation of tertiary education. I am pleased to inform the House that, of the 30 colleges of advanced education identified for rationalisation, at this stage acceptable arrangements have been received for all but seven. I pay tribute to the way in which State governments have co-operated with the Commonwealth over the consolidation of institutions. In Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia all of the consolidation proposals made by the Commonwealth have been agreed to by the States and action is in train in respect of the consolidations. Some particular issues in New South Wales and Victoria remain to be resolved, and I look forward to further consultations with these States on the outstanding issues.

In the meantime, funds for 1982 for those colleges of advanced education in New South Wales and Victoria, for which acceptable consolidation arrangements have not yet been received, have been included in the legislation in a national unallocated reserve. Should acceptable consolidation arrangements be reached before the end of the year the Minister, after advice from the Commission, will be able to allocate amounts from this reserve to the newly consolidated institutions.

Under the terms of the Government's decisions on rationalisation the Commonwealth will continue funding for the Wollongong Institute of Education and Newcastle, Armidale and Townsville Colleges of Advanced Education only if they merge with the Universities of Wollongong, Newcastle and New England and James Cook University of North Queensland respectively. Allocations for Wollongong, Newcastle and New England universities for 1982 have been included in the Bill on the basis that amalgamations with the respective colleges will proceed. In order to ensure the maintenance of the two streams of tertiary education in these universities, however, the minimum amounts required for teaching purposes in advanced education, as recommended by the Commission, have been earmarked in the legislation. In the case of the James Cook University and the Townsville College of Advanced Education where acceptable arrangements for amalgamation have been developed, funds for 1982, 1983 and 1984 have also been appropriated in the Bill. For the other three universities and the related colleges where suitable amalgamation arrangements are yet to be proposed, grants have not been appropriated for 1983 and 1984. These will be provided by a subsequent legislative amendment.

Should suitable arrangements not be worked out by the end of 1981 it will be possible for those funds presently allocated to the three New South Wales universities for 1982 in respect of advanced education to be transferred to the national unallocated reserve. In those circumstances, the legislation would enable funding for the three universities and the related colleges to continue for 1982 only. Funds for 1983 and 1984 will have to be the subject of further legislation. The Government would be able to make similar funding arrangements in respect of the other outstanding colleges listed for amalgamation to which I referred earlier.

The Bill incorporates the funding recommendations for individual institutions and projects as recommended by the Commission. In some States not all of the funds available for advanced education have yet been allocated to particular colleges and the Bill provides that this can be done at the request of the States concerned. In accordance with the Commission's recommendations, provision will also be made to permit these funds to be transferred between years. These funds should provide added flexibility which will assist with the consolidation and rationalisation of higher education institutions that is already proceeding in the States.

The Bill provides for the limited reintroduction of tuition fees from 1982. The Bill specifically excludes the charging of tuition fees for students undertaking courses leading to first awards. It also exempts students who commenced second degree or diploma courses before 1982 from paying fees for those courses, and it sets a maximum fee, that is for full time students, of $1,000 per annum. Subject to these principles, the Bill contains a provision for the Minister to make determination as to the circumstances in which students are either required to pay tuition fees or are to be exempt. Subject to various exemptions, to be covered by the determination, students who have already gained a diploma or a degree, who enrol in a university or an advanced education course, will be required to pay tuition fees. Exemptions from tuition fees will apply, for example, where higher degree students are in receipt of Commonwealth awards or awards of at least $3,500 per annum from universities, colleges of advanced education and State governments. The States and institutions have been consulted on the detailed arrangements.

The Bill will contain a provision that, as a condition of recurrent grants, institutions charge fees in accordance with these arrangements and that they do not charge fees in other circumstances. The Bill provides for recurrent grants scheduled in the Bill to be offset by an amount equivalent to the money from fees which those institutions will be required to charge. The Australian National University Bill and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill, which are also being introduced at this time, contain provisions for the reintroduction of tuition fees in the same terms as this Bill, except where particular requirements necessitate differences.

The Government has considered the Commission's recommendation that the arrangements for the disapproval of new teaching developments should be extended to cover such developments regardless of the source of funds. It does not propose to legislate in the way recommended by the Commission but will ask the Commission to continue to monitor new teaching developments and to bring to its attention any examples of proposed new teaching developments funded from other sources which, in the Commission's view, are not in the best interests of the balanced development of tertiary education in Australia. I will also seek the co-operation of State governments and institutions in this context.

In accordance with the Government's election undertakings the Bill contains a specific allocation of $16m over the triennium for research centres of excellence, and $900,000 in each year of the triennium for the development of community language courses in universities and colleges of advanced education. The allocation of funds to particular universities and colleges of advanced education for the development of community language courses will be approved by the Minister after taking account of the views of the Commission and the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs. Similarly detailed allocations for the research centres of excellence will be announced after the Government has considered the recommendations of the special committee established to provide advice on the implementation of this initiative.

The Bill provides an increased level of support for those non-government teachers colleges in the States which, until now, have been in receipt of partial recurrent funding. The two institutions included in the Bill, McAuley College in Queensland and Avondale College in New South Wales, together with Signadou College in the Australian Capital Territory, are not recognised as colleges of advanced education. The Government's decision to increase the level of support for these institutions is consistent with its view that freedom of choice in primary and secondary education is dependent upon the preparation of teachers with a special commitment to teach in non-government schools.

The Bill also provides financial assistance to the Northern Territory for advanced education purposes. Following an inquiry into the proposal to establish a university in the Northern Territory the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission recommended that an external studies centre be established at the Darwin Community College, and that subject to the agreement of the Australian National University, the North Australia Research Unit of that institution be given the capacity to co-ordinate research directly related to the needs of the Territory. The establishment of an external studies centre is currently under discussion, but funds for the proposed centre have been included in the legislation in the national unallocated reserve. Provision for the North Australia Research Unit of the Australian National University will be included in the annual appropriations of the Department of Education. The matter of additional financial provision from 1983 for superannuation for staff in universities and colleges of advanced education, which was recommended by the Commission, is under separate consideration by the Government.

In summary, the Bill provides evidence of the Government's continuing commitment to the development of tertiary education in Australia. Some particular parts of the tertiary education sectors have faced, and will continue to face, the need for substantial readjustment. This is required if valuable resources are to be allocated to the most urgent priorities. All governments would like to increase spending on education-it is an investment in the future of Australia. Resources, however, are not unlimited, and the Government's decisions are both reasonable and responsible. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fife, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the limited re-introduction of tuition fees at the Australian National University. In addition to this primary purpose, the Bill provides for two other amendments to the Australian National University Act, requested by the University, concerned with aspects of the administration of the University. These relate to the election of undergraduate and postgraduate representatives on the University Council, and the granting of status and exemptions in respect of courses at the University. In relation to its primary purpose, the same principles are involved in this Bill as in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill for the re-introduction of tuition fees. The three Bills are viewed as parallel legislation for this purpose and have been drafted in the same terms except where the particular requirements of the States Grants Act or the Acts of the two institutions necessitate differences.

This Bill is similar to the States Grants Bill in its provision which empowers the Minister to make determinations in the same terms and subject to the same general conditions, as that Bill. The same annual limit of $1,000 is set. The Bill differs from the States Grants Bill in that there is no specific provision for the adjustment of grants to take account of fees revenue collected. This power is not needed in either this Bill or the Canberra College of Advanced Education Bill. Whereas the States Grants Bill places the obligation on the State, as a condition of grant, to ensure that fees are charged in respect of those students required to pay fees, in the case of this Bill this obligation is placed on the Council of the University. In order to give effect to this obligation, the Council is empowered to make a statute in line with the requirements of the Minister's determination.

In addition to its primary purpose, the Australian National University Bill also contains two amendments to the Act requested by the University. Clause 3 is intended to clarify the distinction between undergraduate and postgraduate students for the purpose of the election of representatives to the University Council. The Act provides for undergraduate students having two representatives on the Council and other students having one representative. Clause 4 broadens the power of the University to grant status or to grant awards to persons who have undertaken studies in other institutions. At present this power is restricted to students from other universities so that position of colleges of advanced education, for example, is not recognised in the Act. Clause 4 similarly includes a power for the University Council to grant exemptions in respect of particular courses. I commend the Bill to the House.

This Bill is intended to provide for the limited re-introduction of tuition fees at the Canberra College of Advanced Education and is a companion measure to the Bill to amend the Australian National University Act and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill in this respect.
