SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Opposition spokesman on foreign policy matters, in the short time available I want to make a few remarks about matters relating to that policy in the light of the report of Estimates Committee A. One matter that concerns the Opposition is what we call the debasing of the international currency in respect of our international credibility. I will address my remarks to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Communique which had a number of splendid things to say and with which the Opposition agrees. For example, we agree with the Government's concern that substantial progress must be made in the North-South dialogue. But from the point of view of our aid performance to the poorer countries, even taking into account the recent increase, our overseas aid contribution still represents only 0.45 per cent of our our gross national product. Under the Labor Government in 1975, it had reached 0.65 per cent of our gross national product. Accordingly, it has declined dramatically since the Australian Labor Party was ousted from office.

SPEECH.PARA: When dealing with aid, we need to talk about the overall review of our overseas aid commitment. I have raised this matter before. Notwithstanding the quantitative increase in our overseas aid, there is a need to reassess the quality of some of the projects and whether they are as essential as they might be deemed by the country receiving them. I have also indicated in which areas we are not giving aid but should be. Vietnam is perhaps the most outstanding example of a country in this category. If the Government wants to have peace and stability in our region but behaves as though we can ignore the necessity to assist in the reconstruction and economic rehabilitation of a country which we must include in all policy calculations, then it surely must relate to Vietnam. It is quite counter-productive to assist in a policy which will put an economic squeeze on Vietnam and which can cause massive numbers of refugees and at the same time suggest that there can be peace and stability in the region.
Another matter related to the CHOGM Communique is that of disarmament. Again, it is important that we note in the Communique the statement:

. . . practical measures which are directed towards nuclear disarmament and the avoidance of all armed conflict, particularly nuclear conflicts, must have the highest priority on the international agenda.

Let us look at disarmament. It is important that we assist the poorer countries. We need to adopt a more independent foreign policy and to assert the necessity for de-escalation of the international arms race, particularly the nuclear arms race, because there is a finite limit to the capacity of the developed countries-even the super-powers. It is just not possible to go on spending well over $520,000m a year on weapons and at the same time devote the necessary resources to increase food production, agrarian reform and improved health and living standards.

The fine words of the CHOGM Communique are simply not reflected in the Government's actions. In other words, the total annual income of the 92 billion poorest people in the world would amount to the $520,000m being spent on armaments, that is, the poorest half of the world's population could well do with some of that money. But tragically at present, the biggest single business in the world is the arms trade. We are currently spending $1m a minute on armaments while many people in the world are starving, in need of medical care and in need of education. So it is quite wrong to be talking about these matters. One-half of one per cent of arms spending would pay for all the farm equipment needed to make food deficit countries virtually self-sufficient by 1990. For the cost of one tank we could build basic classrooms for 30,000 children, hundreds of whom at present will never get an education. For the cost of one modern jet fighter we could establish over 40,000 village pharmacies. The greatest danger we face is that our sense of responsibility will be dulled by the massiveness of these figures and the apparent incredible stupidity of the course on which we have embarked.
We talk about the Indian Ocean. The Communique states:
. . . that despite the expressed wishes of the littoral and hinterland states there had been a further increase in the military presence of outside powers in the Indian Ocean.

It also states that this undermines the 1971 United Nations Declaration on an Indian Ocean Zone of Peace. Let us have a look at our record. We talk about peace in the Indian Ocean but we know perfectly well that we are allowing long range strategic nuclear bombers to land at and transit through Darwin and that their primary purpose is to project military might in the Indian Ocean, particularly through Diego Garcia. We should have known that the American military planners envisaged the use of a limited nuclear conflict in the Gulf region. So whatever the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) thinks of having B52s in Australia, it is pretty clear that the Soviet Union sees this as a substantial increase of strategic power into the Indian Ocean and, of course, it will move to counter that escalation. So it goes on.

Let us have a look at another aspect of the Communique-El Salvador. The Government's only statement on this matter was a reaffirmation by the Prime Minister of endorsement of the Reagan Administration's support for President Duarte as being the right President, having the right sorts of policies. I doubt whether there is anyone in the world, including President Reagan's advisers, who agree with that. I do not pretend that Australia does have influence in El Salvador. But if we wish to maintain a credible and principled policy towards Central and Southern America, we must do more than just parrot Washington's Views.

The CHOGM Communique on Cyprus does not go far enough. The Cypriot leaders are disappointed. This Government and others were not prepared to call for the withdrawal of all foreign troops from that island. Perhaps this has something to do with the fact that the British have some bases there. But we should make it absolutely clear that the presence of Turkish troops is intolerable on that island. On the Middle East-the most difficult and sensitive issue for us in Australia-we note that the Communique, which is the view of all the Heads of Government at CHOGM, states:

They recognise that a just and lasting settlement-that is in the Middle East-should be on the basis of the relevant United Nations resolution and recognition of the rights of the Palestinian people, including their inalienable right to a homeland, as well as the right of all States in the region to live in peace within secure borders.

Has there been peace in that area? I think not. As we know, a number of matters have arisen since this subject was last debated in this House. We welcome the opportunity to debate this matter. But it is important to have another debate because since it was last debated, rather sadly and tragically, President Sadat has been assassinated. This certainly highlights the instability of the area-an area in which there has been warfare in recent months. Iraq's nuclear reactor was destroyed. In Beirut there has been bombing with the killing of 300 civilians and the wounding of another 500. In other words, tension has increased substantially. I call on the Government to have another full scale debate in this Parliament before any decision is taken as to whether we are going to commit any Australian presence in that region. It can have most serious medium and long term consequences for our nation. There are even more substantial reasons now than there were five months ago why Australian troops should not be committed. For example, the Israeli Chief of Staff said that, if anything happened to President Sadat, the entire peace process would come adrift. Since the Minister made his statement, might I refer to the remarks of a former American Secretary of State, Cyrus Vance, who said that it was agreed at Camp David that there should be full autonomy for the West Bank and Gaza and that it was understood by the parties that full-I underline 'full'-autonomy meant exactly what the words indicated.

We are told that any Australian peacekeeping contingent would be part of a Camp David process, but half of that process has been ignored, which is extremely dangerous. What of the CHOGM Communique and its reference to the rights of the Palestinian people, that is, that all states in the region have a right to live in peace within secure boundaries? Finally, what about doing something about Lebanon and not limiting attention just to Israel and Egypt, because that country has been torn asunder? There are at least 200,000 Lebanese people in Australia wondering why this Government never says anything about the disarray in Lebanon and its destruction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may, I want to comment briefly about another aspect of the report from Estimates Committee A. For those who are listening, it might be worth commenting that the House is currently considering a report from an Estimates committee that examined not just the Department of Foreign Affairs but three other departments as well-the Parliament, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Defence. My colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) directed his remarks to the Department of Foreign Affairs. While I am tempted to enter into a debate with him on those issues which interest me and him alike, I want to comment really on the resolutions that pertain to the estimates relating to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do so, I suggest to the House that at the time when these matters come before us for a vote we might subdivide the questions. If honourable members care to identify them, they will see that paragraph (2) with respect to the Parliament has two sub-paragraphs and that paragraph (3) relating to the Department of Foreign Affairs has three sub-paragraphs. I think it may be beneficial to the House were the matters to be placed before us separately rather than as a whole.
I want to make a couple of brief comments with respect to the resolutions relating to the Parliament. The first is in respect of paragraph (2) sub-paragraph (1), which reads:

That this Committee resolves that in appropriation procedures for 1982-83 the funds for Parliament should be contained in a separate single line Appropriation Bill and notes the support for this procedure contained in the recommendations of the Report of the Senate Select Committee on the Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing.

The Government at this stage is considering the report of the Senate Select Committee. Accordingly, the Government believes that it is inappropriate for the Parliament at this stage to agree to this recommendation. It is necessary that the report be considered not just in relation to that one question but also in relation to a number of other equally important matters which are before it. For that reason, without expressing a view on the substance of the resolution, the Government intends to oppose the recommendation. However, it will be the intention of the Government at a later stage to consider all the recommendations of the Jessop Committee report and at that time, of course, it will be possible for members to express their views and to consider the matter in a little more detail. Paragraph (2) sub-paragraph (2) reads:
That this committee registers its grave disquiet at many of the proposed cuts in real terms in the budget for the Parliament.

I had the opportunity of discussing this matter with the Department of Finance which had been through the estimates but, regrettably, at the time of the consideration of the matter by the Estimates Committee, I did not have the benefit of that advice. It seems that the position is that, as in all areas where the same real money is provided, there is excluded from consideration any areas where there is a non-recurring Budget item. In other words, where there is funding for a project which has a short life and where there is a non-recurrence of that item in a subsequent year, it is excluded in the consideration of the funds to be provided. Thus the same real money decision excludes one-off expenditures that took place in 1980-81. The advice that I have from the Department of Finance that I want to pass on to this Parliament is that the same real level of money has been provided for on going items of expenditure for which the Parliament's bid has been made. Accordingly, the Government disagrees with the expression of view that Estimates Committee A passed on to this chamber.

However, there is certainly some concern by the Presiding Officers, Mr Speaker and Mr President, with respect to some items of the parliamentary estimates. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) and I, representing the Government, intend to enter into discussions with Mr Speaker and Mr President regarding their concern and to discuss details of the parliamentary estimates at an appropriate time. At this stage the Government will be voting against paragraph (2) sub-paragraph (2), but that vote is without prejudice to those discussions which, as I have indicated, will take place at an appropriate time. I hope and believe they will be held fairly shortly rather than at some date in the far distance. We wish to have that discussion fairly soon. Now that Senator Young has taken up his newly-assumed responsibilities as President, I hope that we can pursue our discussion and come to some mutually satisfactory conclusion regarding the parliamentary estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! I take it that the Leader of the House wishes the concurrence of the Opposition on the method of procedure with regard to the voting on the five paragraphs resolutions. Is he suggesting that there be a separate vote on each? Is there agreement on that?

—Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I did not know whether it was quite appropriate that I put that request at this time. I am suggesting that at the time when it comes to vote I would seek the concurrence of the Opposition.

—I think there can be agreement on it rather than doing it by resolution. Is there any opposition to the proposal that there be separate votes on each of the resolutions? There being no opposition to that proposal I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not a member of Estimates Committee A, but I would like to speak about Australia's providing foreign aid to Vietnam which is the subject of one of the expressions of opinion agreed to by Estimates Committee A in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs. However, I am a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which, in June of this year, presented a report to this Parliament called: 'Power in Indo China since 1975'. That report clearly stated in one of its recommendations that Australia should not give economic aid to Vietnam, a position I fully support. Certainly there was a minority suggesting the contrary, but that minority report represents a position I did not then and will not now support.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at Vietnam since its so-called glorious liberation. Any rational assessment of Vietnam's domestic and foreign policies shows that, since 1975, it has deliberately decided not to help itself in economic reconstruction and in fact has undertaken policies which can result only in weakening the economic fabric of that nation. Vietnam has decided of its own volition and in conjunction with the wishes of the Soviet Union to commit a very large percentage of its resources to military purposes. In proportion to its population of some 53 million people, Vietnam has one of the largest armed forces in the world. Vietnam currently has some 200,000 troops in Kampuchea. It also has 40,000 to 50,000 troops in Laos. Quite apart from the effect that this has had on Vietnam's economy, it has also meant that Thailand is now confronted with 250,000 Vietnamese troops on two of its borders. This imposes major pres- sures on Thailand's allocation of resources to domestic and foreign purposes. It would be more appropriate for us, in my opinion, to look more sympathetically to countries such as Thailand, rather than Vietnam, when considerating aid allocations. It should also be recognised that the Soviet Union has been giving increasing military and economic aid to Vietnam, enabling a massive re-equipping of the Vietnamese armed forces.

I see no merit in putting Australian aid in to a country if it would have the effect of allowing that country to divert more of its resources to military purposes designed to meet Soviet wishes to destabilise our region of the world. Any economic aid we give would simply serve the regional foreign relations interests of the Soviet Union. The fact remains that Vietnam, following its reunification after a long period of warfare which destroyed the country's economic infrastruture and placed intolerable burdens on its population, made a conscious decision of its own within its own undemocratic political decision-making machinery to opt for guns instead of butter and to further its military imperialism in Indo-China rather than concentrate its resources on economic development and seek to raise the living standards of its people. If Vietnam chooses guns instead of butter, we do not have to provide the butter, particularly if the guns are pointed, however indirectly, in our direction.

Further, the Vietnamese Goverment decided to expel the Chinese middle class in its country, a class of merchants and entrepreneurs which formed an important part of the tertiary and secondary sectors of that country's economy. Apart from the deleterious effects this had on Vietnam's economy, it also placed enormous burdens on other nations in the region and throughout the world by creating the flood of refugees which other nations, including Australia, have had to accommodate for humanitarian reasons. In this sense, aid has already been given to Vietnam. I must say that I find it impossible to justify giving direct economic aid to Vietnam in these circumstances. More economic aid would allow Vietnam to divert more of its resources to military expansion in the region with the endorsement and with the support of the Soviet Union. To give economic aid under these circumstances to a country over which we have no influence, to a country which has itself decided to give priority to military expansion rather than economic development, and to a country which has strategic interests clearly against our best interests in this region is something I just cannot support.

Vietnam is just another of the great modern day liberations we hear about in international forums and in the propaganda outbursts of totalitarian regimes throughout the world. Far from liberating its citizens, the Vietnamese Government has brought despair, deprivation and repression to them. This is a tragedy for the people of Vietnam, but it is a result of deliberately taken decisions of a government which is committed to remaining on its present course with regard to both its domestic and its foreign policies. In these circumstances, I cannot support Australia giving economic aid to this country. I would not give it a cracker. I therefore disagree with that expression of opinion agreed to by Estimates Committee A.

To put my view on foreign aid in a more general and proper perspective, I say that as a matter of principle I fully support the obligations of relatively affluent nations, such as Australia, to provide aid to the poorer nations which, through no fault of their own, unlike Vietnam, have to cope with the problems of thousands and millions of their children and families facing death through starvation. Morally it is impossible for nations such as Australia not to play a role in alleviating this massive human suffering. In this regard, I was very proud of the opening comments of our Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne recently when he said:

. . . our generation of leaders will ultimately be judged largely in terms of their success or failure in reconciling the interests of the rich and poor countries of the earth. For if they are not reconciled the world in which we shall live out our lives and which our children shall inherit will be an unhappy one, condemned to turmoil and bitterness.
. . . those who fail to recognise the gravity and drama of the issues disguised by the rather bland term 'North-South dialogue' are guilty of a serious failure of historical imagination.

I think that is a statesmanlike view of the world. It is a realistic view of the world and it is a morally proper view of the world. I think it is a magnificent statement which basically reminds the relatively well off nations of this world, such as Australia, that where equity is concerned national boundaries are irrelevant if we are to overcome the suffering experienced by so much of mankind, whether it be in Africa, South America, South East Asia or Asia generally. From a compassionate point of view and even from a pragmatic international point of view, to secure long term peace on this earth we have to meet these obligations. I therefore support the Government in its present efforts to increase our foreign aid vote along the lines referred to by the Estimates Committee, which stated that it was of the view that the Government should accept and work towards meeting the United Nations target of 0.7 per cent of gross national product as official development assistance. That is the stated objective of this Government and it is an objective which I am very pleased to support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are considering the report of Estimates Committee A which covers two departments of interest to the Australian Labor Party and certainly to me personally. One is the Department of Defence and the other is the Department of Foreign Affairs. We are at a disadvantage in discussing the estimates of the Department of Defence because we have not had a statement from the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) relating to the Budget. This, I believe, is a retrograde step. This Parliament should be completely informed of the significance of the figures in the Budget statement on defence. I regret that at this stage we have not had in the Parliament a statement from the Minister for Defence associating himself with the policies implicit in the Budget. We have also not had from the Minister for Defence the defence report. So, in any discussions of the matters associated with the Budget on defence, this House-not only members of the Opposition but also members of the Government-is at a marked disadvantage.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take up with the House the question of the Government's statements-one may call them the rhetoric of the Government-on defence and the Government's actual performance on defence. In Budget Paper No. 1 of 1980-81 the following statement appeared:
In keeping with the Government's policy, the outlays on Defence of $3541.4m represent . . . a real increase of at least 7 per cent . . .

In the Budget Papers the statement was made that in the following year the increase in the Budget expenditure on defence would represent an increase of 7 per cent. The House will recall that on a number of occasions this Government has informed the House that it is attached to a defence policy program that will incorporate in each year an increase of 7 per cent, but when we get down to the actual figures we find that in 1979-80, compared with the previous year, the increase in defence expenditure was only 3 per cent. We had some discussions in the Estimates Committee meeting about what the last year's percentage increase was, remembering that the Government had pronounced that it should be 7 per cent. In fact, it turned out to be, not 7 per cent, but 5.6 per cent. When we come to this year's Budget statements we find that the Government has provided a real increase in the current financial year over 1980-81 of only 5.3 per cent. We have the Government stating time and time again that its whole purpose is to have a growth in the defence expenditure, defence outlay, of 7 per cent, but in no year since it has been in government has it achieved the 7 per cent that it has so vainly promised. I believe that this Government's whole attitude to defence is seen only in relation to elections because that is the only time we ever hear any statements about defence from the Government. Nothing so concentrates the mind of members of the Liberal Party on defence as an upcoming election. The whole performance of the Government has fallen far short of any promises it has ever made. I believe this House should criticise and castigate the Government for the hollowness of its rhetoric about defence because it has not, at any stage since it came to power, undertaken its full responsibilities to the Australian people in regard to defence. After six years of the Fraser Government, expenditure on defence-in the only measurable terms that mean anything, and that is in relation to gross national product-has hardly moved from 2.6 per cent of gross national product. That is in fact lower than the last Labor Party Budget which arranged for expenditure on defence, in terms of gross domestic product, of 2.7 per cent.

I now refer to the estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs. Honourable members will note that three resolutions were brought forward from the Estimates Committee. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) pointed out again the lack of performance of the Fraser Government in relation to foreign aid. When we left office in 1975 the Australian contribution to foreign aid amounted to 0.65 per cent of gross national product and after six years of Fraser Government that has woefully gone down to 0.48 per cent. This again shows the hollowness of the rhetoric of the Fraser Government. It parades the world stage, for instance at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting and with other groups in the world. Its performance is lamentably short of its promises. So the Opposition moved in the Estimates Committee the resolution that has been circulated to the House. Another resolution that we raised in the Estimates Committee related to the expenditure of $150,000 on the Australia-Britain Society. At the same time funds to organisations of great repute such as the Australian Institute of International Affairs and the United Nations Association of Australia were cut. So these organisations finished up with $15,000 or $20,000 whilst the Australia-Britain Society received a vote of $150,000. We asked in the Committee that that matter be reviewed by the Government and that a more equitable distribution of funds for non-governmental organisations be made available. The honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean) raised the question of aid to Vietnam. I shall quote from a report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. We are both members of that Committee. In dealing with Indo-China and the dissenting report that was produced on that occasion in relation to the question of aid to Vietnam the report stated:

The cessation of Australia's small aid program to Vietnam following the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea is understandable, but in the context of our longer term interests, is counterproductive. For Australia to continue to maintain this position deprives us of attaining an identifiable position in the process of reaching a solution to the Indo-Chinese problem. This is not to say that the quantity of aid that we would be in a position to provide would lessen Vietnamese dependence on Soviet aid, but it would sufficiently demarcate Australia from the position taken by other countries and strengthen Australia's hand in . . . implementing the recommendations put forward by the report.

In the light of the resolutions that were passed by that Committee I wish to move an amendment to the resolution that has been put forward by the Government. The Government said, in relation to the Estimates Committee's report that, the expenditures be agreed to and that the resolutions and expressions of opinion be noted. I do not think that goes far enough. I think the issues that were raised in the Foreign Affairs Committee report are worthy of greater action than indicated by the phrase 'be noted'. On behalf of the Opposition I move:

Omit the words 'the expressions of opinion agreed to by Committee A in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs be noted', substitute the following words: 'this House fully endorses the expressions of opinion agreed to by Committee A in relation to the Department of Foreign Affairs and requests appropriate action by the Government'.

Members of the Opposition already have indicated that they support the statement that the Australian Government should accept the goal of 0.7 per cent of GNP for foreign aid. What we are insisting upon, apart from the Government making the promise, is that the Fraser Government, for a change, should try to achieve what it promises. In relation to the other propositions, and looking at the questions I have already referred to, I think it is only fair and reasonable that this House should support those recommendations. Therefore I have much pleasure in submitting the amendment to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have pleasure in seconding the amendment. I think the various resolutions carried by the Estimates Committee which examined the appropriation for the Department of Foreign Affairs were extremely important and do bear the more detailed attention of this House than they would get under the proposition that is currently before it. I want to take points with respect to two of those resolutions. Firstly, that one which related to expenditure on the United Nations Association of Australia and the Australian Institute of International Affairs and, secondly, the resolution which referred to recommending aid to Vietnam. On the question of the United Nations Association and the Australian Institute of International Affairs we pointed out at the Estimates Committee hearing that there was discrimination on the part of the Government in its handling of the proposed expenditure in relation to those two organisations, and a number of other organisations that dealt with bilateral relations between different countries such as the Australia-Britain Society and one or two others.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of the Australia-Britain Society there will be a cut in real terms but not in absolute terms-in real terms in a sense that the expenditure budgeted this year will be the same as it was last year and therefore there will be no adjustments for anticipated inflation. But in the case of the Australian Institute of International Affairs and the United Nations Association there has been an absolute cut in the funds granted. In the case of the United Nations Association, it is a reduction from $25,000 to $20,000 and there is a similar reduction in the case of the Australian Institute of International Affairs. It is not as though those two organisations, as independent organisations supported by the Government, were the most expensive. In fact they are among the cheaper organisations offered government support. In the case of the Australia-Britain Society, for example, an amount of $150,000 was budgeted and in the case of the Australia Indo-China Society it was an amount, I think, of some $500,000.

There needs to be an explanation as to why these two organisations which to this point have been treated relatively ungenerously are treated even more ungenerously by the Government in this Budget. I cannot for the life of me figure out why that should be the case. Both those organisations, far more than other organisations I have referred to, have contributed in a major way to public understanding of foreign affairs issues in Australia for a very long number of years. The Government grant to the Australian Institute of International Affairs when it was instituted, reflected at that time the government decision that there ought to be in the Australian community a greater understanding of international affairs. In many ways the Australian Institute of International Affairs and its predecessor were contributing to serious discussion on foreign affairs in this country when governments in this country were most reluctant to believe we had a foreign policy at all. The Institute provided the Australian public with some sort of direction in foreign affairs when governments in the 1930s in particular, abdicated responsibility. That they should be cut in this way and at this moment, I think, is an insult to the record of those organisations and the contributions they have made.

The same applies to the United Nations organisation. That has been supported for a very long time and it started as a gesture of support by the Government overall to the concept of the United Nations. There has been no retreating from that under any government. We regularly send delegates and we participate in all United Nations affairs. There is no justification for the reduction in allocations for that body as well. I cannot work out why the Government should choose to treat those bodies like that. As far as I am aware, neither of those bodies has engaged in activities which are embarrassing to the Government. As far as I am aware, both of them have had representatives of the Government at their various meetings explaining government policy. There has been no reluctance by the Government to participate in the affairs of those bodies. There has been no assumption that a fair hearing will not be accorded them when they participate in affairs. Indeed, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) opened the last major seminar on the Middle East of the Australian Institute of International Affairs. He was accorded, I thought at the time, a reasonably good reception.

I do not believe that the Government will have the confidence of a large number of people in the independent-or outside, if you like-non-official foreign policy influencing community if, on the one hand, it is going to treat organisations such as the Australian Institute of International Affairs and the United Nations Association with an extreme of ungenerosity and, on the other hand, it is going to treat with a relative degree of generosity organisations of highly doubtful value in the case of the Australia-Britain Society and of some value in the case of the Australia-Indo-China Society, although it is not of substantially greater value than are the other two organisations.

I turn to the second of the three parts of the proposition we put forward, that is, that part which dealt with the matter of aid to Vietnam. I had not intended to deal with this matter at any length, but I think some points need to be made on the remarks of the honourale member for Perth (Mr McLean). I think it is reasonable to say that when it comes to handling questions regarding Indo-China, historically this Government had had the Midas touch of failure. Everything this Government has decided in respect of Indo-China irrespective of the reasons or the validity of the reasons that were espoused for taking a particular action, has ended up detrimental to Australia's interests.

The two great advances, in territorial terms, made in communist power virtually since the Bolshevik revolution in 1917 were the First World War and the situation in Indo-China. The Second World War gains were made as a result of the policies of Adolf Hitler. The policies pursued by the Administration of the United States of America and supported by the Australian Government produced a situation in Indo-China in which the likely outcome of conflict there was definitely a communist government in Vietnam, but a communist government under which in the south of Vietnam there would be a degree of conflict at least with the North Vietnamese communists. The cadres need not have been wasted in the way in which they were during the war. So a North Vietnamese takeover was complete and neutralist regimes were established in Laos and Kampuchea.

What do we have in that situation? We have hard-line communist regimes in every one of those countries as a direct result of Australian Government and American government policies. I do not believe that that is a record which ought to give us any confidence in the sorts of propositions that will be put forward by the other side. It certainly is not a record that ought to give us any confidence in the propositions put forward by the honourable member for Perth.

When we come to look at the matter of aid to Vietnam we see yet another Australian government failure in the making. It is not as though Vietnam has pursued, with no internal debate and with utter consistency, the present policies in Indo-China since its success in South Vietnam. As the honourable member for Perth pointed out, in the evidence on Indo-China presented to the Committee-this is detailed in the Committee's report-between 1976 and 1979 there was considerable debate and uncertainty within the Vietnamese regime about what ought to be done concerning the situation in Laos and Kampuchea. Again, that information was presented to the Committee in evidence.

One of the factors which finally determined the course of the regime was the continuing hostility by powers which previously had been involved in Vietnam to the notion that Vietnam should receive the sort of aid which would permit its economic recovery. Of course, there are other factors, but that was one of them. It was that factor that we attempted to come to grips with in the minority report we submitted on this and also in the amendment before us. The Vietnamese had every reason, in the end, to be distrustful of Western motives in dealing with them. It must be said that the record of the West-Australia and the United States-is not all that good. None of us believe for one moment that if we were to give to Vietnam the sort of aid we were giving it before we cut if off there would be a dramatic change in Vietnam's policy.

The point made in the minority report, to which the honourable member for Perth referred, was that at least that would be a start, at least it would give the Vietnamese an American option to take them out of a situation in which they clearly do not want to be, namely, one of dependence on the Soviet Union. It would put them in a situation in which they could balance their Soviet relationship with a relationship with another nation. For them to be able to do that is in our interests. A Soviet Union influence in Vietnam is not in our interests. It is up to us to produce sensible policies to diminish Soviet influence in that area. The Government will fail in its policy, particularly if it encourages the United States to take a similar stance. The Government will fail in its policy on this, just as the coalition government of the 1960s failed in its policies on Vietnam. This Parliament ought to record its recognition of that failure by passing the amendment moved by the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to consider certain aspects of the estimates for the Department of Defence. The appropriations for the defence effort this financial year represent 10.1 per cent of total Budget outlays, compared with its representing 9.1 per cent of total Budget outlays in 1974-75. I want to make particular reference to the capital expenditure side and to examine some of the trends in expenditure in that area. The provision for capital expenditure on defence in this Budget represents an overall increase of about 7 per cent, in real terms, over the capital expenditure on defence in last year's Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting to look at some of the components of that category of capital expenditure. For example, expenditure on naval construction is down by about 18 per cent in real terms reflecting probably the run-down of the FFG program. Expenditure on aircraft procurement represents an increase of about 27 per cent in real terms, which probably is dependent upon a Tactical Fighter Force decision, which we are assured by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) can be expected in the next few weeks. Expenditure on the acquisition of armoured vehicles and artillery declined by about 11 per cent in real terms. Expenditure on non-specified capital equipment-that is, non-specified in the Budget Papers-represents an increase of 25 per cent in real terms.

When one looks through the details of some of the items included under the heading 'Other capital equipment' one sees that the Defence Integrated Secure Communications Network project, which was the subject of a recent announcement, is one of the projects listed. One of the issues I would like the Minister to deal with if he replies in this debate is that of the extent to which the delay in the DISCON project as a result of the Government's decision to call fresh tenders for the project will result in savings this financial year. The estimates for the Department indicate that the cost of new commitments to be met in 1981-82 on the DISCON project amount to $14.756m. It would be interesting to know to what extent savings might result from a delay this financial year.

I want to discuss a little further the DISCON project, but before doing so I make this comment: It seems to me that what has happened in succeeding years with respect to acquisition projects is that, where there has been a delay in the acquisition of defence equipment-and that has been a fairly common occurrence-we have been able to save some money from the original allocation in the appropriations. We have not diverted that money to other projects in the defence program which perhaps could have been brought forward to accommodate some of the very real needs of the Defence Force. I think one of the reasons why we sometimes have a shortfall in defence expenditure compared with the allocation in the original appropriations is that we have delays in decision making as far as acquisition is concerned and that money which is thereby not spent in that financial year is not diverted elsewhere. If we want to keep up with our program of modernising and re-equipping our defence forces, I think we would do well to ensure that we bring forward other programs which could well fill the gap in expenditure terms and modernise other aspects of our defence forces.

On 10 September, the Minister for Defence announced that new tenders would be called for the DISCON communications project, that is, the communications project which would link every arm of the Defence Force throughout Australia-all the defence agencies-in a secure, integrated network. I should say initially that I have some interest in this project as the succesful tenderer earlier this year was in fact a company in my electorate, the Rockwell-Collins (Australasia) Pty Ltd company in Lilydale. I have no other interest in the project other than that the company is within my electorate. I should put that fact before the House so that other people may be able to judge the perspective which I bring to it.
The Minister said, in his statement on 10 September:

The first step in calling new tenders will be a public invitation to firms to register their interest. This is necessary in view of the time that has elapsed since the original list of four tenderers was agreed. A shortlist of companies will be selected from the responses and invited to tender.

I question the need to go right back to the beginning of the tendering process. It appears to me that there was no question that the company, which was originally the successful tenderer, was guilty of any impropriety. That is not being suggested at all. I know, from discussions that I have had with the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) and the Minister for Defence that there is no suspicion of that whatsoever. There was a change in the nature of the project in that the successful tenderer sought to change a major sub-contractor. It was judged by our defence officials that that was a substantial change to the original tender that was put in. But there is no evidence of any impropriety. Indeed, it appears that it was as a result of protests being put in by unsuccessful tenderers on the shortlist that the Government reconsidered the matter and decided, in order to ensure that everything was above board, that tenders should be called again.

I suggest that, in view of the unfortunate history that we have in this country of delays in our acquisition programs, it would have been better, would have met any requirements of propriety and would have ensured that our tendering process was above board, if we had gone back to the shortlist of four and invited them to come forward with fresh tenders rather than to start the whole project over again and again delay our acquisition program. It is possible that the Government cannot change its decision announced on 10 September, but I believe that the suggestion that I have put forward would have met all the requirements that the Government had in mind and would have enabled us to get on with the job a little more quickly than we have been able to do.

If one looks at the expenditure program for new capital equipment in the defence area, one concludes that the Government has maintained a commitment to some real growth in the defence vote. There are some pleasing aspects, especially the increased outlay on new base facilities. That has gone up by about 30 per cent in real terms. However, it may be that projects in this field have been brought forward to take up the slack in others, especially in the capital expenditure area. Nevertheless, the projects are probably long overdue in the provision of an adequate infrastructure.

The slowdown in capital equipment spending which I have mentioned already may get worse than the figures show if we continue with a persistent inability to make timely decisions and stick to acquisition timetables. In the long term, I believe that this problem is serious, leading to a bunching of projects and associated costs. It leads also to a growing obsolescence of the Defence Force and increased maintenance costs. However, I welcome the real progress that has been made in this defence vote and I trust that we will do even better in future years by sticking to our acquisition programs and meeting the original appropriation figures which were announced in the Budget Speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) in supporting the expressions of opinion made by Estimates Committee A on the Department of Foreign Affairs. It is a significant pointer to the standing of the Government, particularly the standing of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) when the Opposition with only four members was able to have carried a three part resolution in that Committee. Although the Minister was there with some 20 advisers, he could not get three members of the Government to support him to vote against our resolution. I think it is a disgraceful situation. I feel extremely sorry for the Minister. But it reflects the state of the Government and its attitude towards these very important considerations. It reflects also its ignorance of the real position.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a few remarks about the particular resolution that I moved that aid programs in Vietnam should be restored. The honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean) said earlier tonight what terrible people the Vietnamese were for diverting their resources to aggressive warefare in Kampuchea. Of course, if he had been there, had a look around, and had talked to people on the spot, he would have seen that that was not what was happening at all. In fact the Vietnamese forces in Kampuchea have brought peace and stability to Kampuchea. He knows that and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) knows that. It is to the credit of the honourable member for Kooyong that he persuaded the Government that it should drop its recognition of Pol Pot. Pol Pot caused all the killing and the instability in Kampuchea. It was not the Vietnamese. I say the incursion by the Vietnamese in Kampuchea advisedly because it was not an invasion as far as the Kampucheans are concerned. If the honourable member for Perth had gone there, he would have found out very quickly that the Kampucheans welcomed the Vietnamese. They do not see them as invaders. They see them as their saviours because they have brought peace and stability to the greater part of Kampuchea.

The argument that we have wasted our economic resources in Kamuchea is nonsense because these people are very poorly paid. They do not cost much to maintain. They have to be paid and fed wherever they are, whether in Vietnam or Kampuchea. In fact, when we were in Kampuchea the agricultural position was better there than it was in Vietnam. So that is quite an irrelevant argument and it just does not stand up. To cut off those aid programs was a very petty action unworthy of the Australian nation. They were not of terribly great import; they were fairly symbolic gestures. But we spent money in sending cattle over there and then we cut off the program that would have established pastures to support the cattle. I do not know what has happened to the cattle now. So the money has been wasted. We spent money on putting down the foundations for a milk factory which was then taken away and put somewhere else. That is more of the Australian taxpayers' money that has been wasted by t's very petty action of cutting off two aid programs which had a symbolic value. This action of ours was very hurtful to the Vietnamese people.

I think we should reconsider that proposition. The Vietnamese need aid from wherever they can get it. Of course, the Soviet Union has been assisting them for many years, not just recently but since about 1968. The Americans, of course, who have caused all of the destruction there have not given them anything at all. They have been left in the lurch. Then we criticise them because they accept aid from the Soviet Union.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Care for the Elderly-Qantas: Use of Excess Capacity by Domestic Passengers-East Timor-Explanation of Incident Involving the Member for O'Connor

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Australia approximately 1.5 million people, or 10 per cent of the population, are over the age of 65. By the year 2001 the number will increase by over half a million. Most individuals will eventually suffer from some form of permanent impairment associated with aging, and so it must be in the ultimate interests of the community as a whole to encourage measures designed to minimise community disruption. As I described earlier this week, there are many studies available at present which show quite clearly the gains for the community in the greater freedom for elderly people living independently. Even patients who have suffered strokes are able to achieve and maintain significant gains in the activities of normal living through community rehabilitation. The savings resulting from returning patients to their homes or families, or to independent living, will more than pay for the costs of providing rehabilitation services in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: A Telecom Australia report on the disabled published recently states that approximately 20 per cent of those over 65 years of age suffer from some handicap. Within this group are the greatest concentration of people handicapped by rheumatism, athritis, strokes, hearing impairment and sight defects. One of the greatest fears of elderly disabled people living alone is that of suffering a heart attack or stroke and being unable to obtain assistance. It is estimated that over 50,000 persons would appreciate some sort of alarm system which enables a person either to obtain assistance when required or to have assistance dispatched when the subsriber fails to respond to checking calls.

In my electorate, a Bayswater man, Mr Norman Wiggett, has developed a new home help crisis intervention service which will provide medical and/or other emergency services at the touch of a button. This system is aimed at age and invalid pensioners and others in the community who are handicapped or isolated from rapid access to emergency help. There are, of course, many such systems being developed commercially at present and they are regarded by groups working with the elderly and the handicapped as extremely advantageous. The difference perhaps with Mr Wiggett's system is that he is determined to provide it as a community service-a non-profit organisation. To this end he has been involved in all sorts of lobbying and publicity efforts to try to convince State and Federal governments of the importance and value of their support for this scheme.

His 'visec-assist-alert' unit, once installed, provides an automatic dialling system which contacts a central monitoring point through normal telephone links. All the subscriber needs to do to activate the system in an emergency is to push a button on a wall unit or on a small hand held transmitter which is carried at all times. The system then contacts a central monitoring station, run by the Handicapped and Aged Emergency Telephone Answering Service, whose round the clock monitoring staff ascertain the nature of the problem and alert the necessary emergency services. The system is tested daily-or hourly if required-both to ensure that the equipment is working and to let monitoring staff know the subscriber is well enough to carry out the check procedure. If the check is not received at a pre-arranged time each day, the monitors make their own checks, ensuring that, even if the subscriber is incapacitated and unable to reach the wall unit or to work the hand unit, help is never too far away.

I have inspected and tested Mr Wiggett's system and find it most impressive. Each 'visec-assist-alert' unit comprising the wall unit and portable transmitter, costs around $300. Monitoring at this stage costs $78 a year, or $1.50 per week. Mr Wiggett would like to be able to provide the equipment free to every person who wishes to become a subscriber. To this end he has contacted Federal and State authorities and, although several departments have expressed great interest in his scheme, he has been unable to gain government backing. He has therefore had to spend many thousands of hours in publicising the scheme through various service agencies and businesses in the hope of attracting individuals and groups to donate a unit for the use of a subscriber. He has even contemplated a national system of raffles which he hopes would raise enough money to purchase a number of units each year for pensioners.

I contend that this is a disgraceful situation. We have an individual who has provided the research and produced a scheme which would undoubtedly save the Government a considerable amount of the funds allocated at present to institutional care. It would also provide security and independence for many thousands of our citizens. Mr Wiggett is keen to provide this as a non-profit service, and yet he cannot get the support of the Government. Such a system, coupled with a real commitment to community health and the provision of domiciliary care through municipalities, would provide elderly people with the freedom to remain at home in a familiar environment and yet retain the security of knowing that specialist assistance is only minutes away. It is time for this Government to re-assess its policies towards the aged and handicapped in our community. Modern research and new technology quite clearly indicate that the Government's present schemes are not in the best interests of the community, and that there are exciting and innovative ways available of ensuring that all our citizens are able to live full and satisfying lives, not just until age or infirmity catches up with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you will well recall, earlier this afternoon I addressed myself to the question of the use of the excess capacity of Qantas Airways Ltd by domestic passengers on domestic sectors-for example, Perth to Sydney and Perth to Melbourne. I demonstrated that the use of that excess capacity has taken place when the domestic airlines have been caught in industrial disputes. I believe there is evidence that there are no practical problems to that practice being allowed to continue in normal times. In fact, the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) has recognised that the proposition is feasible in terms of administration. If the proposal were to be adopted in the longer term, it could certainly be improved in that at the exit point for domestic passengers there could be a separate queue so that those passengers would not have to join the longer queue of passengers returning from international flights originating outside Australia. The Department of Transport has estimated that when Qantas flies between Perth and eastern Australia up to 600 seats are available in each direction. The actual number of seats vacant in a particular week may be less than that figure, depending on a number of factors. The Department anticipates that the number of vacant seats will diminish as a result of recently announced reduced fares for international travel between Perth and the United States of America on Qantas services. My argument is a very simple one. Even if only one seat is going begging, I believe it is an economic and community social waste which should not be countenanced.

SPEECH.PARA: Qantas has suggested to the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares and in other forums that it could offer its excess capacity to domestic passengers for a fare of $199 one way. When I asked the Minister about this in April he said that he had initiated discussions between the airlines to see whether Qantas's capacity could be used on the domestic routes. I can see two ways in which Qantas's capacity could be employed. Firstly, we could look at the recently announced decision by the Minister to allow East West Airlines Ltd to operate a specialised air service over the two-airline route of Sydney to Canberra. I believe Qantas could put forward a similar proposal to operate a specialised service which in itself would not directly threaten the two-airline policy, which the Government is keen to preserve and protect. Such a specialised service could simply involve passengers going out to the airport and purchasing their tickets on board the plane. Perhaps they would be allowed to carry only the luggage that they could on board the aircraft so as not to delay unnecessarily the incoming or outgoing international flights.

If it were deemed to be too detrimental to the two-airline policy for Qantas to be allowed to sell directly its excess capacity to the air fare paying public, I believe, there would be a second way round the problem. That would be for Qantas to be allowed to sell its capacity to the two airlines and they in turn could market the tickets to the public and gain the profit from those seats. The point is that, firstly, there would be bottoms on seats and the capacity would not be wasted. Secondly, we would have a two-tiered fare level. People could still travel across the continent by normal, regular domestic services but every now and then, depending upon the incoming or outgoing flights, excess capacity would be available for people at a cheaper fare. I do not in any way believe that this would strike at the two-airline policy. I do not believe it would lessen the demand for the services of the two domestic airlines currently flying across the continent as most of their planes are full. I believe the excess capacity of Qantas at the much reduced fare-about $100 cheaper than what is presently available-would, in fact, create demand and generate traffic.

One of the great problems in America when it experimented with deregulation and cheaper airline fares was that the services on the ground at the airports could not cope with the number of people who for the first time were able to fly. I believe that if Qantas were allowed to sell its excess capacity, either through the airlines or directly to the public, we would see the creation of demand along the same lines as we have seen in America. At present we have a wasteful situation which is denying to many people an opportunity to avail themselves of a lower fare in order to be able to travel backwards and forwards across the country. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) said in April that he was initiating discussions with the airline. I hope that, over the months that have expired since then, they have exhausted all the issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is only about two years too late.
—Like the honourable member for Fremantle, I look forward to an early definitive response as to when Qantas will be allowed to offer this service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly about Sir Keith Shann's statement that the Australian journalists who had been murdered by the Indonesians in Portuguese East Timor in 1974 had asked for it and got it. I think this statement was outrageously obscene. It was insensitive in the extreme and highly offensive to most Australians, and especially so to the relatives and friends of the victims of the Indonesian brutality. I find it very difficult to understand how a former senior diplomat could make such offensive, misleading and generally undiplomatic statements. To say that the journalists were told not to go to the area raises questions of who told them and when they were told. It is interesting to note that when Senator Gietzelt and I visited East Timor in August 1975 we were advised in Darwin by Department of Foreign Affairs officers not to go.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe now that they did not want us to go because they did not want the Parliament or the Australian people to know the truth of the situation in East Timor and because what was happening there was quite different to what they were telling the public was happening. I think the journalists went to East Timor for the same reason; they wanted to break the curtain of silence and deceit about what was going on and to inform the Australian people of what was happening in a friendly country, a country that had been our loyal ally in World War II, situated only 150 miles from Darwin. To do this they had to get as near as possible to where the action was and, of course, this always involves a degree of risk. But to say that they had deliberately and unnecessarily exposed themselves to risk is, in my view, a cowardly slander on a courageous group of young Australians who were there to do a legitimate job of informing the Australian people. I believe that if they had been in possession of all the relevant information which the Government had regarding Indonesian invasion plans they may have acted differently. I believe that if anyone is culpable it is those government officials who deliberately withheld from them vital information which might well have saved their lives.

The allegation that the journalists were wearing Fretilin uniforms is irrelevant and has no standing as there was no such thing as a Fretilin uniform. The Fretilin forces were wearing Portuguese uniforms in defence of sovereign Portuguese territory, which also happened to be their own country. Letters in the Press today indicate quite clearly that the journalists were definitely not wearing uniforms of any kind. To use this propaganda is just to parrot Indonesian propaganda. The film of the attack at Balibo shows quite clearly that the journalists went to great lengths to identify themselves as Australians by painting the Australian flag very clearly and prominently on the house they occupied. There is no question that the Indonesians knew that they were Australians, and they were murdered.

I have always had a favourable opinion of Sir Keith Shann and I am at a loss to understand the motivation for such strong and insensitive language. The answer could lie in Sir Keith's business interests. We know, for instance, that he is a former president of the Australian-Asian Business Council. I understand that he recently visited Indonesia on a lecture tour at government expense and addressed the Australian Confederation of Industry on his return. I believe that Sir Keith is also a director of Mount Isa Mines Holding Co. These are, of course, quite legitimate interests, but when an Australian citizen's interest in another country leads him to make harsh and unfounded judgments about citizens of his own country who have died in the service of their country I think we must seriously question that judgment.

It seems to me to be an occupational hazard of Australian ambassadors to Indonesia that they succumb to the seductive charms of their host country and finish up acting as ambassadors for the host country rather than for their own country. I hope that in this situation Sir Keith Shann sees fit to apologise to all whom he has so grievously offended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nice to hear the noises start before Opposition members even know what I am going to say.
—We know what you are going to say.
—That is good because the honourable member might learn something.
—Order! The honourable member will address himself to the Chair and not to individuals of the House.

—This morning I chose to try to tell this House some matters of considerable importance and to give a comparison of the situation as it existed with the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding). It is very easy, as I have pointed out on many occasions, to be the accuser. It is interesting to know that I can tell the honourable member for Melbourne Ports how it feels to be accused and, in fact, to be accused incorrectly. There are many degrees of accuracy in this place, but it appears to me that at any time there are those who are prepared to conduct a form of kangaroo court: They stand and read newspaper articles and from those articles, they choose to prove that a person has done anything they like. We, as politicians, are pretty well aware that the Press chooses to publish parts of things and to give to them a context which suits the sensational nature of most newspapers today. If anybody wishes to continue to read pieces from newspapers referring to my activities in the past-in this case I am talking about 1967-I think it would not be bad if he did what I am about to do, that is, to read some extracts from the actual findings of Chief Justice Sir Albert Wolff.

SPEECH.PARA: I started to tell the House today that the case to which everybody refers actually was in two parts. When my enemies in Carnarvon discovered that the successful conviction and fine of $48 that they had achieved was insufficient to have me removed from the Shire of Carnarvon and that it was necessary to achieve a gaol sentence, it did not deter them at all from continuing with their arrangement. They consequently did so and their appeal was subsequently rejected. The fact is that the Chief Justice overturned quite a bit of the evidence which the local court magistrate said he believed. It is not possible to read the whole of his findings but I will read pieces. On page 4 he said, referring to me: 'He must know the disastrous consequences that may ensue should he ever take the law into his own hands again. The magistrate deals with the core of the matter. His findings on the main issue must be accepted, but on the question of the severity of the assault there was evidence that the only visible injury McGibbon received was a small laceration near the hairline on his forehead.' If the next speaker decides to get up to say that the laceration was three and three-quarters of an inch long I point out that it was, in fact, three-quarters of an inch long. McGibbon said that he had a lump on his forehead but nobody else substantiated this. The nursing sister-do not worry, he was carted immediately up to the hospital by the people concerned-who cleaned and dressed the wound just after the assault said that he had no other injury except a small laceration. The doctor who examined McGibbon some days later noticed a small laceration and was not able to find anything else. He said specifically that there was no bruising. We are talking about a bashing. Some of the evidence for the prosecution suggested that Wilson was raining blows-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did it?

—Oh, come off your artificial laughter. Look, I can do this to Clyde Holding every day of the week. Some of the evidence for the prosecution suggested that Wilson was raining blows with all his force on McGibbon's head.

—Order! I think what the honourable member means is that the honourable member for Melbourne Ports was heard with quiet and respect. I think if honourable members are not selfish they might also do the same thing for the honourable member for O'Connor.
—I am carefully putting it on the record. It has been on the record since 1968.
—Order! I had not given the honourable member the call again, but I now do so.
—Well, I am going to run out of time.
—I call the honourable member for O'Connor.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I believe that this was highly exaggerated, having seen and examined those things. Anyhow that goes on. I have now run out of time. I have no doubt that the assault committed by the three respondents was related to the events which had taken place on the previous--
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Dawkins) agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for O'Connor from speaking for a further five minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to think that this is the way that people see it. But I just thought I might go on quoting the Chief Justice. He said: 'Seeing that McGibbon was undoubtedly a nuisance and inclined to violence, this is a mitigating feature'. He went on. The point I want to raise there is to substantiate this matter. This morning honourable members opposite said I could not substantiate that the man was, in fact, both violent and dangerous. In fact, on numerous occasions he was known to have assaulted people of the Aboriginal race and members of the police force. I am sure that members of the Opposition, through sources that they seem to be able to provide at any other time, could check that. Letters were written to the newspaper. One was written on 18 December by a Mrs Samsa. She said: 'Recently you reported another case against McGibbon and referred to a disturbance. The sworn evidence was, briefly, that McGibbon had a fight with a man in the street, came inside the hotel and soon afterwards punched a coloured woman sitting with her husband. She ran away but was followed and punched again. Then McGibbon returned and punched the husband. When Tuckey was called McGibbon attacked Tuckey's brother striking him across the bar. Evidence supported Tuckey's claim of being hit in the face also. McGibbon was convicted. Five attacks in quick succession is quite a disturbance in my opinion and good reason to have protection when meeting a man like this man in the future'. I ask that that letter be tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: Another letter that was sent to the West Australian was dated 13 December 1967. It was signed by a large group of Carnarvon businessmen. It is quite interesting because it says: 'However, what is now happening in the town is essentially of a political nature by a few people who wish to oust our elected president. As a prominent citizen and successful publican who is unafraid to speak out and fight for what he believes is of benefit to Carnarvon, he naturally makes certain enemies. However these are very much in the minority, the greatest majority knowing his value to this community and appreciate the large amount of good work he has done for Carnarvon's people. It is understood that after close investigation the Native Welfare Department considered the case closed. If this is so who is providing the funds for additional action now being taken and why if it is not for personal political gain? Also, why did the same people not rush to support the native concerned when he was involved in two assault cases this week? 'These were the people on the spot. These are the people who knew what was going on'. I have the original of that letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If I could interrupt the honourable member for a minute. He sought leave to table a letter. Is that the letter that the honourable member read out anyway?
—I only read a piece of that letter.
—Do you wish it to be incorporated in Hansard?
—Yes, please. I do not mind, I have read the piece.
—Is leave granted?
—In granting leave for that Mr Deputy Speaker-
—No, it is just a matter of granting leave.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, additional to that. Might I suggest that the honourable member for O'Connor table and have incorporated the full text of the judgments from which he is now-
—That is a separate question. I am asking honourable members to give leave for the letters to be tabled.
—You are wasting my time.
—What do you mean by saying wasting your time? We just gave you another five minutes to make a mug of yourself.
—Well what about it?
—Why don't you table the whole lot?
—Is leave granted?
—I do not mind, I just chose to read a bit of it.
—Well table it; table the whole lot.
—I hope that the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) reads from the rest of it, but he will read it from the newspaper, will he not?
—Why not? Table the whole lot.
—I do not mind tabling the whole lot.
—Have it incorporated.
—The thing that I have to do is try to finish my task.
—Order! The honourable member has been given leave to speak for another five minutes. I suggest that the House let him get on with it.

—If we consider that there was not a plot organised by the Australian Labor Party, we might ask ourselves why on 1 December 1967 another leading member of the Labor Party decided to write to the newspaper suggesting that things were not as they should be. It is quite interesting that he was able to get a letter in the paper in such a very short time when the actual statement appeared in the newspaper only on 29 November. One can say one of two things about the person who wrote the letter, the first one being that, as a politician, he should not judge by what was published in the newspaper and the second being that he had an ulterior motive. It might be interesting for the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) to look at the article because his father wrote it. I have a photocopy of that letter here for his benefit. The point is that I still argue that if there was a basher of people around at the time it was Raymond McGibbon. I still argue that the action I took was, as the Chief Justice suggested, exaggerated. I still argue that it happened in 1967. As I said this morning, if we choose to keep up this type of innuendo and pressure, I am quite happy to play the game but I will not expect members from the other side of the House to jump up and scream their heads off if I interject on one of them.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence. There has been some misunderstanding about what it was agreed should be incorporated in Hansard. My understanding is that we agreed to incorporate not only the first item that the honourable member brought forward but also the full text of the document.
—That was not my understanding. I did not think that leave was granted.
—As far as I was concerned, leave was granted for the incorporation of the judge's decision also. Could you check on that?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, that is not the case.

—The Chair does not need any help on this at present. The question I put to the honourable member was whether he would grant leave for incorporation of a letter in Hansard. To my knowledge that leave was never given. Is the honourable member now saying that leave is given?
—It is certainly given in relation to the first item, and in relation to the full text of the judgment, if the honourable member so desires.

—That is a proposition that has not been put to the Chair until now. There is no question that the honourable member for O'Connor did not seek leave to have that document incorporated in Hansard. Is that a point of order? Have we now cleared up the matter and is leave granted for the letter to be incorporated in Hansard?
—I move that an extension of time be given to the honourable member for O'Connor.
—There is no such question before the Chair at this stage. Does the honourable member for Fremantle now wish to speak on the adjournment debate?
—Why not, Mr Deputy Speaker?
—I move that an extension of time be given to the honourable member for O'Connor.
—The honourable member may move for an extension of time, but there has already been a suspension of the Standing Orders. Frankly, I think that is enough in an adjournment debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the couple of minutes that are available to me I wish to say that, insofar as the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) took the opportunity to assail again his victim in the case, I do not think it matters two bits whether this incident occurred yesterday or 20 years ago. The fact is that it occured in 1967. I simply want to read what was said by the magistrate who first examined this case. The West Australian of 29 November states:

SPEECH.PARA: The magistrate believed the evidence of McGibbon and other native witnesses, who said Stephen Tuckey and Huysing held McGibbon's arms while Wilson Tuckey struck him with a baton-like weapon.
They said McGibbon had been quietly drinking with friends in the native bar of the Port Hotel when Wilson Tuckey ordered him to leave. He was leaving peacefully when he was attacked by the three men.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. Is the honourable member reading from a newspaper article and saying that it was a record from the court?
—I said that I was reading from the West Australian and reading what the magistrate said.
—Can the honourable member guarantee that that is an accurate interpretation? Otherwise, the honourable member is imputing--
—Later, on 12 December, in the proceedings--
—I raise a point of order.
—Order! There is no point of order. It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until Tuesday next at 1.45 p.m.
