QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: to ask Mr Speaker:

QUESTION.PARA: What was the annual total cost to the Commonwealth Government of Australia's participation in the Inter-Parliamentary Union for each of the years 1978-79 to 1980-81.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many unofficial post offices were closed in Western Australia during (a) 1979-80 and (b) the period 1 January 1981.
(2) Is the Government determined to phase out or substantially reduce unoffical post offices from Australia Post operations; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Australia Post is obliged under the Postal Services Act to continually review its network of post offices (official and non-official) to ensure that the facilities and services provided best meet the reasonable needs of the community, having regard to economy and efficiency. Under this program, areas may be identified where new post offices are necessary while other post offices may be identified for closure, where the level of business transacted is not sufficient to justify retention. It is Australia Post's objective, in the latter circumstances, to ensure that reasonable alternative arrangements are made for communities affected by the withdrawal of a post office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Royal Australian Air Force recently undertake a study aimed at providing the basis for Defence Force takeover of the functions of air traffic control using military airfields for the study; if so, who initiated the study.

(2) Are Defence personnel indemnified against civil damages claims which may arise during any period when Defence personnel are carrying out air traffic control functions which are normally a function of Department of Transport employees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) From time to time the Government has, as an action of responsible national management, sought advice on ways in which the Departments of Transport and Defence could best co-operate to ameliorate the effects of industrial disruptions affecting air traffic control services, if the Government believed such an action was necessary. In view of a number of incidents in recent months, both within Australia and overseas, these matters have been reviewed again recently. The precise nature and scope of any actions that might be taken would be a matter for judgement by the Government.

(2) In accordance with the principle of the vicarious liability of an employer for actions which his employees perform in the course of their employment, the Commonwealth would be liable for the actions of Defence personnel performing air traffic control functions in the circumstances described in (1) above. If an action were to be brought against a member of the Defence Force, in respect of matters occurring in the course of his employment, that member's defence would be arranged at Commonwealth expense and damages awarded against the member, would be met by the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Commonealth Trading Bank lifted the charge for issuing a bank draft in a foreign currency from $1 to $5, which represents a 400 per cent increase.
(2) If so, when did this massive increase occur.
(3) What was the reason for such a sharp increase.
(4) Was the increase announced; if so, when and what were the terms of the announcement.
(5) What are the charges by other major trading banks for this same service.
(6) Have any of these banks increased their charges recently; if so, when and by how much.
(7) Did any of the other major trading banks announce any reason for the increase; if so, what were the terms of the announcement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (3) and (4) Bank charges of this nature are a matter for determination by the bank concerned, but are generally designed to cover, at least partially, the administrative costs incurred in providing the relevant services.

The Managing Director of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation has advised that the Commonwealth Trading Bank's charges for its overseas services were reviewed by the Bank earlier this year. The $1 charge for 'small' foreign currency drafts had been unchanged for some five years. The results of that review disclosed that substantial losses were being incurred on the issue of foreign currency drafts for relatively small amounts. Accordingly, it was decided to apply charges for drafts that went some way towards recovering costs.
The new charges for drafts up to the equivalent of $2,000 in foreign currencies are as follows:
When issued on the office of the Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia at London or New York-$3
When issued on an overseas bank-$5
Drafts issued on the Bank's own offices are less costly to process because of more highly automated procedures. For drafts over the equivalent of $2,000 there is no charge.
The new charges were applied from 3 July 1981. There was no public announcement of the new charges. Customers are informed by staff at the Bank's branches.

(5), (6) and (7) It is understood that, when the CTB's new fees were introduced, charges by other banks for the same service ranged up to $2. The Managing Director is not aware of any recent announcement on charges for drafts issued by other banks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of producing and distributing the poster entitled 'Working for Australia-Working for You'.
(2) How many copies were (a) printed and (b) distributed.
(3) In view of the Government's decision to abolish the Community Youth Support Scheme are the posters to be recalled; if not, what remedial action is to be taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The cost of printing the wall chart was $3860.10. Distribution of the wall chart commenced on 9 March 1981, but it is not possible to identify the cost of distributing the wall chart from the Department's total distribution and postal expenditure.

(3) The Government has decided that existing Community Youth Support Scheme projects will receive their current level of funds until 28 February 1982. From that time, the Scheme will operate under new and improved guidelines. Although it was never intended that the wall chart would be recalled, consideration is being given to issuing a revised edition consistent with the new functional format of the Government's employment and youth affairs programs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales: Restrictions on Development

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) concluded a review relating to the need to maintain the existing restrictions on development (a) within 1.6 kilometres and (b) between 1.6 kilometres and 4.8 kilometres of the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales.
(2) If so, has the AAEC recommended any variation to existing restrictions and what are the proposals.
(3) Has the Commonwealth Government or the AAEC canvassed any of the proposals referred to in part (2) with (a) the Sutherland Shire Council and (b) New South Wales State Authorities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The AAEC has not recommended any variation to existing restrictions. However, on the basis of the review it has concluded that with the completion of engineering modifications now in progress, public safety would be protected without any need for land use restrictions outside the 1.6 km zone around HIFAR. It is expected that these modifications will be completed about the end of 1982.

(3) Sutherland Shire and other local councils are being kept informed of these matters in discussions with senior AAEC officials. The Prime Minister has advised the Premier of New South Wales of the Commission's conclusions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales: Potential Hazards

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) embarked on a study into the potential hazards associated with the existing nuclear reactors or the possible siting of a new reactor at the research establishment at Lucas Heights, New South Wales.
(2) If so, when will the report be made available to the (a) Commonwealth Parliament, (b) New South Wales authorities and (c) public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2). The AAEC has been engaged in a continuing assessment of any possible hazards to the public from the operation of the two reactors at Lucas Heights since they were first commissioned. However, there is no specific report as such. There are no plans for a new reactor, at Lucas Heights or elsewhere.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nuclear Reactors at Lucas Heights, New South Wales: Potential Hazards

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government received reports on the potential hazards associated with the operation of nuclear reactors of the same size as the HIFAR reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) research establishment at Lucas Heights, New South Wales operating in (a) the United States of America, (b) the United Kingdom, (c) France, (d) the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republic, (e) Germany, (f) Japan and (g) Canada; if so, when will the reports be made available to the (i) Commonwealth Parliament, (ii) State authorities and (iii) public.

(2) In relation to the reactors referred to in part (1), (a) what is the age and location of each reactor and (b) how many persons are reported as living (i) with 1.6 kilometres and (ii) between 1.6 kilometres and 4.8 kilometres of each reactor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the countries listed the only reactors of similar size and type to the Commission's HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights are two in the United Kingdom and one in the Federal Republic of Germany. The Government is not aware of any reports on the potential hazards from the operation of these plants.

(2) The United Kingdom reactors are located near Didcot, Berkshire and were constructed in 1956 and 1957. The FRG reactor is at Julich and was constructed in 1961. There is no information available on persons living in proximity to these reactors.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nuclear Reactors at Lucas Heights, New South Wales: Decommissioning

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: HIFAR Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and energy, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the expected working life of the existing HIFAR Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales.
(2) What is the estimated cost of (a) maintaining or (b) upgrading HIFAR.
(3) For how many years is it expected that the working life of HIFAR would be extended by upgrading it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not possible to determine precisely the working life of HIFAR. Relevant factors were discussed in response to Question No. 3902 on 17 October 1979.

(2) (a) and (b) In 1979 the Commission determined that in order to ensure continued safe and reliable operation of HIFAR (at its current power level) consistent with the best current international practice, it was desirable to undertake a program of engineering upgrading of the reactor. Initial estimates show this program would cost $4.7 million over five years. $0.05 million was provided for this purpose in the Government's 1980-81 Budget and $0.52 million has been provided in the current Budget.
(3) The envisaged upgrading program is expected to ensure the safe and reliable operation of HIFAR until at least the mid-1990s.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: HIFAR Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to the proposed safety upgrading of the HIFAR Reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Research Commission Establishment at Lucas Heights, New South Wales (a) what work is to be carried out in each of the remaining years of the 5 year program and (b) what work was carried out last year.
(2) What other work for the upgrading of the HIFAR Reactor is proposed in the next 5 years and what is its estimated cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) In the current year work will continue on the reactor containment and emergency core cooling system, and will commence on the power supply and the portable handling cell. Following this, the program provides for work to be carried out on general instrumentation, the secondary cooling system, auxiliary systems, and experimental facilities.
It is not possible at this stage to provide an annual schedule for future work.
(b) last year work was carried out on the reactor containment and the emergency core cooling system.
(2) Apart from the safety upgrading program referred to in (1), there is no other program for the upgrading of HIFAR.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he noted that the Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay received over 1500 submissions from servicemen and servicewomen many of whom expressed areas of discontent relating to matters outside the committee's terms of reference.

(2) Did the areas of discontent relate to (a) the obligation of Defence Force Members to pay for rations and quarters, (b) the level of uniform maintenance allowance, (c) the charges levied for certain items of clothing, (d) the adequacy of payments made in association with postings, (e) inconsistencies in respect of the standards of married quarters and rentals relating thereto, (f) inconsistencies in relation to the payment and adequacy of the education allowance and (g) the level, frequency and adequacy of reunion travel for separated families.
(3) What measures does he propose to take to alleviate the expressed problems referred to in part (2).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) I am aware of a level of concern over the matters listed. Frequently reviews are carried out to rectify, if possible, any shortcomings. More specifically:
(a) Rations and Quarters-The circumstances under which Defence Force members are required to pay for rations and quarters, is currently under review.

(b) & (c) Uniform Maintenance Allowance and Clothing Charges-Although no adjustment was made to uniform maintenance allowance between 1975 to 1980, the rates have been increased twice recently. A 35 per cent increase was introduced in July 1980 along with an annual review adjustment of 3.028 per cent in July 1981. Another review is now in progress and changes to the rates, as prices change, will occur annually in future with adjustments to be effective in July of each year.

(d) Payments in Association with Postings-These payments include Disturbance Allowance, Vehicle Allowance, Temporary Rental Allowance, Temporary Accommodation Allowance and Travelling Allowance. On these issues:

1. Disturbance Allowance-A survey of expenses incurred on removal on posting was recently carried out, the results of which are now being analysed to ascertain whether variations to the current rates of Disturbances Allowance are appropriate, and whether other measures for meeting the problems of expenses during removal should be taken.
2. Vehicle Allowance-The rates of Vehicle Allowance are the same as those applying to all other Commonwealth employees. The rates are reviewed annually.

3. Temporary Rental Allowance-Temporary Rental Allowance ceilings, which govern the payment of the allowance, are reviewed periodically for all localities. New ceilings have been recommended to take effect from 1 September 1981, as a result of the last review.
4. Temporary Accomodation Allowance-This is a reimbursement allowance, based upon actual expenditure. It is, therefore, self-adjusting.

5. Travelling Allowance-The rates of Travelling Allowance are reviewed annually in accordance with surveys carried out by the Public Service Board. The Public Service Board rates flow on to members of the Defence Force with the same date of effect.

(e) Married Quarters and Rentals-Scales and standards have been set for married quarters to ensure that new quarters are built to community standards. When funds are available, existing quarters are improved or modified as close as possible to the required standard. A Working Party is currently examining the development of programmes for replacing replacing quarters that cannot be satisfactorily improved, and a review of existing scales and standards is currently being undertaken. Rental housing for service members is provided through the Group Rent Scheme, which directly relates rents to the size and quality of each quarter. The scheme also contains a rental appeal and rebate system to which every tenant has access. Rentals have not been increased for some time, and are presently under review.

(f) Education Allowances-Education Allowance rates are reviewed annually by the Public Service Board, based upon fees charged at a selected range of private schools within Australia. The resultant rates flow on to the Defence Force. A Defence Standing Committee is available to assess the cases of individuals who believe their circumstances merit special consideration. In addition, the conditions under which Education Allowance may be available have been widened considerably over the last two or three years.

(g) Reunion Travel-The level, frequency and adequacy of reunion travel is continually under review and the rules applied to them closely follow those approved by the Public Service Board for other Commonwealth employees. Recently, the number of annual visits by children being educated in Australia, whose parents are posted overseas, was increased from two to three. In addition, family reunion and leave travel arrangements for members serving in remote areas have recently be widened.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tenosynovitis: Department of National Development and Energy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article based on statements of Leonce Kealy in the National Times, 6-12 September 1981, referring to a former Prime Minister's claim that Australia had no knowledge of E Systems or TRW and no Australian politician entered the central computer rooms at Pine Gap.

(2) Does he have evidence from Mr Sam Calder, a former member of this House, union officials and others that the firms concerned deceived Australian employees by (a) failing to honour verbal undertakings and (b) using false claims of security requirements and of Australian government directives to refuse written confirmation of employment conditions.

(3) Has he warned the United States of America authorities of (a) the unreliability of its private contractors, (b) their contractors' alleged involvement in framing an Australian on a charge of sabotage and (c) the doubt this may throw on charges brought forward against Mr Christopher Boyce.

(4) Will he insist on (a) equal access for Australians and Americans to Pine Gap and (b) equal opportunity for Australians and Australian contracting firms at Pine Gap; if not, will he acknowledge that Pine Gap is part of a strategic intelligence system which Australia has renounced under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I would, however, clarify an ambiguity in the honourable member's question; the reference to a former Prime Minister was not made by Mr Kealy. In addition I refer the honourable member to the statement by Mr Whitlam of 4 May 1977 (Hansard, page 1520) and suggest that if he compares that with the report in the newspaper he referred to, he will observe that some liberty has been taken with the former Prime Minister's statement of that date.

Mr Whitlam did not state that Australia had no knowledge of E Systems or TRW; neither did he state that no Australian politician entered the central computer rooms at Pine Gap. A number of fully briefed Australian politicians have visited that area both before and after Mr Barnard did in February 1973.
(2) (a) and (b) No.
(3) (a) and (b) No.

(c) I refer the honourable member to the Hansard of 4 May 1977, page 1524 when I responded to the then Leader of the Opposition's statement which inter alia referred to Christopher Boyce. The facts remain now as they were then: Boyce was convicted of espionage by a jury of his peers in a trial conducted under the proper processes of United States law.

(4) (a) I refer the honourable member to my statement of 2 June 1977 (Hansard pages 2411-12) in which I said that those Australians and Americans at the site whose responsibilities so require have equal right of access to all parts of the Joint Defence Space Research Facility and to its activities. Access to the facility by personnel who are not normally employed at the site is determined according to the nature of their requirement to visit the facility; there is no discrimination between Australians and Americans on the basis of nationality.

(b) I refer the honourable member to Article 4 of the agreement relating to the Establishment of a Joint Defence Space Research Facility (JDSRF), dated 9 December 1966. In relation to the second part of this question it is the practice of the Government neither to confirm nor deny speculation or assertion concerning the role and functions of the JDSRF.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sales Tax: Exemption of Scientific Items

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the procedure for assessing the scientificity of items eligible for exemption under item 63 (1) of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.
(2) Do the officers assessing an item's tax liability have appropriate scientific training to enable them to determine whether or not an instrument or apparatus is scientific.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the question whether goods are scientific instruments or scientific apparatus for the purposes of item 63 (1) is decided by reference to the ordinary meaning of the term 'scientific' and to the nature and use of the goods concerned.

(2) Scientific training is not usually necessary to decide what is the ordinary meaning of the word 'scientific' or the nature or use of the goods. Where appropriate, the Commissioner makes inquiries in the relevant industry and from independent experts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cass The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) For the Agent Orange Pilot Study of medical records of ex-servicemen what were the qualifications required of the research workers involved in examining the records.
(2) Were those employed all trained in, and acquainted with, the World Health Organisation International Classification of Diseases of 1975.
(3) In the examination of hospital records, has the same group of research workers been employed.
(4) If this examination has not yet been carried out, will the same group of research workers do it.

(5) Was the format of the Agent Orange Pilot Study discussed with the workers involved in the examination of the medical records to ensure the maximum amount of relevant information was extracted, and appropriately recorded for subsequent computer analysis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Examination of the medical records of ex-servicemen was undertaken by staff occupying positions classified as Medical Record Officer. These staff are all qualified Medical Record Administrators who work under the overall direction of Medical Officers.

(2) Training and experience in the use of the International Classification of Diseases forms part of the course of training for Medical Record Administrators and this approach to disease classification was used.
(3) Yes.
(4) See 3 above.
(5) Yes, there have been detailed discussions at all levels with emphasis on the fact that the exercise under review was a pilot study.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cass The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is evidence of possible exposure of ex-servicemen to Agent Orange and associated toxic substances dependent on the individual ex-serviceman's recollection now or his recollection as recorded in the medical record.

(2) Were areas of service and changes in rank or corps of each ex-serviceman recorded in the pilot study for the correlation with the place and time of storage and use of Agent Orange and its associated substances as recorded in official military records in order to assess the possibility of exposure unknown to the individual ex-serviceman.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During the period of the Pilot Survey, two methods for determining the possible exposure of veterans to herbicides were evaluated.
(a) The flight paths of herbicide spraying missions (obtained in the herbs tape from the U.S.A.F.) were compared with troop location data from Army records.
(b) Veterans were asked to recollect whether they had been subject to aerial spraying and if so, to give details of the spraying aircraft, approximate height, time of spraying etc.

(2) Pilot Survey subjects were asked information about changes in rank and corps to assist with the determination of their location. Army data provides information of all troops by sub-units and so veterans have been asked to identify the sub-units to which they belonged.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cass The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When handling Agent Orange and related substances, how were all servicemen (a) informed of the nature of the chemicals and their possible effects on the individuals handling them, (b) advised on proper dress and proper handling procedures, (c) issued with appropriate protective clothing and (d) required to take all these precautions.
(2) Were all these procedures followed for all servicemen handling these toxic materials.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) & (2) I assume that the honourable member is referring to the use of herbicides in Vietnam.

Australian Forces used herbicides in Vietnam to clear firing zones and deny concealment to the enemy around perimeter fences and the like, but no records have been found to show that Australian Forces used the herbicide known as Agent Orange.

Operating and safety procedures relating to those herbicides used by the Australian Army in Vietnam are set out in an annex to a 1968 report by the Australian Army Operational Research Group on the spraying of herbicides at the site of the 1st Australian Task Force in Vietnam. I tabled that Report in the House on 27 March 1980 (House of Representatives Hansard, page 1311).

Further information is contained in a report, co-ordinated by the Department of Health, on the use and effects of pesticides. A copy of the Report, entitled 'Pesticides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and Their Use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study', has been placed in the Parliamentary Library.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cass The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: In the Agent Orange Pilot Study, have operations or injuries which may cause infertility been noted in the Vietnam veterans and the controls in order to assess the relationship of infertility to exposure to Agent Orange and related substances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of the pilot study is to test the questionnaire, assess response rates and provide sufficient information to determine the methodology to be used in a major study or series of studies. Any information which is supplied on the matters raised in the question is noted, but it will not be the basis for the drawing of conclusions as this is not a function of the pilot study.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many 50 cent royal wedding commemorative coins have been minted.
(2) What quantity has been supplied to (a) banks and (b) numismatic stores.
(3) Is it a fact that these coins can now be purchased only through Brisbane numismatic stores at 75 cents per coin; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Twenty million 50-cent Royal wedding commemorative coins are being minted. All coins are being issued through the banking system as part of the circulating currency. To date some 6.56 million pieces have been so issued; the balance will become available over the next two or three months. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Are widows of merchant seamen who were recently awarded service pensions in the 1981-82 Budget entitled to the same war widows pension as that paid to wives of T.P.I. pensioners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The decision announced in the Budget Speech for 1981-82 concerned the extension of service pension to Australian mariners who served in a 'theatre of war' in the 1939-45 War.

There are two types of pension payable under Repatriation legislation. Disability pensions, which include war widow's pensions, are compensatory payments for incapacity or death accepted as service-related while service pensions are social-welfare type payments similar to age and invalid pensions paid by the Department of Social Security.

Provision exists in the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940, for the payment of disability pensions to Australian mariners and their eligible dependants for the incapacity or death of mariners due to war injury. The rates of pension under that Act are basically the same as those specified in the Repatriation Act for incapacitated veterans and their eligible dependants.

A widow of an Australian mariner may be eligible under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act for payment of a war widow's pension if the death of her husband was a direct result of a war injury, or he was entitled to receive a disability pension at the Special (T. & P.I.) Rate immediately prior to his death, irrespective of whether or not his death was due to war injury.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 23 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum was spent on maintenance of equipment and facilities in Kakadu National Park in 1980-81 and what sum is allocated for maintenance during 1981-82.

(2) If the funding for maintenance has been reduced for 1981-82 what is the reason for this decision, taking into consideration the large sum of $2.3 million spent on capital works in Kakadu National Park in 1980-81.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable members's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During 1980-81 a total of $599,974 was expended by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service on operations at Kakadu National Park. Of that amount $83,147 was expended on maintenance of equipment and facilities. A total of $637,000 has been allocated for park operations in 1981-82, and funding for maintenance of equipment and facilities in Kakadu will be provided from that allocation.

(2) The cost of maintenance of assets installed in 1980-81 and in previous years will be met from the increased Kakadu park operations funds. The levels of expenditure will depend on the extent of required maintenance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 24 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he say whether Victoria has been allocated an annual commercial kangaroo kill quota of 30,000 at the request of the Victorian Government.
(2) Has the Commonwealth Government issued a licence to a Victorian Company to process kangaroo meat for human consumption and for export.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Victoria has been allocated a Commercial Quota for 1981 of 30,000 Eastern and Western Grey Kangaroos.

The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) received a request for this quota from the Victorian Ministry for Conservation on 20 January 1981. Following consultation on the proposal between ANPWS and the Ministry for Conservation, my predecessor, the Hon. M. J. R. MacKellar, M.P., agreed to the quota on 6 March 1981 and authorised ANPWS to advise the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Victorian Government of the decision.
(2) I am advised that a Victorian company was registered under the Export (Meat) Regulations on 12 March 1981 to enable the processing for export of kangaroo meat for human consumption.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 1153) Mr Charles asked me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In the recent Budget the Government granted service pensions to Australian merchant seamen. However, this excludes the many British and other allied mariners who now live in Australia and possibly Australians who served in other allied vessels during the war. Will the Minister give this House an assurance that the Government will include all Australians and allied merchant seamen when legislation is brought before this House granting service pensions to merchant seamen?
The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
A Bill will be introduced into Parliament shortly to provide for the extension of service pension eligibility to Australian merchant mariners.

Merchant mariners were not members of the forces but were civilians undertaking their normal occupation. The Government has recognised that, in war time, this occupation was subject to abnormal dangers; but they were not the only group of civilians exposed to enemy hostility.

In considering the competing demands of various groups for the extension of Repatriation benefits, the Government decided that, in the present climate of financial stringency, extension of service pension eligibility would, at this time, be limited to Australian mariners.

This will include a mariner employed in sea-going service on any ship registered in Australia, which traded between Australia and any other port or on a ship registered in New Zealand which operated from an Australian port; and a mariner who was, or whose dependants were, resident in Australia for 12 months before his employment on a ship registered outside Australia.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Northern Territory Disabled Persons: Aboriginal Affairs Projects

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What financial appropriations have been allocated by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for use in the Northern Territory for projects to assist the disabled during 1980-81.
(2) For what specific projects has this sum been allocated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) An amount of $34,500 was allocated in 1980-81 to the Australian National Council for the Blind to train Aboriginal Health Workers in rehabilitation techniques to assist visually handicapped Aboriginals in the Alice Springs area. The commencement of this program was delayed, and a modified version of the project has been included in 1981-82 programs with an estimated expenditure of $18,500.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that 400 meat workers at Borthwick's Meat Works, Murarrie, Queensland (some of whom have given up to 40 years of service to that employer) have been retrenched with a redundancy lump sum payment offer of $2000 each.

(2) If so, and in view of increased redundancies in the Australian work-force, will he urgently draft and introduce legislation similar to the United Kingdom Employment Protection (Consolidation) Act 1981, in order to provide Australian workers with a severance payment which, like that Act, will give adequate recognition to years of service in employment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that the Murarrie meatworks of Thomas Borthwick & Sons (Australasia) Ltd in Queensland has not re-opened since closing in November 1980 and that a redundancy agreement was reached between the Australasian Meat Employees Union and the company in May 1981 in respect of meatworkers employed at the works. I understand that the agreement was ratified by a meeting of the retrenched AMIEU members on 31 May 1981. The redundancy benefits to individual employees depended on a variety of factors including length of service, annual and long leave entitlements. The actual entitlements accruing to these retrenched employees are a matter between the company and each individual employee concerned.

(2) Under the Australian Constitution, the Commonwealth Parliament's power to legislate directly in respect of the general community is limited. It would not be possible for it to legislate along the lines of the United Kingdom Employment Protection (Consolidation) Act 1981.
I further refer the honourable member to the statement of the Minister for Industry and Commerce in response to the CITCA Report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 5 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Prime Minister in 1978 assure the National Aboriginal Conference that the Government would not fail Aboriginal communities seeking self-determination.
(2) Did the Minister's predecessor find no possibility of acceptance of Federal Government jurisdiction or of co-operation in meeting this promise to Aborigines.

(3) Is the present Queensland Minister for Aboriginal and Islander Affairs Advancement equally intransigent; if not, what progress has been made in providing land rights for Aboriginal communities in Queensland, and the right of Aboriginal co-operatives to acquire pastoral leases.

(4) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the report in the National Times of 31 May to 6 June 1981, that the National Party State Member for the area is reported to have said that Yarrabah is too good for a 'heap of boongs' littering it up and drinking on it.
(5) Is there any substance to this report; if so, has he sought the Queensland Government's response to this statement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Prime Minister in his address to the National Aboriginal Conference on 3 April 1978 referred to developments then occuring at Aurukun and Mornington Island and said: 'These communities have turned to us. We will not fail them'.
(2) No. My predecessor negotiated agreements with Queensland Ministers on the development of self-management for the Yarrabah community, near Cairns, in 1979.

(3) No. The Queensland Government is at present considering possible changes to land tenure and management arrangements for Queensland Aboriginal and Island reserves but has not yet announced its proposals. I have kept in touch with Queensland Ministers and with Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and have clearly stated the Commonwealth Government's position on this matter.

(4) and (5) I have seen the statement attributed to Mr Tenni and if it has been reported correctly I deplore the sentiments expressed. It is not however my practice to raise with the Queensland Government every statement affecting Aboriginals made by members of that Parliament.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Advertising and Promotion: Department of Industrial Relations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What evaluation has been made of the noise profiles of TAA's Airbus and Ansett's proposed new 767 aircraft.
(2) Was an evaluation carried out on the noise profiles of the 2 aircraft prior to orders being placed for each.
(3) What would be the noise levels generated by each aircraft in a typical day's service into the capital cities of (a) Melbourne, (b) Sydney and (c) Brisbane.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Both TAA's Airbus and Ansett's proposed new Boeing 767 aircraft are required to meet international aircraft noise certification standards established by the International Civil Aviation Organization in Annex 16 to the Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation and endorsed by Australia.
Flight testing to demonstrate compliance with the Annex 16 Standards were carried out by the manufacturer of the Airbus in France prior to delivery of the first TAA Airbus.
Similar demonstration of compliance will have to be undertaken by the manufacturer of the B767 aircraft before a noise certificate is issued.
(3) Noise measurements of the Airbus at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport show that the aircraft, in typical operations, produces the following average noise levels:
(a) on takeoff, 85 dB(A) at a point under the flight path 4,000 metres from the start of the runway, and 80 dB(A) at a point 6,500 metres from the start of the runway.
(b) on approach to landing, 90 dB(A) at a point under the flight path 1,700 metres from touchdown, and 82 dB(A) 5,000 metres from touchdown.
These figures would be similar for Melbourne and Brisbane airports.
Noise level data are not available for the Boeing 767 as specific noise level testing has not yet been carried out.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aborignal Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

Wages for up to 15 full-time Aboriginal trainees, including allowances and on costs 174,650 175,500 External Courses 5,000 5,000 Materials 3,500 3,500 Transport-fares, vehicles, repairs, fuel and oil 20,500 20,500 Salary for 2 training officers for Pilbara and Kimberley regions, including allowances and on costs 38,000 38,000 Vehicle equipment 850 . .

Length of Employment
Pilbara Kimberley
More than 12 months 5 0 9-12 months 4 1 6-9 months 5 1 3-6 months 16 15 Less than 3 months 6 27

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sydney and Melbourne Airports: Fire-fighting Equipment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Sydney and Melbourne airports the busiest airports for which his Department is responsible.

(2) To what extent, and how urgently, can the fire-fighting equipment at Sydney and Melbourne airports be used in association with the fire-fighting equipment used by State and local government authorities.

(3) Will his Department now consider adopting the Storz fire hose coupling as recommended by the Commonwealth fire board in its report of 5 May 1977 and which is progressively being adopted in New South Wales and Melbourne as indicated in the answer to question No. 232 (Hansard, 24 February 1981, page 84).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Departmental fire-fighting equipment can be used in association with equipment operated by State and local government authorities. This is achieved by the use of coupling adaptors and does not delay operations.

(3) As indicated in my answer to question No. 230 on 24 February 1981 the Commonwealth Fire Board, in its report recognised that two types of couplings, viz. British Instantaneous (BIC) and Storz, were gaining world wide and Australian acceptance. The Board considered that the Storz design offered marginal advantages and therefore adopted it as their recommended coupling. My Department adopted the BIC as standard for the purpose of airport fire fighting circa 1953, and having assessed the Storz coupling has continued to regard the BIC as a superior coupling for this particular application. It is understood that the Department of Defence maintains a similar view. No change is therefore planned, but appropriate adaptors are carried. State and local government authorities also have to carry adaptors to enable them to make connections between water main hydrants and their appliances.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Disputed Income Tax Assessments: Legal Proceedings

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Taxation Office at any stage required a signed statement from any person or persons with whom they are negotiating for the recovery of unpaid income tax to the effect that the person or persons concerned will not undertake legal proceedings against the Office following the outcome of the negotiations.

(2) Has the practice referred to in part (1) been referred to the Attorney-General's Department for a legal opinion; if not, will he do so; if so, what were the terms of the advice from the Attorney-General's Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A taxpayer negotiating with the Australian Taxation Office solely in relation to unpaid income tax would not normally have any right to undertake legal proceedings against the Taxation Office in relation to that unpaid tax. Accordingly the need to seek an undertaking of the kind referred to by the honourable member would not arise. However, negotiations aimed at achieving a compromise settlement of a disputed assessment may involve the question of the payment of tax ultimately agreed to be payable and it would normally be a condition of the settlement that the taxpayer would discontinue any legal proceedings instituted in relation to the disputed assessment.

(2) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the practice of requiring discontinuance of legal proceedings as a condition of settlement of disputes relating to assessments has not been specifically referred to the Attorney-General's Department. The settlement of disputes by way of compromise is a long established procedure in most forms of litigation. If, however, as frequently happens, a taxation dispute is settled by compromise after counsel has been engaged by the Crown Solicitor to represent the Commissioner of Taxation, the Crown Solicitor's officers and counsel will be involved in the settlement negotiations with the taxpayer and his representatives. These settlements usually require discontinuance of legal proceedings instituted by the taxpayer or the Commissioner.

(2) The term 'near miss' is not amenable to precise definition, but such occurrences are embraced in the air safety incident reporting system. Apart from the legal requirement to report incidents, pilots and other operational personnel are encouraged to submit incident reports concerning any circumstances which the originator believes to be undesirable or hazardous, including those in which an infringement of prescribed separation standards has been reported to have occurred. For the purpose of monitoring safety, no differentiation is made between those occurrences in which aircraft came into close proximity and those in which the separation reduction was relatively minor.
In the period under question there were three reported incidents at Adelaide which involved an infringement of separation standards or the potential for such infringement. The details are as follows:
Date
Circumstances

A Boeing 727 executed a go-around from a landing approach when it appeared that there may have been inadequate separation from a light aircraft which had previously landed
Two light aircraft came into close proximity following the unauthorised entry into controlled airspace by one of them
